verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]In the beginning was the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Word, and the Word was [note]3[/note]with God, and the [note]4[/note]Word was [note]5[/note][xref]c[/xref]God.
verse.note: [i]In the beginning[/i] means in eternity past. As the introduction to this Gospel, this chapter begins in eternity past with God, who had divinity but not humanity ([link]v. 1[/link]); it then passes through His creation of all things ([link]v. 3[/link]), His incarnation ([link]v. 14[/link]), His becoming the Lamb who takes away the sin of the world ([link]v. 29[/link]), and His being the Spirit who causes the believers to be transformed into living stones for His building ([link]vv. 32[/link], [link]42[/link]), and continues all the way to eternity future, in which the Son of Man, who has both divinity and humanity, is the center for the communication between heaven and earth and for the union of God and man in eternity. After this, [link]ch. 2[/link] shows that the principle of the Triune God as life is to change death into life ([link]2:1-11[/link]) and that the purpose of life is to build the house, the temple, of God ([link]2:13-22[/link]). In [link]chs. 3-11[/link], nine cases are given to illustrate how God as life meets the different needs of different kinds of people. As a result, in the beginning of [link]ch. 12[/link] a miniature of the church is produced ([link]12:1-11[/link]). From [link]12:12[/link] to the end of [link]ch. 17[/link] an explanation is given concerning how the church is produced through the multiplication and increase of the incarnated God-man by means of His death and resurrection. [link]Chapters 18-20[/link] show the accomplishing of the multiplication and increase, which causes Him to have many brothers ([link]20:17[/link]) and enables Him to enter into them ([link]20:22[/link]) to be their life and everything that they may be constituted His Body as His increase and expression. Finally, [link]ch. 21[/link] reveals that He will be with them in an invisible way until His coming back ([link]21:22[/link]).
The Word is the definition, explanation, and expression of God; hence, it is God defined, explained, and expressed.

The Word is not separate from God. It is not that the Word is the Word and God is God, and that they are thus separate from each other. Rather, the two are one; hence, the next clause says that the Word was God.
That the Word is God implies that God in His person is not simple; He is triune.
Not God the Son only, but the complete Triune God.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]He was [note]2[/note]in the beginning with God.
verse.note: Or, This One.

In the beginning, that is, from eternity past, the Word was with God. Contrary to what is supposed by some, it is not that Christ was not with God and was not God from eternity past, and that at a certain time Christ became God and was with God. Christ's deity is eternal and absolute. From eternity past to eternity future, He is with God and He is God. This is why this Gospel, unlike Matthew ([link]ch. 1[/link]) and Luke ([link]ch. 3[/link]), has no genealogy of Christ ([link]Heb. 7:3[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]All things came into being through Him, and apart from Him not one thing came into being which has come into being.
In Him was [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]life, and the life was the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]light of men.
verse.note: Since [link]v. 3[/link] refers to the creation in [link]Gen. 1[/link], [i]life[/i] here should refer to the life signified by the tree of life in [link]Gen. 2[/link]. This is confirmed by the fact that in [link]Rev. 22[/link] John mentions the tree of life. Since life is in Him, He is life ([link]11:25[/link]; [link]14:6[/link]), and He came that man might have life ([link]10:10b[/link]). The introduction to this Gospel is composed of this entire chapter; it begins with life ([link]v. 4[/link]) and ends with building ([link]vv. 42[/link], [link]51[/link]), that is, with the house of God (see notes [link]42[sup]1[/sup][/link], [link]51[sup]2[/sup][/link], and [link]51[sup]3[/sup][/link]). Hence, it is an introduction to life and building.
The light for the old creation was physical light ([link]Gen. 1:3-5[/link], [link]14-18[/link]). The light for the new creation is the light of life mentioned here.

verse.text: And the [xref]a[/xref]light shines in the darkness, and the darkness did not overcome it.
There came a man [note]1[/note]sent from God, whose name was John.
verse.note: The verb has the sense of being sent as an envoy with a special commission.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]He came for a testimony that he might testify concerning the light, that all might believe through him.
verse.note: Or, This one.

verse.text: He was not the light, but [i]came[/i] that he might testify concerning the light.
[i]This[/i] was the [xref]a[/xref]true light which, coming into the world, [xref]b[/xref]enlightens every man.
He was in the world, and the world came into being through Him, yet the world did not know Him.
He came to His own, yet those who were His own did not receive Him.
But as many as [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]received Him, to them He gave the authority to become [note]2[/note]children of God, to those who [note]1[/note]believe into His name,
verse.note: To believe into is to receive.
For human beings to become children of God is for man to have the divine life and the divine nature.

verse.text: Who were begotten not [note]1[/note]of [note]2[/note]blood, nor [note]1[/note]of the [note]2[/note]will of the flesh, nor [note]1[/note]of the [note]2[/note]will of man, but [note]1[/note]of God.
verse.note: Lit., out of.

[i]Blood[/i] (lit., bloods) here signifies the physical life; [i]will of the flesh[/i] denotes the will of fallen man after man became flesh; and [i]will of man[/i] refers to the will of the man created by God.

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note]Word became [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]flesh and [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]tabernacled among us (and [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]we beheld His glory, glory as of the only Begotten [note]5[/note]from the Father), full of [note]6[/note][xref]d[/xref]grace and [note]6[/note][xref]e[/xref]reality.
verse.note: For the Word as God to become flesh is for God to have the human life and the human nature.

[link]Romans 8:3[/link] indicates that although this flesh was the flesh of sin, it had only the likeness of the flesh of sin and did not have the sin of the flesh. It is the Word who became such flesh, and this Word was God, the complete Triune God ([link]v. 1[/link]). That the Word became flesh means that the Triune God became a man of flesh in the likeness of a sinful man. By so doing God entered into sinful man and became one with sinful man. However, He had only the likeness of a sinful man and not the sin of a sinful man. Hence, He was a sinless God-man, the complete God and the perfect man, having two natures, the divine nature and the human nature. Although His two natures were mingled to produce a God-man, the individual characteristics of the two natures remained distinct; the two natures did not intermix to form a third nature. Rather, the divine nature existed in the human nature and was expressed through the human nature, full of grace, which is God enjoyed by man, and reality, which is God obtained by man. In this way the invisible God was expressed so that men can obtain and enjoy Him as their life for the fulfillment of His New Testament economy.[br][br]God's becoming flesh was contrary to the teaching of the Gnostics of that time. The Gnostics maintained that since the flesh is an evil substance, God, who is pure, could never be united with the evil flesh. Using the teaching of the Gnostics as a basis, the Docetists denied that Christ had come in the flesh ([link]1 John 4:2[/link]). John wrote this Gospel in part to refute the heresy of the Docetists and to prove strongly that Christ, the God-man, is indeed God who became flesh (having only the likeness of the flesh of sin but not the sin of the flesh) that through this flesh, on the one hand, He might destroy the devil ([link]Heb. 2:14[/link]) and put away the sins of man ([link]Heb. 9:26[/link]), and, on the other hand, God might be united with man and be expressed through humanity for the fulfillment of His glorious purpose, a purpose He planned in eternity past for eternity future.[br][br]The deep thought of the Gospel of John is that Christ, the incarnate God, came as the embodiment of God, as illustrated by the tabernacle ([link]v. 14[/link]) and the temple ([link]2:21[/link]), so that man could contact Him and enter into Him to enjoy the riches contained in God. Both the tabernacle and the temple had an outer court, a Holy Place, and a Holy of Holies. Therefore, John points out first that Christ was the Lamb (who took away sin — [link]v. 29[/link]) offered on the altar, which signifies the cross, in the outer court of the tabernacle, and then that He was like the bronze serpent (which caused man to have life) lifted up on the pole ([link]3:14[/link]), which signifies the cross. This shows how Christ in His redemption was received by His believers that they might be delivered from sin and obtain life and might enter into Him as the embodiment of God, typified by the tabernacle, to enjoy all the riches that are in God. The foot-washing in [link]ch. 13[/link] may be considered the washing in the laver in the outer court of the tabernacle, which washed away the earthly defilement of those who drew near to God, so that their fellowship with God and with one another could be maintained. In [link]ch. 14[/link] those who receive Christ are brought by Him into the Holy Place to experience Him as the bread of life ([link]6:35[/link]), signified by the showbread, and as the light of life ([link]8:12[/link]; [link]9:5[/link]), signified by the lampstand. Eventually, in [link]ch. 17[/link], through the highest and most mysterious prayer, which is typified by the burning incense on the golden incense altar, those who enjoy Christ as life and as light are brought by Him into the Holy of Holies to enter with Him into the deepest enjoyment of God and to enjoy the glory that God has given Him ([link]17:22-24[/link]).
The Word, by being incarnated, not only brought God into humanity but also became a tabernacle to God as God's habitation on earth among men.
This refers to Christ's transfiguration on the Mount ([link]Matt. 17:1-2[/link], [link]5[/link]; [link]Luke 9:32[/link]; [link]2 Pet. 1:16-18[/link]).

Gk. [i]para,[/i] which means [i]by the side of,[/i] implying [i]with;[/i] hence, it is, literally, [i]from with.[/i] The Son not only is from God but also is with God. On the one hand, He is from God, and on the other hand, He is still with God ([link]8:16b[/link], [link]29[/link]; [link]16:32b[/link]).

Grace is God in the Son as our enjoyment; reality is God realized by us in the Son. The Greek word for [i]reality[/i] is the same as that for [i]truth[/i] in [link]5:33[/link]; [link]8:32[/link]; and [link]17:17[/link], [link]19[/link].

verse.text: John testified concerning Him and cried out, saying, This was He of whom I said, [xref]a[/xref]He who is coming after me has become ahead of me, because He was before me.
For [note]1[/note]of His [xref]a[/xref]fullness we have all received, and grace upon grace.
verse.note: Lit., out of.

verse.text: For the [note]1[/note]law was given through Moses; [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]grace and [note]1[/note]reality [note]2[/note]came through Jesus Christ.
verse.note: The law makes demands on man according to what God is; grace supplies man with what God is to meet what God demands. The law, at most, was only a testimony of what God is ([link]Exo. 25:21[/link]), but reality is the realization of what God is. No man can partake of God through the law, but grace enables man to enjoy God. Reality is God realized by man, and grace is God enjoyed by man.
Lit., became.

verse.text: No one has ever seen God; the [note]1[/note]only begotten Son, who is [note]2[/note]in the bosom of the Father, He has [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]declared [i]Him.[/i]
verse.note: The Father's only begotten Son declared God by the Word, life, light, grace, and reality. The Word is God expressed, life is God imparted, light is God shining, grace is God enjoyed, and reality is God realized, apprehended. God is fully declared in the Son through these five things.
Lit., into.
Or, explained.

verse.text: And this is the testimony of John, when the Jews sent to him priests and Levites from Jerusalem to ask him, Who are you?
And he confessed and did not deny, and he confessed, I am not the [xref]a[/xref]Christ.
And they asked him, What then? Are you [xref]a[/xref]Elijah? And he said, I am not. Are you the [xref]b[/xref]Prophet? And he answered, No.
They said then to him, Who are you, that we may give an answer to those who sent us? What do you say about yourself?
He said, I am a [xref]a[/xref]voice of one crying in the wilderness, "Make straight the way of the Lord!" as Isaiah the prophet said.
And those who had been sent were of the Pharisees.
And they asked him and said to him, Why then are you baptizing if you are not the Christ nor Elijah nor the Prophet?
John answered them, saying, I [xref]a[/xref]baptize in water; [i]but[/i] among you stands One whom you do not know,
He who is coming after me, the thong of whose sandal I am not worthy to untie.
These things took place in [note]1[/note]Bethany across the Jordan, where John was baptizing.
verse.note: Bethany here was a place on the east side of the Jordan and is different from the Bethany in [link]11:1[/link], which was a village on the west side of the Jordan.

verse.text: The next day he saw Jesus coming to him and said, Behold, the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Lamb of God, who takes away the [xref]b[/xref]sin of the [note]2[/note]world!
verse.note: Based on the Scriptures, the religious people were looking for a great leader ([link]vv. 19-25[/link]) such as Messiah, Elijah, or the Prophet ([link]Dan. 9:26[/link]; [link]Mal. 4:5[/link]; [link]Deut. 18:15[/link], [link]18[/link]). But Jesus was introduced to them as a little lamb with a little dove ([link]vv. 29-33[/link]). The Lamb takes sin away from man, and the dove brings God as life to man. The Lamb is for redemption, to redeem fallen man back to God, and the dove is for life-giving, for anointing, to anoint man with what God is, to bring God into man and man into God, and for uniting the believers in God. Both the Lamb and the dove are needed for man to participate in God.
The world here refers to mankind, as in [link]3:16[/link].

verse.text: This is He of whom I said, [xref]a[/xref]A man is coming after me who has become ahead of me, because He was before me.
And I did not know Him, but in order that He might be manifested to Israel, for this [i]reason[/i] I came baptizing in water.
And John testified, saying, I beheld the Spirit descending as a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]dove out of heaven, and He abode upon Him.
verse.note: See note [link]29[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And I did not know Him, but He who sent me to baptize in water, He said to me, He upon whom you see the Spirit descending and abiding upon Him, this is He who baptizes in the Holy Spirit.
And I have seen and have testified that this is the [xref]a[/xref]Son of God.
Again the next day John was standing with two of his disciples,
And looking at Jesus walking, he said, Behold, the [xref]a[/xref]Lamb of God!
And the two disciples heard him speak [i]this,[/i] and they followed Jesus.
And Jesus, turning and beholding them following, said to them, What are you seeking? And they said to Him, Rabbi (which translated means Teacher), where are You staying?
He said to them, Come, and you will see. They went therefore and saw where He was staying, and they stayed with Him that day; it was about the [note]1[/note]tenth hour.
verse.note: I.e., 10:00 a.m., Roman time. Roman time is used throughout the book.

verse.text: One of the two who heard [i]this[/i] from John and followed Him was Andrew, Simon Peter's brother.
He first found his own brother Simon and said to him, We have found the [note]1[/note]Messiah (which translated means [note]1[/note]Christ).
verse.note: [i]Messiah[/i] is a Hebrew word; [i]Christ[/i] is the Greek translation. Both mean [i]the anointed.[/i] Christ is God's Anointed, the One appointed by God to accomplish God's purpose, God's eternal plan.

verse.text: He led him to Jesus. Looking at him, Jesus said, You are Simon, the son of John; you shall be called Cephas (which is interpreted, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Peter).
verse.note: Meaning [i]a stone.[/i] In [link]Matt. 16:18[/link] the Lord mentioned this word when He spoke to Peter about the building of the church. It must have been from this that Peter obtained the concept of living stones for the building of a spiritual house ([link]1 Pet. 2:5[/link]), which is the church. The stone here denotes a work of transformation that brings forth material for God's building ([link]1 Cor. 3:12[/link]).

verse.text: The next day He wanted to go forth into Galilee, and He found Philip. And Jesus said to him, Follow Me.
Now Philip was from Bethsaida, of the city of Andrew and Peter.
Philip found Nathanael and said to him, We have found Him of whom Moses in the law, and the prophets, wrote, Jesus, the [note]1[/note]son of Joseph, from Nazareth.
verse.note: The information that Philip passed on to Nathanael in the words [i]son of Joseph[/i] and [i]from Nazareth[/i] was inaccurate. Jesus was born not of Joseph but of Mary ([link]Matt. 1:16[/link]), and not in Nazareth but in Bethlehem ([link]Luke 2:4-7[/link]).

verse.text: And Nathanael said to him, Can anything good be from Nazareth? Philip said to him, [xref]a[/xref]Come and see.
Jesus saw Nathanael coming to Him and said concerning him, Behold, truly an Israelite, in whom there is no guile!
Nathanael said to Him, How do You know me? Jesus answered and said to him, Before Philip called you, while you were under the fig tree, I saw you.
Nathanael answered Him, Rabbi, You are the Son of God; You are the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]King of Israel.
verse.note: The Messiah.

verse.text: Jesus answered and said to him, Is it because I told you that I saw you under the fig tree [i]that[/i] you believe? You shall see [xref]a[/xref]greater things than these.
And He said to him, [note]1[/note]Truly, truly, I say to you, You shall see [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]heaven opened and the angels of God ascending and descending on the [note]3[/note]Son of Man.
verse.note: In Greek, Amen, amen. So throughout the book.

This is the fulfillment of Jacob's dream ([link]Gen. 28:11-22[/link]). Christ as the Son of Man, with His humanity, is the ladder set up on the earth and leading to heaven, keeping heaven open to earth and joining earth to heaven for the house of God, Bethel. Jacob poured oil (a symbol of the Holy Spirit, the ultimate expression of the Triune God reaching man) upon the stone (a symbol of the transformed man) that it might be the house of God. Here in this chapter are the Spirit ([link]v. 32[/link]) and the stone ([link]v. 42[/link]) for the house of God with Christ in His humanity. Where this is, there is an open heaven.

This chapter, as the introduction to this Gospel, introduces Christ as both the Son of God ([link]vv. 34[/link], [link]49[/link]) and the Son of Man. Nathanael recognized Him as the Son of God and addressed Him as such ([link]v. 49[/link]), but Christ said to Nathanael that He was the Son of Man. The Son of God is God; as such, He has the divine nature. The Son of Man is man; as such, He possesses the human nature. For the declaring of God ([link]v. 18[/link]) and for the bringing of God to man, He is the only begotten Son of God. But for the building of God's habitation on earth among men, He is the Son of Man. God's building needs His humanity. In eternity past Christ was only God, only the Son of God, and had only divinity; but in eternity future Christ, as God and man and as the Son of God and the Son of Man, will have both divinity and humanity forever.

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]third day a [note]2[/note]wedding took place in [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]Cana of [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]Galilee, and the mother of Jesus was there.
verse.note: The day of resurrection ([link]1 Cor. 15:4[/link]).
Marriage signifies the continuation of human life, and a wedding (feast) signifies the pleasure and enjoyment of human life.
[i]Cana[/i] means [i]reed,[/i] and reeds signify weak and fragile people ([link]Isa. 42:3a[/link]; [link]Matt. 12:20a[/link]; [link]11:7[/link]).
Galilee was a despised place ([link]John 7:52[/link]).

verse.text: And Jesus also was invited, as well as His disciples, to the wedding.
And when the [note]1[/note]wine [note]2[/note]ran out, the [note]3[/note]mother of Jesus said to Him, They have no wine.
verse.note: Wine, the life juice of the grape, signifies life. Hence, the wine's running out symbolizes that the human life runs out.
Lit., fell short.
Here the mother of Jesus symbolizes the natural man, which has nothing to do with life ([link]v. 4[/link]) and must be subdued by life ([link]v. 5[/link]).

verse.text: And Jesus said to her, [note]1[/note]Woman, [note]2[/note]what do I have in this that concerns you? [xref]a[/xref]My hour has not yet come.
verse.note: A term of respect and endearment.
Lit., what is there to Me and to you? (a Hebrew idiom).

verse.text: His mother said to the servants, Whatever He says to you, do.
Now there were [note]1[/note]six stone waterpots lying there, according to the [note]2[/note]Jews' rite of purification, holding [note]3[/note]two or three measures each.
verse.note: The six waterpots signify the created man, for man was created on the sixth day ([link]Gen. 1:27[/link], [link]31[/link]).
The Jews' rite of purification with water signifies religion's attempt to make people clean by certain dead practices. But the Lord changes death into life.
Two or three measures equal twenty or thirty gallons.

verse.text: Jesus said to them, Fill the waterpots with [note]1[/note]water. And they filled them up to the brim.
verse.note: Water here signifies death, as in [link]Gen. 1:2[/link], [link]6[/link], [link]Exo. 14:21[/link], and [link]Matt. 3:16[/link].

verse.text: And He said to them, Draw some out now and take it to the master of the feast. And they took [i]it to him.[/i]

And when the master of the feast tasted the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]water which had become wine and did not know where it came from, though the servants who had drawn the water knew, the master of the feast called the bridegroom
verse.note: The changing of water into wine signifies the changing of death into life.

verse.text: And said to him, Every man sets out the good wine first, and when they have drunk freely, [i]then[/i] that which is worse; you have kept the good wine until now.
This [note]1[/note]beginning of [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]signs Jesus performed in Cana of Galilee and [note]3[/note]manifested His glory, and His disciples believed into Him.
verse.note: The first mentioning of any matter in the Scriptures sets forth the principle of that matter. Therefore, this first sign sets forth the principle of all the following signs, that is, to change death into life.[br][br]In the Scriptures, figuratively, the tree of life is the source of life and the tree of knowledge is the source of death, as revealed in [link]Gen. 2:9[/link], [link]17[/link]. The meaning of all the cases recorded in this Gospel corresponds with the principle that the tree of life results in life and the tree of knowledge results in death.

In this book all the miracles done by the Lord are called signs ([link]v. 23[/link]; [link]3:2[/link]; [link]4:54[/link]; [link]6:2[/link], [link]14[/link], [link]26[/link], [link]30[/link]; [link]7:31[/link]; [link]9:16[/link]; [link]10:41[/link]; [link]11:47[/link]; [link]12:18[/link], [link]37[/link]; [link]20:30[/link]). They are miracles, but they are used as signs to signify the matter of life.
The Lord's divinity was manifested here.

verse.text: After this He went down to Capernaum, He and His mother and His brothers and His disciples; and they remained there not many days.
And the [xref]a[/xref]Passover of the Jews was near, and Jesus went up to Jerusalem.
And [xref]a[/xref]He found in the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]temple those selling oxen and sheep and doves, and the moneychangers sitting [i]there.[/i]
verse.note: The Greek word refers to the entire precincts of the temple. So in the next verse.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]having made a whip out of [note]2[/note]cords, He drove them all out of the temple, as well as the sheep and the oxen, and He poured out the money of the moneychangers and overturned their tables.
verse.note: This case of the cleansing of the temple reveals the purpose of life, i.e., that life is for the building of the house of God.
Lit., cords [i]made of[/i] rushes.

verse.text: And to those who were selling the doves He said, Take these things away from here; do not make [xref]a[/xref]My Father's house a house of merchandise.
His disciples remembered that it was written, [xref]a[/xref]"The zeal of Your house shall devour Me."
The Jews then answered and said to Him, What sign do You show us, seeing that You do these things?
Jesus answered and said to them, Destroy this [note]1[/note]temple, and in [note]2[/note]three days I will [xref]a[/xref]raise it up.
verse.note: The Greek word refers to the inner temple. So in [link]vv. 20[/link], [link]21[/link].
[i]In three days[/i] signifies in resurrection.

verse.text: Then the Jews said, This temple was built in forty-six years, and You will raise it up in three days?
But He spoke of the [xref]a[/xref]temple of His body.
When therefore He was raised from the dead, His disciples remembered that He had said this, and they believed the [xref]a[/xref]Scripture and the word which Jesus had spoken.
Now when He was in Jerusalem at the Passover, during the feast, many believed into His name when they saw the signs which He did.
But Jesus Himself did not entrust Himself to them, for He knew all men,
And because He did not need anyone to testify concerning man, for [xref]a[/xref]He Himself knew what was in man.
[note]1[/note]But there was a man of the Pharisees named [xref]a[/xref]Nicodemus, a ruler of the Jews.
verse.note: [i]But[/i] indicates that this case, concerning Nicodemus, differs from the case in the foregoing verses, [link]2:23-25[/link]. There the people believed into the Lord because they saw the miracles He performed. The Lord could not commit Himself to such people. But the case in this chapter concerns life in regeneration; it reveals that this book is not for miraculous things but is only for life. This is why in this book even the miracles done by the Lord are called signs, signifying that the Lord came for life so that God might be multiplied ([link]12:24[/link]), not for miracles so that man might be benefited.

verse.text: This one came to Him by night and said to Him, Rabbi, we know that You have come from God as a [note]1[/note]teacher, for no one can do these [xref]a[/xref]signs that You do unless [xref]b[/xref]God is with him.
verse.note: Nicodemus considered Christ a teacher who had come from God. This indicates that he might have thought that he needed better teachings so that he could improve himself. But the Lord's answer in the next verse unveiled to him that his need was to be born anew. To be born anew is to be regenerated with the divine life, a life different from the human life received by natural birth. Hence, his real need was not better teachings by which he could improve himself, but the divine life by which he could be remade. He was seeking for teachings, which belong to the tree of knowledge, but the Lord's answer turned him to his need for life, which belongs to the tree of life (cf. [link]Gen. 2:9[/link], [link]17[/link]).

verse.text: Jesus answered and said to him, Truly, truly, I say to you, Unless one is [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]born anew, he cannot [note]2[/note]see the [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]kingdom of God.
verse.note: Or, born from above. So in [link]v. 7[/link]. To be born anew is to be born from above, from heaven, that is, to be born from God, who is in heaven.
In spiritual things, to see is to enter into ([link]v. 5[/link]).

The kingdom of God is the reign of God. It is a divine realm to be entered into, a realm that requires the divine life. Only the divine life can realize the divine things. Hence, for one to see, or to enter into, the kingdom of God requires that he be regenerated with the divine life.

verse.text: Nicodemus said to Him, How can a man be born when he is old? He cannot enter a second time into his mother's womb and be born, can he?
Jesus answered, Truly, truly, I say to you, Unless one is [xref]a[/xref]born [note]1[/note]of [note]2[/note]water and the Spirit, he cannot enter into the kingdom of God.
verse.note: Lit., out of.

The words [i]of water and the Spirit[/i] should have been plain to Nicodemus, without any need of explanation. In [link]Matt. 3:11[/link] John the Baptist spoke the same words to the Pharisees; hence, they should have been fully understood among the Pharisees. Now Nicodemus, one of the Pharisees, was conversing with the Lord, and the Lord spoke these familiar words. "Water" was the central concept of the ministry of John the Baptist, that is, to terminate people of the old creation. "Spirit" is the central concept of the ministry of Jesus, that is, to germinate people in the new creation. These two main concepts together constitute the concept of regeneration. Regeneration is the termination of people of the old creation with all their deeds, and the germination of people in the new creation with the divine life.

verse.text: That which is [xref]a[/xref]born [note]1[/note]of the flesh is flesh, and that which is born [note]1[/note]of the [note]2[/note]Spirit is [note]2[/note]spirit.
verse.note: Lit., out of.

The first Spirit mentioned here is the divine Spirit, the Holy Spirit of God, and the second spirit is the human spirit, the regenerated spirit of man. Regeneration is accomplished in the human spirit by the Holy Spirit of God with God's life, the uncreated eternal life. Thus, to be regenerated is to have the divine, eternal life (in addition to the human, natural life) as the new source and new element of a new person.

verse.text: Do not marvel that I said to you, [note]1[/note]You must be born anew.
verse.note: Plural in Greek.

verse.text: The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]wind blows where it wills, and you hear the sound of it, but you do not know where it comes from and where it goes; so is everyone who is born [note]2[/note]of the Spirit.
verse.note: The Greek word for [i]wind[/i] is the same as that for [i]spirit.[/i] Whether it is rendered [i]wind[/i] or [i]spirit[/i] depends on the context. This verse refers to something that blows, the sound of which can be heard, indicating that the word should be rendered [i]wind.[/i] A regenerated person is like the wind, which can be recognized but which is beyond understanding; even so, it is a fact, a reality.
Lit., out of.

verse.text: Nicodemus answered and said to Him, How can these things be?
Jesus answered and said to him, You are a teacher of Israel, and you do not know these things?
Truly, truly, I say to you, We speak that which we know and [xref]a[/xref]testify of that which we have seen, and yet you do not receive our testimony.
If I told you of the [note]1[/note]things on earth and you do not believe, how will you believe if I tell you of the [note]1[/note]things in heaven?
verse.note: [i]Things on earth[/i] here does not mean things of an earthly nature but things that take place on earth, including redemption and regeneration. In the same principle [i]things in heaven[/i] in this verse does not mean things of a heavenly nature but things that take place in heaven. In the next verse the Lord said that He was the One who descended out of heaven and who was still in heaven. This indicates that He knew the things that took place in heaven, because He was the One who was in heaven all the time.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]no one has ascended into heaven, but He who descended out of heaven, the [xref]b[/xref]Son of Man, [note]1[/note]who is in heaven.
verse.note: Some ancient MSS omit, who is in heaven.

verse.text: And as [xref]a[/xref]Moses [xref]b[/xref]lifted up the [note]1[/note]serpent in the wilderness, so must the Son of Man be lifted up,
verse.note: This chapter deals with regeneration. Regeneration, on one hand, brings the divine life with the divine nature into us. On the other hand, regeneration terminates the evil nature of Satan in our flesh. In [link]Gen. 3[/link] Satan, the serpent, injected his nature into man's flesh. When the children of Israel sinned against God, they were bitten by serpents ([link]Num. 21:4-9[/link]). God told Moses to lift up a bronze serpent on their behalf for God's judgment, that by looking upon that bronze serpent all might live. That was a type. Here, in this verse, the Lord Jesus applied that type to Himself, indicating that when He was in the flesh, He was in "the likeness of the flesh of sin" ([link]Rom. 8:3[/link]), which likeness is equal to the form of the bronze serpent. The bronze serpent had the form of the serpent but was without the serpent's poison. Christ was made in "the likeness of the flesh of sin," but He did not participate in any way in the sin of the flesh ([link]2 Cor. 5:21[/link]; [link]Heb. 4:15[/link]). When He was lifted up in the flesh on the cross, by His death Satan, the old serpent, was dealt with ([link]12:31-33[/link]; [link]Heb. 2:14[/link]). This means that the serpentine nature within fallen man has been dealt with. When a man is regenerated with the divine life in Christ, his satanic nature is annulled. Because of this, in this portion of the Word, when the Lord revealed the matter of regeneration to Nicodemus, He specifically mentioned this point.[br][br]Nicodemus might have considered himself a moral and good man. But the Lord's word in this verse implied that regardless of how good Nicodemus might have been outwardly, he had the serpentine nature of Satan inwardly. As a descendant of Adam, he had been poisoned by the old serpent, and the serpent's nature was within him. He needed the Lord not only to be the Lamb of God to take away his sin ([link]1:29[/link]) but also to be in the form of the serpent that his serpentine nature might be dealt with on the cross and that he might have eternal life. In the principle set forth in [link]ch. 2[/link], this is the changing of death into life.

verse.text: That everyone who believes into Him may have [note]1[/note]eternal life.
verse.note: This is the divine life, the uncreated life of God, which not only is everlasting with respect to time but also is eternal and divine in nature. So in [link]vv. 16[/link], [link]36[/link].

verse.text: For God so [xref]a[/xref]loved the [note]1[/note]world that He [xref]b[/xref]gave His [xref]c[/xref]only begotten Son, that everyone who [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]believes into Him would not perish, but would have eternal life.
verse.note: The world here refers to sinful, fallen people, who constitute the world. They have not only sin but also the poisonous element of the devil, the ancient serpent; hence, they have become serpents. They need Christ to die for them in the form of a serpent and be judged by God as their Substitute ([link]v. 14[/link]); otherwise, they will perish ([link]v. 16[/link]). Although men are utterly fallen, God still loves them with His divine love, which is Himself ([link]1 John 4:8[/link], [link]16[/link]), because they are vessels created by God according to His own image to contain Himself ([link]Gen. 1:26[/link]; [link]Rom. 9:21a[/link], [link]23[/link]). Moreover, He so loves them that He gave them His only begotten Son, His expression, that they might obtain His eternal life to become His many sons and be His corporate expression for the fulfillment of His eternal New Testament economy. Hence, God first regenerates them by His Spirit ([link]vv. 3-6[/link]) that they may have His eternal life ([link]vv. 15-16[/link], [link]36a[/link]). Then He fills them with His unlimited Spirit ([link]v. 34[/link]) that they may become the bride of Christ, who is above all and is all-inclusive ([link]vv. 31-35[/link]), to be His increase and fullness ([link]vv. 28-30[/link]).

Believing into the Lord is not the same as believing Him ([link]6:30[/link]). To believe Him is to believe that He is true and real, but to believe into Him is to receive Him and be united with Him as one. The former is to acknowledge a fact objectively; the latter is to receive a life subjectively.

verse.text: For God did not send the Son into the world to [note]1[/note]condemn the world, but that the world might be saved through Him.
verse.note: Or, judge.

verse.text: He who believes into Him is not [note]1[/note]condemned; but he who does not believe has been [note]1[/note]condemned already, because he has not believed into the name of [xref]a[/xref]the only begotten Son of God.
verse.note: Or, judged.

verse.text: And this is the [note]1[/note]condemnation, that the [xref]a[/xref]light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the light, for their works were evil.
verse.note: Or, judgment.

verse.text: For everyone who [note]1[/note]practices evil hates the light, and does not come to the light, lest his works be [note]2[/note]reproved.
verse.note: I.e., does evil habitually. The same word is used in [link]5:29[/link].
Or, exposed, uncovered.

verse.text: But he who does the [note]1[/note]truth comes to the light, that his works may be manifested that they are wrought in God.
verse.note: According to the context, [i]truth[/i] here denotes uprightness (as opposed to evil — [link]vv. 19-20[/link]), which is the reality manifested in a man who lives in God according to what He is, and which corresponds with the divine light, which is God, as the source of the truth, manifested in Christ. See note [link]6[sup]6[/sup] in 1 John 1[/link].

verse.text: After these things, Jesus and His disciples came into the land of Judea, and there He spent some time with them and [xref]a[/xref]baptized.
And John also was baptizing in Aenon near Salim, because there was much water there; and people came and were baptized;
For [xref]a[/xref]John had not yet been thrown into prison.
There arose therefore a questioning on the part of John's disciples with a Jew about [xref]a[/xref]purification.

And they came to John and said to him, Rabbi, He who was with you [xref]a[/xref]across the Jordan, of whom you have [xref]b[/xref]testified, behold, He is [xref]c[/xref]baptizing and all are coming to Him.
John answered and said, A man cannot receive anything unless it has been given to him from heaven.
You yourselves testify of me that I said, [xref]a[/xref]I am not the Christ, but I have been sent before Him.

[xref]a[/xref]He who has the bride is the bridegroom; but the friend of the bridegroom, who stands and hears him, rejoices with joy because of the bridegroom's voice. This joy of mine therefore is made full.
He must [note]1[/note]increase, but I [i]must[/i] decrease.
verse.note: The increase in this verse is the bride in [link]v. 29[/link], and the bride there is a living composition of all the regenerated people. This means, in this chapter on regeneration, that regeneration not only brings the divine life into the believers and annuls the satanic nature in their flesh, but it also makes them the corporate bride for Christ's increase. The last two points, the annulling of the serpentine nature in the believers and the believers' being made the bride of Christ, are fully developed in John's Revelation. The book of Revelation reveals mainly how Satan as the old serpent will be fully eliminated ([link]Rev. 20:2[/link], [link]10[/link]) and how Christ's bride, the New Jerusalem, will be fully produced ([link]Rev. 21:2[/link], [link]10-27[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]He who comes from above is above all; he who is [note]2[/note]from the earth is [note]2[/note]of the earth and speaks [note]2[/note]out of the earth. [xref]b[/xref]He who comes [note]2[/note]from heaven is above all.
verse.note: [link]Verses 31-36[/link] unveil to us the immeasurableness, the unlimitedness, of Christ. He is such an immeasurable and unlimited One, who comes from above, who is above all, to whom the Father has given all, and who dispenses the Spirit without measure. Such a One needs a universal increase to be His bride to match Him, as revealed in [link]vv. 22-30[/link]. He who believes into this immeasurable One has eternal life; he who disobeys this One is under the wrath of God.

[i]From, of,[/i] and [i]out of[/i] are the same word in Greek. Since persons, matters, and things on the earth are from the earth, they are of the earth. [i]He who comes from heaven[/i] refers to one who is out of heaven; therefore, such a one is of heaven.

verse.text: What He has seen and heard, of this He testifies, and [xref]a[/xref]no one receives His testimony.
He who receives His testimony has sealed that God is true.
For He whom God has sent speaks the [note]1[/note]words of God, for He gives the Spirit not by measure.
verse.note: See note [link]63[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 6[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]The Father loves the Son and has given all into His hand.
He who [xref]a[/xref]believes into the Son has eternal life; but he who disobeys the Son shall not see life, but the wrath of God abides upon him.
When therefore the Lord knew that the Pharisees had heard that Jesus was making and [xref]a[/xref]baptizing more disciples than John
(Although Jesus Himself did not baptize, but [i]rather[/i] His disciples),
He left [xref]a[/xref]Judea and went away [xref]b[/xref]again into Galilee.
And He had to pass through Samaria.
So He came to a city of Samaria called Sychar, [xref]a[/xref]near the piece of land that Jacob gave to Joseph his son;
And Jacob's [note]1[/note]well was there. Jesus therefore, being wearied from the journey, sat thus by the [note]1[/note]well; it was about the [note]2[/note]sixth hour.
verse.note: Lit., fountain; as in [link]v. 14[/link].

verse.text: There came a woman of Samaria to draw water. Jesus said to her, Give Me [i]something[/i] to drink.
For His disciples had gone away into the city to buy food.

The Samaritan woman then said to Him, How [i]is it that[/i] You, being a Jew, ask for a drink from me, who am a Samaritan woman? ([xref]a[/xref]For Jews have no dealings with [note]1[/note]Samaritans.)
verse.note: Samaria was the leading region of the northern kingdom of Israel and was the site of its capital ([link]1 Kings 16:24[/link], [link]29[/link]). Around 700 B.C., the Assyrians captured Samaria and brought people from Babylon and other heathen countries to the cities of Samaria ([link]2 Kings 17:6[/link], [link]24[/link]). From that time the Samaritans became a people of mixed heathen and Jewish blood. History tells us that they had the Pentateuch (the five books of Moses) and worshipped God according to that part of the Old Testament. But they were never recognized by the Jews as being part of the Jewish people.

verse.text: Jesus answered and said to her, If you knew the [xref]a[/xref]gift of God and who it is who says to you, Give Me a drink, you would have asked Him, and He would have given you [xref]b[/xref]living water.
The woman said to Him, Sir, You have no bucket, and the well is deep; where then do You get this living water?
Are You greater than our father Jacob, who gave us the well and drank of it himself, as well as his sons and his cattle?
Jesus answered and said to her, Everyone who [note]1[/note]drinks of this water shall thirst again,
verse.note: This signifies the enjoyment of material things and the amusement obtained from worldly entertainment. These cannot quench the thirst deep within man. However much he drinks of this material and worldly "water," he will thirst again. The more he drinks of this "water," the more his thirst increases.

verse.text: But whoever [xref]a[/xref]drinks of the water that I will give him shall [xref]b[/xref]by no means thirst forever; but the water that I will give him will become in him a fountain of water springing up into [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]eternal life.
verse.note: See note [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].

verse.text: The woman said to Him, Sir, [xref]a[/xref]give me this water so that I will not thirst nor come here to draw.
He said to her, Go, [note]1[/note]call your husband and come here.
verse.note: This word was intended to touch her conscience by referring to her history of immorality, so that she would repent of her sins.

verse.text: The woman answered and said, I do not have a husband. Jesus said to her, You have well said, I do not have a husband,
For you have had [note]1[/note]five husbands, and the one you now have is not your husband; this you have said truly.
verse.note: The woman tried the first husband, drinking of that "water," and she was not satisfied. Then she tried the second, third, fourth, and fifth husbands. Since none of these satisfied her, she was trying another. Her changing of husbands fully proved that however much she drank of that "water," she was still thirsty. "Everyone who drinks of this water shall thirst again." This word of the Lord's is true!

verse.text: The woman said to Him, Sir, I perceive that You are a prophet.
[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Our fathers worshipped [xref]b[/xref]in this mountain, yet you say that [xref]c[/xref]in Jerusalem is the place where [i]men[/i] must worship.
verse.note: The woman's problem, like the questions in [link]8:3-5[/link] and [link]9:2-3[/link], was a matter of yes or no, which belongs to the tree of knowledge; but the Lord turned her to the spirit ([link]vv. 21-24[/link]), which belongs to the tree of life (cf. [link]Gen. 2:9[/link], [link]17[/link]).

verse.text: Jesus said to her, Woman, believe Me, [xref]a[/xref]an hour is coming when neither in this mountain nor in Jerusalem will you worship the Father.
[xref]a[/xref]You worship that which you do not know; we worship that which we know, for salvation is of the Jews.
But [xref]a[/xref]an hour is coming, and it is now, when the true worshippers will worship the Father [xref]b[/xref]in spirit and truthfulness, for the Father also seeks such to worship Him.
[note]1[/note]God is [note]2[/note]Spirit, and those who [note]3[/note]worship Him must worship [xref]a[/xref]in [note]4[/note]spirit and [note]5[/note]truthfulness.
verse.note: God here is the complete Triune God — the Father, the Son, and the Spirit.

[i]Spirit[/i] here refers to the nature of the complete Triune God; it does not refer merely to the Lord Spirit. To worship God, who is Spirit, we must worship with our spirit, which is of the same nature as He is.

This word was given to instruct the Samaritan woman regarding her need to exercise her spirit to contact God the Spirit. To contact God the Spirit with the spirit is to drink of the living water, and to drink of the living water is to render real worship to God.

This is our human spirit. According to typology, God should be worshipped (1) in the place chosen by God for His habitation ([link]Deut. 12:5[/link], [link]11[/link], [link]13-14[/link], [link]18[/link]), and (2) with the offerings ([link]Lev. 1-6[/link]). The place chosen by God for His habitation typifies the human spirit, where God's habitation is today ([link]Eph. 2:22[/link]). The offerings typify Christ; Christ is the fulfillment and reality of all the offerings with which the people worshipped God. Hence, when the Lord instructed the woman to worship God the Spirit in spirit and truthfulness, He meant that she should contact God the Spirit in her spirit instead of in a specific location, and through Christ instead of with the offerings. Since Christ, as the reality that issues in the human virtue of truthfulness, has come ([link]vv. 25-26[/link]), all the shadows and types are over.

According to the context of this chapter and the entire revelation of John's Gospel, [i]truthfulness[/i] here denotes the divine reality becoming man's genuineness and sincerity (which are the opposite of the hypocrisy of the immoral Samaritan worshipper — [link]vv. 16-18[/link]) for the true worship of God. The divine reality is Christ (who is the reality — [link]14:6[/link]) as the reality of all the offerings of the Old Testament for the worship of God ([link]1:29[/link]; [link]3:14[/link]) and as the fountain of the living water, the life-giving Spirit ([link]vv. 7-15[/link]), partaken of and drunk by His believers to be the reality within them, which eventually becomes their genuineness and sincerity in which they worship God with the worship that He seeks. See note [link]6[sup]6[/sup] in 1 John 1[/link]; [link]Rom. 3:7[/link]; and note [link]8[sup]2[/sup] in Rom. 15[/link].

verse.text: The woman said to Him, I know that [xref]a[/xref]Messiah is coming (He who is called Christ); when He comes, He will declare all things to us.
Jesus said to her, [note]1[/note]I, who speak to you, am [i]He.[/i]
verse.note: By this word Jesus led her to believe that He was the Christ, that she might have eternal life ([link]20:31[/link]). She believed ([link]v. 29[/link]).

verse.text: And at this [i]point[/i] His disciples came, and they marveled that He was speaking with a woman; yet no one said, What are You seeking? or, Why are You speaking with her?
Then the woman [note]1[/note]left her waterpot and went away into the city, and said to the people,
verse.note: Whoever drinks the living water and is satisfied with it will drop his preoccupations and testify of it. In the principle set forth in [link]ch. 2[/link], this also is the changing of death into life.

verse.text: Come, see a man who told me all that I have done. [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Is this not the Christ?
verse.note: This indicates that the woman believed that Jesus was the Christ. By thus believing, she received the living water and was satisfied.

verse.text: They went out of the city and came to Him.
In the meantime, the disciples urged Him, saying, Rabbi, eat.
But He said to them, [note]1[/note]I have food to eat that you do not know about.
verse.note: The sinner was satisfied by receiving the Savior's living water, and the Savior was satisfied by doing God's will in satisfying the sinner. Doing the will of God to satisfy the sinner is the Savior's food ([link]v. 34[/link]).

verse.text: The disciples therefore said to one another, Has anyone brought Him [i]anything[/i] to eat?
Jesus said to them, My food is [xref]a[/xref]to do the will of Him who sent Me and [xref]b[/xref]to finish His work.
Do you not say that there are yet four months and then the [xref]a[/xref]harvest comes? Behold, I tell you, Lift up your eyes and look on the fields, for they are already white for harvest.
He who reaps receives wages and gathers fruit [note]1[/note]unto [note]2[/note]eternal life, in order that he who sows and he who reaps may rejoice together.
verse.note: Or, for.
See note [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].

verse.text: For in this the saying is true, One sows and another reaps.
I sent you to reap that for which you have not labored; [note]1[/note]others have labored, and you have entered into their labor.
verse.note: [i]Others have labored[/i] should mean that some had sown the seed among the Samaritans using the Pentateuch (the first five books of the Old Testament), which the Samaritans did possess. Here the Lord sent His disciples to reap what the earlier laborers had sown.

verse.text: And many of the Samaritans from that city believed into Him because of the word of the woman who testified, He told me all that I have done.
So when the Samaritans came to Him, they asked Him to remain with them, and He remained there two days.
And many more believed because of His word.
And they said to the woman, It is no longer because of your speaking [i]that[/i] we believe, for we ourselves have heard and know that this One is truly the [xref]a[/xref]Savior of the world.
And after the two days He went forth from there into Galilee,
For Jesus Himself testified that [xref]a[/xref]a prophet has [note]1[/note]no honor in his own country.
verse.note: The Lord went to Galilee to avoid gaining fame, which He had gained in Jerusalem ([link]2:23[/link]).

verse.text: Then when He came into Galilee, the Galileans received Him, having seen all that He did in Jerusalem at the feast, for they also went to the feast.

He then came again to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Cana of [note]2[/note]Galilee, where He had [xref]b[/xref]made the water wine.[separator]And there was a certain royal official, whose son was sick in Capernaum.
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].
Galilee, a despised place ([link]7:41[/link], [link]52[/link]), signifies the world, which is in a low and mean condition.

verse.text: When he heard that Jesus had come out of Judea into Galilee, he went to Him and asked [i]Him[/i] to come down and heal his son, for he was about to die.
Jesus therefore said to him, Unless you see [xref]a[/xref]signs and wonders, you will by no means believe.
The royal official said to Him, Sir, come down before my little child dies.
Jesus said to him, Go, your son lives. The man believed the [note]1[/note]word which Jesus said to him and went his way.
verse.note: The word of life out of the mouth of the Lord gives life to the dying.

verse.text: And as he was now going down, his slaves met him and said that his child was living.
So he asked them the hour in which he got better. They said then to him, Yesterday at the [note]1[/note]seventh hour the fever left him.
Then the father knew that [i]it was[/i] in that hour in which Jesus said to him, Your son lives; and he believed, he and his whole house.
Again, this [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]second sign Jesus performed when He came out of Judea into Galilee.
verse.note: The first sign in Cana ([link]2:1-11[/link]) signifies the changing of death into life, setting forth the principle of life. The second sign here is a continuation, an application of the principle of the changing of death into life. The source of death is the tree of knowledge, and the source of life is the tree of life (cf. [link]Gen. 2:9[/link], [link]17[/link]).

verse.text: After these things there was a feast of the Jews, and Jesus went up to Jerusalem.
Now there is in Jerusalem near the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Sheep Gate a pool, which is called in Hebrew [note]2[/note]Bethesda, having [note]3[/note]five porticoes.
verse.note: The Sheep Gate signifies the door to the sheepfold of the religion of law keeping ([link]10:1[/link]).

[i]Bethesda[/i] means [i]house of mercy,[/i] signifying that the people who practiced law keeping needed the mercy of God because they were impotent, weak, and wretched, as portrayed in [link]Rom. 7:7-24[/link].
Porticoes signify the shelter of the religion of law keeping, a shelter like that provided by a sheepfold. The number five signifies responsibility.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]In these lay a multitude of those who were sick, blind, lame, [i]and[/i] withered, [note]2[/note]waiting for the moving of the water.
verse.note: This signifies that under the shelter of law keeping, in the sheepfold of religion, there are many who are blind, unable to see; many who are lame, unable to walk; and many who are withered, lacking the life supply.
Some MSS omit this last part of [link]v. 3[/link] and all of [link]v. 4[/link].

verse.text: For an [note]1[/note]angel went down from time to time in the pool and [note]2[/note]stirred up the water; the first then to step in after the stirring up of the water was made [note]3[/note]well of whatever disease he was being held by.
verse.note: The angel here signifies the agent through which the law, which could not give life, was given ([link]Gal. 3:19[/link], [link]21[/link]).
The stirring up of the water to make people well signifies the attempt to make people perfect by the practice of law keeping.
Or, whole, sound. So in [link]v. 6[/link].

verse.text: And a certain [note]1[/note]man was there, who had been thirty-eight years in his sickness.
verse.note: With this sick and impotent man there was no happiness, even on the joyful day of a feast ([link]v. 1[/link]), and there was no rest, even on the Sabbath day ([link]v. 10[/link]).

verse.text: When Jesus saw this one lying [i]there[/i] and knew that he had already been a long time [i]in that condition,[/i] [note]1[/note]He said to him, Do you want to get well?
verse.note: This sign signifies that when the practice of law keeping in the Jewish religion became an impossibility because of the impotence of man ([link]Rom. 8:3[/link]), the Son of God came to enliven the dead ([link]v. 25[/link]). The law could not give life ([link]Gal. 3:21[/link]), but the Son of God gives life to the dead ([link]v. 21[/link]). "While we were yet weak" ([link]Rom. 5:6[/link]), He came to enliven us.

verse.text: The sick man answered Him, [note]1[/note]Sir, [note]2[/note]I have no one to put me into the pool when the water is stirred up; but while I am coming, another steps down before me.
verse.note: Or, Lord.

There was a means for healing in the religion of law keeping, but it did not profit the impotent man, because he had no strength to fulfill the law's requirements. The law keeping in religion depends on man's effort, man's doing, man's self-cultivation. Since man is impotent, the law keeping in religion becomes ineffective. The holy city, the holy temple, the feast, the Sabbath, the angels, Moses, and the Scriptures are all good things of this religion, but they could do nothing for this impotent man. In the eyes of the Lord he was a dead person ([link]v. 25[/link]), in need not only of healing but also of enlivening. With the Lord's enlivening there is no requirement. The impotent man heard His voice and was enlivened ([link]v. 25[/link]).

verse.text: Jesus said to him, [xref]a[/xref]Rise, take up your [note]1[/note]mat and walk.
verse.note: A small mattress or pad; so in [link]vv. 9[/link], [link]10[/link], [link]11[/link], and 12.

verse.text: And immediately the man [note]1[/note]became well, and he [note]2[/note]took up his mat and walked. Now it was the [xref]a[/xref]Sabbath on that day;
verse.note: According to [link]vv. 24-25[/link], this is to pass out of death into life and to live. In the principle set forth in [link]ch. 2[/link], this is the changing of death into life.
Formerly, the mat carried the impotent man, but now the enlivened man carried the mat.

verse.text: Therefore the Jews said to the one who had been healed, It is the [xref]a[/xref]Sabbath, and [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]it is not lawful for you to take up your mat.
verse.note: Life's enlivening broke religion's ritual. Religion was offended by life and began its opposition to life from this point ([link]vv. 16[/link], [link]18[/link]).[br][br]The Sabbath is for man ([link]Mark 2:27[/link]) and should be a rest to man. Religion's law keeping did not bring rest to this man who had been sick for thirty-eight years, but life's enlivening did. Yet the religious cared only for their ritual of Sabbath keeping; they had no concern for the sick man's rest.

verse.text: But he answered them, He who made me well, that One said to me, Take up your mat and walk.
They asked him, Who is the man who said to you, Take up [i]your mat[/i] and walk?
But he who had been healed did not know who it was, for Jesus had withdrawn, there being a crowd in that place.
After these things Jesus found him in the temple and said to him, Behold, you have become well; [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sin no more so that nothing worse happens to you.
verse.note: This indicates that the man's former sickness was due to his sin.

verse.text: The man went away and told the Jews that Jesus was the One who made him well.
And because of this the Jews persecuted Jesus [note]1[/note]and [xref]a[/xref]sought to kill Him, because He did these things on the Sabbath.
verse.note: Some MSS omit, and sought to kill Him.

verse.text: But Jesus answered them, My Father is [note]1[/note]working until now, and I also am working.
verse.note: God's work in creation was finished ([link]Gen. 2:1-3[/link]), but the Father and the Son were still working for redemption and building.

verse.text: Because of this therefore the Jews [note]1[/note]sought all the more to [xref]a[/xref]kill Him, because He not only broke the Sabbath but also called God His own Father, making Himself [note]2[/note]equal with [xref]b[/xref]God.
verse.note: On one hand, the religious people kept the Sabbath, but on the other hand, they sought to kill Jesus. How could they have had rest? Because of their religious concept, they thought that to kill those who would not keep their religious ritual was to offer service to God ([link]16:2[/link]). This is Satan's poisoning of people with religion, causing them to murder, just as he poisons people with sin.
Actually, the Son and the Father are one ([link]10:30[/link]).

verse.text: Then Jesus answered and said to them, Truly, truly, I say to you, [xref]a[/xref]The Son can do nothing from Himself except what He sees the Father doing, for whatever that One does, these things the Son also does in like manner.
For [xref]a[/xref]the Father loves the Son and shows Him all things that He Himself is doing; and [xref]b[/xref]greater works than these He will show Him that you may marvel.
For just as the Father [xref]a[/xref]raises the dead and gives [i]them[/i] life, so also the Son gives life to whom He wills.
For neither does the Father judge anyone, but He has given all [xref]a[/xref]judgment to the Son,
In order that all may honor the Son even as they honor the Father. He who does not honor the Son does not honor the Father who sent Him.

Truly, truly, I say to you, He who hears My word and [xref]a[/xref]believes Him who sent Me has [note]1[/note]eternal life, and does not come into [note]2[/note]judgment but has [xref]b[/xref]passed out of [note]3[/note]death into life.
verse.note: See note [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].
Or, condemnation.

The source of death is the tree of knowledge, and the source of life is the tree of life (cf. [link]Gen. 2:9[/link], [link]17[/link]). Hence, to pass out of death into life is to change the source of one's living.

verse.text: Truly, truly, I say to you, An hour is coming, and it is now, when the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]dead will hear the voice of the Son of God, and those who hear will [note]1[/note]live.
verse.note: Not those who are dead physically but those who are dead in spirit, in accordance with [link]Eph. 2:1[/link], [link]5[/link] and [link]Col. 2:13[/link]. Hence, in this verse to live means to be alive in spirit. It does not signify resurrection of the physical body, which is mentioned in [link book="John" chapter="5"]vv. 28-29[/link].

verse.text: For just as the Father has life in Himself, so He gave to the Son to also have [xref]a[/xref]life in Himself;
And He gave Him authority to execute [xref]a[/xref]judgment because He is the [note]1[/note]Son of Man.
verse.note: The Lord is the Son of God ([link]v. 25[/link]); hence, He can give life ([link]v. 21[/link]). He is also the Son of Man; hence, He can execute judgment.

verse.text: Do not marvel at this, for an hour is coming in which [note]1[/note]all in the tombs will hear His [xref]a[/xref]voice
verse.note: Referring to those who are dead physically and are buried in a tomb. Hence, their coming forth from the tomb in [link]v. 29[/link] is the resurrection of the physical body.

verse.text: And will come forth: [xref]a[/xref]those who have done good, to the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]resurrection of life; and those who have [note]2[/note]practiced evil, to the [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]resurrection of [note]4[/note]judgment.
verse.note: This is the resurrection of the saved believers, which will take place before the millennium ([link]Rev. 20:4[/link], [link]6[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 15:23[/link], [link]52[/link]; [link]1 Thes. 4:16[/link]). At the Lord Jesus' coming back, the dead believers will be resurrected to enjoy eternal life. Hence, this resurrection is called the resurrection of life.
See note [link]20[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].

This is the resurrection of the unbelievers who have perished; it will take place after the millennium ([link]Rev. 20:5[/link], [link]12[/link]). All the dead unbelievers will be resurrected after the thousand years to be judged at the great white throne ([link]Rev. 20:11-15[/link]). Hence, this resurrection is called the resurrection of judgment.[br][br]In this chapter [link book="John" chapter="5"]vv. 24-26[/link] speak concerning the enlivening of the spirit; [link]vv. 28-29[/link], concerning the resurrection of the whole being, including the body.
Or, condemnation.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]I can do nothing from Myself; as I hear, I judge, and [xref]b[/xref]My judgment is just, because I do not seek My own will but the [xref]c[/xref]will of Him who sent Me.
If [xref]a[/xref]I testify concerning Myself, My testimony is not true.
There is another who testifies concerning Me, and I know that the testimony which he testifies concerning Me is true.
You have sent [i]people[/i] to John, and [xref]a[/xref]he has testified to the [note]1[/note]truth.
verse.note: The same Greek word as for [i]reality[/i] in [link]1:14[/link], [link]17[/link]. The preceding verse says that John testified concerning Christ; this verse says that John testified to the truth. This proves that truth here is Christ ([link]14:6[/link]). According to the entire revelation of this Gospel, truth is the divine reality embodied, revealed, and expressed in Christ, the Son of God. See note [link]6[sup]6[/sup] in 1 John 1[/link].

verse.text: But [i]it is[/i] not from man [i]that[/i] I receive My testimony, but I say these things that you may be saved.
He was the lamp that was burning and shining, and you were willing to exult for a while in his light.

But I have the testimony [i]which is[/i] greater than [i]that[/i] of John, for the [xref]a[/xref]works which the Father has given Me to finish, the works themselves which I do, testify concerning Me that the Father has [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]sent Me.
verse.note: See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link]; so in [link]v. 38[/link].

verse.text: And the [xref]a[/xref]Father who sent Me, He has [note]1[/note]testified concerning Me. You have neither heard His voice at any time, nor have you seen His form,
verse.note: This refers to the Father's testimony concerning the Lord, given at the time He was baptized ([link]Matt. 3:17[/link]). At that time the Jews heard the Father's voice and saw the form of the Holy Spirit ([link]Luke 3:22[/link]), although prior to that time they had neither heard His voice at any time nor seen His form.

verse.text: And you do not have His word abiding in you, for Him whom He sent, this One you do not believe.
You [note]1[/note]search the Scriptures, because you think that in them you have eternal life; and it is these that testify concerning Me.
verse.note: To "search the Scriptures" may be separated from "come to Me" ([link]v. 40[/link]). The Jewish religionists searched the Scriptures but were not willing to come to the Lord. These two should go together; because the Scriptures testify concerning the Lord, they should not be separated from the Lord. We may contact the Scriptures, yet not contact the Lord. Only the Lord can give life.

verse.text: Yet you are not willing to [note]1[/note]come to Me that you may have life.
verse.note: See note [link]39[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: I do not receive glory from men.
But I know you, that you do not have the love of God in yourselves.
I have come [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]in the name of My Father, and you do not receive Me; if another comes in his own name, you will receive him.
verse.note: The Son being in the name of the Father is equivalent to the Son being the Father; hence, He is called the Father ([link]Isa. 9:6[/link]). This proves that the Son and the Father are one ([link]10:30[/link]). See note [link]26[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 14[/link].

verse.text: How can you believe when you receive glory from one another and do not seek the glory that is from the only God?
Do not think that I will accuse you before the Father; there is one who accuses you: Moses, in whom you have set your hope.
For if you believed Moses, you would believe Me; for [xref]a[/xref]he wrote concerning Me.
But [xref]a[/xref]if you do not believe his writings, how will you believe My words?
After these things Jesus went away across the [note]1[/note]Sea of Galilee, [i]which is the Sea[/i] of Tiberias.
verse.note: This case is in contrast to the case in [link]ch. 5[/link]. There the person was by a pool; here the people are around a sea. The scene of the foregoing case was the holy city with a sacred pool for man's healing. The scene of this case is the wilderness with a secular sea for man's livelihood. The person in the previous case was impotent and needed life's enlivening. The people in this case are hungry and need life's feeding. In typology the land signifies the earth, which was created by God for man to live on, and the sea signifies the world, which has been corrupted by Satan and in which fallen mankind lives. In this world mankind is hungry and has no satisfaction. In this world mankind is troubled and has no peace, as portrayed in [link]v. 18[/link].

verse.text: And a great crowd followed Him, because they saw the [xref]a[/xref]signs which He did on those who were sick.
And Jesus went up to the [note]1[/note]mountain and sat there with His disciples.
verse.note: A mountain signifies a transcendent position above the land and the sea. To enjoy Christ's feeding, people must go with Christ to the mountain.

verse.text: Now the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Passover, the feast of the Jews, was near.
verse.note: In the Passover, people slay the redeeming lamb, sprinkle its blood, and eat its flesh. This typifies Christ as our Passover ([link]1 Cor. 5:7[/link]). He is the redeeming Lamb of God ([link]1:29[/link], [link]36[/link]) slain for us that we may eat His flesh and drink His blood, taking Him in as our life supply that we may live by Him.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Jesus then lifting up His eyes and seeing that a great crowd was coming toward Him, said to Philip, Where shall we buy bread that these may eat?
But this He said to test him, for He Himself knew what He was about to do.
Philip answered Him, Two hundred [note]1[/note]denarii worth of bread is not sufficient for them, that each one may take a little.
verse.note: The denarius was the chief silver coin of the Romans; it was considered good pay for a day's labor (see [link]Matt. 20:2[/link]).

verse.text: One of His disciples, Andrew, Simon Peter's brother, said to Him,
There is a little boy here who has [note]1[/note]five [note]2[/note]barley loaves and [note]1[/note]two [note]2[/note]fish; but what are these for so many?
verse.note: The number five signifies responsibility, indicating here that Christ bears the responsibility to be our life supply. The number two signifies testimony, testifying here that Christ is our life supply.

Loaves are of the vegetable life and signify the generating aspect of Christ's life. Fish are of the animal life and signify the redeeming aspect of Christ's life. As the generating life, Christ grows in the land, the God-created earth; as the redeeming life, He lives in the sea, the Satan-corrupted world. In order to regenerate us, He grew on the God-created earth that He might reproduce; in order to redeem us, He lived in the satanic and sinful world. But He is not sinful, not affected by the world, just as fish live in salt water but are not salty.[br][br]In the Jewish land barley ripens earliest and is the first of the harvest; hence, it typifies the resurrected Christ ([link]Lev. 23:10[/link]). The barley loaves represent Christ in resurrection as food to us.[br][br]Barley loaves and fish are small items, signifying Christ's smallness, through which He can be the life supply to us. Those who sought miracles considered Him the promised Prophet and would have forced Him to be King ([link]vv. 14-15[/link]), but He would not seek to be a giant in religion; rather, He preferred to be small loaves and little fish that people might eat Him.

verse.text: Jesus said, Have the people recline. Now there was much grass in the place. So the men reclined, in number about five thousand.
Jesus then took the loaves, and when He had given thanks, He distributed to those who were reclining; likewise also of the fish, as much as they wanted.
And when they were filled, He said to His disciples, Gather the broken pieces left over that nothing may be lost.
So they gathered [i]them[/i] and filled [note]1[/note]twelve handbaskets with broken pieces from the five barley loaves which were left over among those who had eaten.
verse.note: The twelve handbaskets left over signify the overflow of the riches of Christ's life supply. The five loaves, which represent this supply, not only fed one thousand times that number, that is, five thousand people, but also provided enough for something to be left over.

verse.text: The people therefore, seeing the sign which He did, said, This is truly the [xref]a[/xref]Prophet who is to come into the world.
Then Jesus, knowing that they were about to come and take [i]Him[/i] by force [note]1[/note]to make Him [xref]a[/xref]King, [xref]b[/xref]withdrew again to the mountain, Himself alone.
verse.note: I.e., to make Him the Messiah.

verse.text: And when evening fell, His disciples went down to the sea,
And they got into a boat and began crossing the sea to Capernaum. And it had already become dark, and Jesus had not yet come to them.
And because a strong wind was blowing, the [note]1[/note]sea was churning.
verse.note: The churning of the sea signifies the troubles in human life.

verse.text: Then, when they had rowed about [note]1[/note]twenty-five or thirty stadia, they saw [note]2[/note]Jesus walking on the sea and coming near the boat, and they became frightened.
verse.note: I.e., about three or four miles.
This signifies that the Lord can overrule all the troubles of human life. He can walk on the troubling waves of human life, and all the troubles are under His feet.

verse.text: But He said to them, It is I. Do not be afraid.
Then they were willing to [note]1[/note]take Him into the boat; and immediately the boat was at the land to which they were going.
verse.note: We need to take the Lord into our "boat" (our married life, our family, our business, etc.) and enjoy peace with Him on the journey of human life.

verse.text: The next day the crowd which stood on the other side of the sea saw that there had been no other small boat there except one, and that Jesus had not gotten into the boat with His disciples, but [i]that[/i] His disciples had gone away alone.
But other small boats from Tiberias came near to the place where they ate the bread after the Lord had given thanks.
So when the crowd saw that Jesus was not there, nor His disciples, they themselves got into the small boats and came to Capernaum, seeking Jesus.
And when they found Him on the other side of the sea, they said to Him, Rabbi, when did You get here?
Jesus answered them and said, Truly, truly, I say to you, You seek Me not because you have seen signs, but because you ate of the bread and were filled.

[xref]a[/xref]Work not for the food which perishes, but for the [xref]b[/xref]food which abides unto [note]1[/note]eternal life, which the Son of Man will give you; for Him has the Father, [i]even[/i] God, sealed.
verse.note: See note [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link]; so in [link chapter="6"]vv. 40[/link], [link]47[/link], [link]54[/link], [link]68[/link].

verse.text: Then they said to Him, What shall we [note]1[/note]do that we may [note]1[/note]work the works of God?
verse.note: Fallen man's concept concerning God is that he must do something for God and work for God. This is the principle of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil in [link]Gen. 2[/link].

verse.text: Jesus answered and said to them, This is the work of God, that you [note]1[/note]believe into Him whom He has [note]2[/note]sent.
verse.note: The Lord's concept concerning God is that man should believe into Him, that is, receive Him as life and the life supply. This is the principle of the tree of life, which brings in life, as seen in [link]Gen. 2[/link]. It is in contrast to the principle of the tree of knowledge, which brings in death.
See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link]; so in [link chapter="6"]v. 57[/link].

verse.text: They said then to Him, What [xref]a[/xref]sign then will You do that we may see and believe You? What work will You do?
Our fathers [xref]a[/xref]ate the manna in the wilderness, as it is written, [xref]b[/xref]"He gave them bread out of heaven to eat."
Jesus therefore said to them, Truly, truly, I say to you, Moses has not given you the bread out of heaven, but My Father gives you the true bread out of heaven.
For the bread of God is He who [note]1[/note]comes down out of heaven and gives life to the world.
verse.note: Through incarnation.

verse.text: They said therefore to Him, Lord, give us this bread always.
Jesus said to them, I am the [note]1[/note]bread of life; he who comes to Me [xref]a[/xref]shall [note]2[/note]by no means hunger, and he who believes into Me shall by no means ever thirst.
verse.note: The bread of life is the life supply in the form of food. It is like the tree of life ([link]Gen. 2:9[/link]), which also is the life supply "good for food."
In the principle set forth in [link]ch. 2[/link], this also is the changing of death into life. The source of death is the tree of knowledge, and the source of life is the tree of life.

verse.text: But I have said to you that you have also seen Me, and yet you do not believe.
All that the Father [xref]a[/xref]gives Me will come to Me, and him who comes to Me I shall by no means cast out.
For [xref]a[/xref]I have come down from heaven [xref]b[/xref]not to do My own will but the [xref]c[/xref]will of Him who sent Me.
And this is the will of Him who sent Me, that of all which He has given Me I should [xref]a[/xref]lose nothing but should [xref]b[/xref]raise it up in the last day.
For this is the will of My Father, that everyone who beholds the Son and believes into Him should have eternal life, and I will raise him up in the last day.
The Jews therefore murmured concerning Him because He said, I am the bread that [xref]a[/xref]came down out of heaven.
And they said, [xref]a[/xref]Is not this Jesus, the [note]1[/note]son of Joseph, whose father and mother we know? How does He now say, [xref]b[/xref]I have come down out of heaven?
verse.note: See note [link]45[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: Jesus answered and said to them, Do not murmur among yourselves.
[xref]a[/xref]No one can come to Me unless the Father who sent Me [xref]b[/xref]draws him; and I will [xref]c[/xref]raise him up in the last day.
It is written in the prophets, [xref]a[/xref]"And they shall all be [xref]b[/xref]taught of God." Everyone who has heard and learned from the Father comes to Me.
[xref]a[/xref]Not that anyone has seen the Father, except Him who is [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]from God, He has seen the Father.
