verse.note: See note [link]14[sup]5[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: Truly, truly, I say to you, He who believes [xref]a[/xref]has eternal life.
I am the bread of life.
Your fathers ate the manna in the wilderness, and they died.
This is the bread which [xref]a[/xref]comes down out of heaven, that anyone may [xref]b[/xref]eat of it and not die.

I am the [note]1[/note]living bread which came down out of heaven; if anyone eats of this bread, [xref]a[/xref]he shall live forever;[separator]And the bread which I will give is My [note]2[/note]flesh, [i]given[/i] [note]3[/note]for the life of the [xref]b[/xref]world.
verse.note: [i]Bread of life[/i] ([link]v. 35[/link]) refers to the nature of the bread, which is life; [i]living bread[/i] refers to the condition of the bread, which is living.

At this point the bread becomes the flesh. Bread is of the vegetable life and is only for feeding; flesh is of the animal life and is not only for feeding but also for redeeming. Before the fall of man, the Lord was the tree of life ([link]Gen. 2:9[/link]), which is only for feeding man. After man fell into sin, the Lord became the Lamb ([link]1:29[/link]), which is not only for feeding man but also for redeeming him ([link]Exo. 12:4[/link], [link]7-8[/link]).
The Lord gave His body, that is, His flesh, dying for us that we might have life.

verse.text: The Jews then contended with one another, saying, How can this man give us His flesh to eat?
Jesus therefore said to them, Truly, truly, I say to you, Unless you eat the flesh of the Son of Man and drink His [note]1[/note]blood, you do not have life within yourselves.
verse.note: At this point blood is added, which is necessary for redemption ([link]19:34[/link]; [link]Heb. 9:22[/link]; [link]Matt. 26:28[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 1:18-19[/link]; [link]Rom. 3:25[/link]).

verse.text: He who [note]1[/note]eats My [note]2[/note]flesh and drinks My [note]2[/note]blood has eternal life, and I will [xref]a[/xref]raise him up in the last day.
verse.note: Lit., masticates; so in [link]vv. 56[/link], [link]57[/link], [link]58[/link].

Here flesh and blood are mentioned separately. The separation of blood and flesh indicates death. Here the Lord clearly indicated His death, that is, His being slain. He gave His body and shed His blood for us that we may have eternal life. To eat His flesh is to receive by faith all that He did in giving His body for us; and to drink His blood is to receive by faith all that He accomplished in shedding His blood for us. To eat His flesh and drink His blood is to receive Him, in His redemption, as life and the life supply by believing in what He did for us on the cross. By comparing this verse with [link]v. 47[/link], we see that to eat the Lord's flesh and drink His blood is to believe in Him, because to believe or to believe into is to receive ([link]1:12[/link]).

verse.text: For My flesh is true food, and My blood is true drink.
He who eats My flesh and drinks My blood [xref]a[/xref]abides in Me and [note]1[/note]I in him.
verse.note: This indicates that the Lord had to be resurrected so that He could abide in us as our life and life supply.

verse.text: As the living Father has sent Me and I live because of the Father, so he who [note]1[/note]eats Me, he also shall [xref]a[/xref]live because of Me.
verse.note: To eat is to take food into us that it may be assimilated organically into our body. Hence, to eat the Lord Jesus is to receive Him into us that He may be assimilated by the regenerated new man in the way of life. Then we live by Him whom we have received. It is by this that He, the resurrected One, lives in us ([link]14:19-20[/link]).

verse.text: This is the bread which came down out of heaven, not as the fathers ate and died; he who eats this bread [xref]a[/xref]shall live forever.
He said these things in a synagogue as He taught in Capernaum.
Many therefore of His disciples, when they heard [i]this,[/i] said, This word is hard; who can hear it?
But Jesus, knowing in Himself that His disciples were murmuring about this, said to them, Does this [xref]a[/xref]stumble you?
Then what if you saw the Son of Man [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]ascending to where He was before?
verse.note: In [link]v. 56[/link] the Lord's resurrection is implied. In this verse His ascension, which followed His resurrection, is clearly mentioned. The Lord's ascension was the proof that His redemptive work had been completed ([link]Heb. 1:3b[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]It is the [note]1[/note]Spirit who gives life; the [note]2[/note]flesh profits nothing; the [note]3[/note]words which I have spoken to you are spirit and are life.
verse.note: At this point the Spirit who gives life is brought in. After resurrection and through resurrection, the Lord Jesus, who had become flesh ([link]1:14[/link]), became the Spirit who gives life, as is clearly mentioned in [link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]. It is as the life-giving Spirit that He can be life and the life supply to us. When we receive Him as the crucified and resurrected Savior, the Spirit who gives life comes into us to impart eternal life into us. We receive the Lord Jesus, but we get the Spirit who gives life.

[i]Flesh[/i] here, according to the context, refers to the meat of the physical body. When the Lord said, "The bread which I will give is My flesh" ([link]v. 51[/link]), the Jews thought that He would give them the meat of His physical body to eat ([link]v. 52[/link]). They did not understand the Lord's word rightly. To them it was a hard word ([link]v. 60[/link]). Hence, in this verse the Lord explained that what He would give them to eat was not the meat of His physical body; the meat, which is the flesh, profits nothing. What He would give, eventually, was the Spirit who gives life, who is the Lord Himself in resurrection.

The Greek word for [i]words,[/i] here and in [link]v. 68[/link], is [i]rhema,[/i] which denotes the instant and present spoken word. It differs from [i]logos[/i] (used for [i]Word[/i] in [link]1:1[/link]), which denotes the constant word. Here [i]the words[/i] follows [i]the Spirit.[/i] The Spirit is living and real, yet He is very mysterious, intangible, and difficult for people to apprehend; the words, however, are substantial. First, the Lord indicated that for giving life He would become the Spirit. Then He said that the words He speaks are spirit and life. This shows that His spoken words are the embodiment of the Spirit of life. He is now the life-giving Spirit in resurrection, and the Spirit is embodied in His words. When we receive His words by exercising our spirit, we get the Spirit, who is life.

verse.text: But there are some of you who do not believe. For Jesus [xref]a[/xref]knew from the beginning who were the ones who did not believe and [xref]b[/xref]who was the one who would [note]1[/note]betray Him.
verse.note: Lit., deliver Him up; so throughout the book.

verse.text: And He said, For this [i]reason[/i] I have told you that [xref]a[/xref]no one can come to Me unless it has been [xref]b[/xref]given to him from the Father.
From that time many of His disciples went back to what [i]they left[/i] behind and no longer walked with Him.
Jesus therefore said to the twelve, Do you also want to go away?
Simon Peter answered Him, Lord, to whom shall we go? You have [xref]a[/xref]words of eternal life,
And we have believed and have come to know that You are the Holy One of God.
Jesus answered them, [i]Was it[/i] not I [i]who[/i] [xref]a[/xref]chose you, the twelve? Yet one of you is [xref]b[/xref]a devil.
Now He spoke of Judas, [i]the son[/i] of Simon Iscariot, for he, one of the twelve, would betray Him.
And after these things Jesus walked in Galilee, for He would not walk in Judea, because the Jews were [xref]a[/xref]seeking to [note]1[/note]kill Him.
verse.note: Although the Lord is God the Creator, He lived on earth as a man and suffered persecution at the hands of His creatures.

verse.text: Now the Jews' [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Feast of Tabernacles was near.
verse.note: In the scene of the case in [link]ch. 6[/link] there was the Feast of the Passover. In the scene of this case in [link]ch. 7[/link] there is the Feast of Tabernacles. The Feast of the Passover is the first of the Jewish annual feasts, and the Feast of Tabernacles is the last ([link]Lev. 23:5[/link], [link]34[/link]). The Feast of the Passover, being the first feast of the year, implies the beginning of man's life (cf. [link]Exo. 12:2-3[/link], [link]6[/link]), which involves man's seeking for satisfaction and results in man's hunger. The Feast of Tabernacles, being the last feast of the year, implies the completion and success of man's life (cf. [link]Exo. 23:16[/link]), which will end and will result in man's thirst. In the scene of the Feast of the Passover, the Lord presented Himself as the bread of life, which satisfies man's hunger. In the scene of the Feast of Tabernacles, the Lord promised that He would flow forth the living water, which quenches man's thirst.[br][br]After the full harvest of their crops, the Jewish people observed the Feast of Tabernacles to worship God and enjoy what they had reaped ([link]Deut. 16:13-15[/link]). Hence, this feast signifies the completion, achievement, and success in man's career, man's study, and other matters of human life, including religion, with the joy and enjoyment thereof.[br][br]God ordained the Feast of Tabernacles so that the children of Israel would remember how their fathers, while wandering in the wilderness, had lived in tents ([link]Lev. 23:39-43[/link]), expecting to enter into the rest of the good land. Hence, this feast is a reminder that today people are still in the wilderness and need to enter into the rest of the New Jerusalem, which is the eternal tabernacle ([link]Rev. 21:2-3[/link]). Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob also lived in tents and looked forward to this eternal tabernacle ([link]Heb. 11:9-10[/link]), in which there will be a river of water of life proceeding out of the throne of God and of the Lamb to quench man's thirst ([link]Rev. 22:1[/link], [link]17[/link]). At the end of such a feast, which had such a background, Christ cried out the promise of the rivers of living water, which will satisfy man's expectation for eternity ([link]vv. 37-39[/link]).

verse.text: His brothers therefore said to Him, Depart from here and go into Judea, so that Your disciples also may behold Your works which You are doing;
For no one does anything in secret and himself seeks to be [i]known[/i] openly. If You do these things, manifest Yourself to the world.
For not even His brothers believed into Him.
Jesus therefore said to them, My [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]time has not yet come, but your time is always ready.
verse.note: Although the Lord is the eternal, infinite, unlimited God, He lived here on earth as a man, being limited even in the matter of time.

verse.text: The [xref]a[/xref]world cannot hate you, but it hates Me, because I testify concerning it, that [xref]b[/xref]its works are evil.
You go up to the feast; I am not going up to this feast, because My [xref]a[/xref]time has not yet been fulfilled.
And having said these things to them, He remained in Galilee.
But when His brothers had gone up to the feast, then He Himself also went up, [note]1[/note]not openly, but as [i]it were[/i] in secret.
verse.note: Although He is the Almighty God, as a man under persecution the Lord was limited also in relation to His activity.

verse.text: The Jews therefore [xref]a[/xref]sought Him at the feast and said, Where is He?
And there was much murmuring about Him among the crowds: [xref]a[/xref]some said, He is a good man; but others said, No; rather He leads the crowd astray.
Yet no one spoke openly about Him for [xref]a[/xref]fear of the Jews.
But when it was now the middle of the feast, Jesus went up into the temple and began to teach.
The Jews therefore marveled and said, How does this man know letters, [note]1[/note]without ever having studied?
verse.note: Although He is the omniscient God, as a lowly man the Lord appeared to be illiterate.

verse.text: Jesus therefore answered them and said, [xref]a[/xref]My teaching is not Mine, but His who sent Me.
If anyone resolves to do His will, he will know concerning the teaching, whether it is of God or whether I speak from Myself.
He who speaks from himself [xref]a[/xref]seeks his own glory; but He who seeks the glory of Him who sent Him, this One is true, and unrighteousness is not in Him.
[xref]a[/xref]Has not Moses given you the law? Yet none of you keeps the law. Why do you [xref]b[/xref]seek to kill Me?
The crowd answered, You [xref]a[/xref]have a demon! Who is seeking to kill You?
Jesus answered and said to them, I did [xref]a[/xref]one work, and you all marvel.
For the same reason [xref]a[/xref]Moses gave you circumcision (not that it is from Moses, but from the fathers), and on the Sabbath you circumcise a man.
If a man receives circumcision on the Sabbath that the law of Moses may not be broken, are you angry with Me because I [xref]a[/xref]made an entire man well on the Sabbath?
Do not judge according to [note]1[/note]appearance, but judge the righteous judgment.
verse.note: Or, countenance, face, sight.

verse.text: Then some of the people of Jerusalem said, Is not this the One whom they are seeking to kill?
And look, He is speaking openly, and they say nothing to Him. Have the rulers, perhaps, really recognized that this is the Christ?
But we [xref]a[/xref]know where this man is from; yet when the Christ comes, no one knows where He is from.

Jesus therefore cried out in the temple, teaching and saying, You both [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]know Me and [note]1[/note]know where I am from; and [xref]b[/xref]I have not come of Myself, but He who sent Me is true, whom you do not [note]1[/note]know.
verse.note: Inward, subjective understanding. So in the next verse.

verse.text: I [xref]a[/xref]know Him, because I am [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]from Him, and He [note]2[/note]sent Me.
verse.note: See note [link]14[sup]5[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].
See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: They sought then to [xref]a[/xref]seize Him, yet no one laid a hand on Him, because [xref]b[/xref]His hour had not yet come.
But many out of the crowd believed into Him and said, Will the Christ, when He comes, do more signs than this man has done?
The Pharisees heard the crowd murmuring these things about Him, and the chief priests and the Pharisees sent attendants to arrest Him.
Jesus therefore said, [xref]a[/xref]I am still with you a little while, and [i]then[/i] [xref]b[/xref]I am going to Him who sent Me.
[xref]a[/xref]You will seek Me and will not find Me; and where I am, you cannot come.
The Jews then said to one another, Where is this man about to go that we will not find Him? Is He about to go to the [i]Jews in[/i] dispersion among the Greeks and teach the Greeks?
What is the word which He said, You will seek Me and will not find Me; and where I am, you cannot come?
Now on the [note]1[/note]last day, the great [i]day[/i] of the feast, Jesus stood and cried out, saying, If anyone [xref]a[/xref]thirsts, let him [xref]b[/xref]come to Me and [xref]c[/xref]drink.
verse.note: The last day here signifies that all the enjoyment of any success in the human life will end. There is a "last day" to every kind of material thing of the physical life.

verse.text: He who believes into Me, as the Scripture said, out of his [xref]a[/xref]innermost being shall [note]1[/note]flow [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]rivers of living water.
verse.note: In the principle set forth in [link]ch. 2[/link], this also is the changing of death into life. The source of death is the tree of knowledge, and the source of life is the tree of life. This book shows us that life is in opposition to death ([link]5:24-25[/link]; [link]8:24[/link]; [link]11:25-26[/link]).

The rivers of living water are the many flows of the different aspects of life (cf. [link]Rom. 15:30[/link]; [link]1 Thes. 1:6[/link]; [link]2 Thes. 2:13[/link]; [link]Gal. 5:22-23[/link]), originating from the one unique river of water of life ([link]Rev. 22:1[/link]), which is God's Spirit of life ([link]Rom. 8:2[/link]).

verse.text: But this He said concerning the Spirit, whom those who believed into Him were about to receive; for [i]the[/i] [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Spirit was not yet, because Jesus had not yet been [xref]b[/xref]glorified.
verse.note: The Spirit of God was there from the beginning ([link]Gen. 1:1-2[/link]), but at the time the Lord spoke this word, the Spirit as the Spirit of Christ ([link]Rom. 8:9[/link]), the Spirit of Jesus Christ ([link]Phil. 1:19[/link]), was not yet, because the Lord had not yet been glorified. Jesus was glorified when He was resurrected ([link]Luke 24:26[/link]). After Jesus' resurrection, the Spirit of God became the Spirit of the incarnated, crucified, and resurrected Jesus Christ, who was breathed into the disciples by Christ in the evening of the day on which He was resurrected ([link]20:22[/link]). The Spirit is now the "another Comforter," the Spirit of reality promised by Christ before His death ([link]14:16-17[/link]). When the Spirit was the Spirit of God, He had only the divine element. After He became the Spirit of Jesus Christ through Christ's incarnation, crucifixion, and resurrection, the Spirit had both the divine element and the human element, with all the essence and reality of the incarnation, crucifixion, and resurrection of Christ. Hence, the Spirit is now the all-inclusive Spirit of Jesus Christ as the living water for us to receive ([link]vv. 38-39[/link]).

verse.text: [i]Some[/i] of the crowd therefore, when they heard these words, said, This is truly the [xref]a[/xref]Prophet.
Others said, This is the [xref]a[/xref]Christ. But some said, Does then the Christ come out of [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Galilee?
verse.note: The Lord was born in Bethlehem ([link]Luke 2:4-7[/link]) but was raised in Nazareth of Galilee, a city that was despised by people at that time. He was the seed of David, but He came as a Nazarene ([link]Matt. 2:23[/link]). He grew up "like a root out of dry ground," having "no attracting form nor majesty," "nor beautiful appearance that we should desire Him," and "was despised and forsaken of men" ([link]Isa. 53:2-3[/link]). Hence, we should know Him not according to the flesh ([link]2 Cor. 5:16[/link]) but according to the Spirit.

verse.text: Has not the Scripture said that the Christ comes out of the [xref]a[/xref]seed of David and from [xref]b[/xref]Bethlehem, the village where David was?
So there arose a division among the crowd because of Him.
And some of them wanted to seize Him, but no one laid hands on Him.
The attendants therefore came to the chief priests and Pharisees, and these said to them, Why did you not bring Him?
The attendants answered, [xref]a[/xref]Never has a man spoken as this man [i]has.[/i]
The Pharisees then answered them, Have you also been deceived?
Has any one of the [xref]a[/xref]rulers or Pharisees believed into Him?
But this crowd which does not know the law is accursed.
[xref]a[/xref]Nicodemus said to them (he who came to Him before, being one of them),
Does our law [note]1[/note]condemn a man unless it first hears from him and knows what he is doing?
verse.note: Or, judge.

verse.text: They answered and said to him, Are you also from Galilee? Search and see that no prophet arises out of [xref]a[/xref]Galilee.
[note]1[/note]And everyone went to his [i]own[/i] house.
verse.note: Many ancient MSS omit [link]7:53-8:11[/link].

verse.text: But Jesus went to the Mount of Olives.
And early in the morning He came again into the temple, and all the people came to Him, and He sat down and taught them.
And the scribes and Pharisees brought a [note]1[/note]woman caught in adultery, and having set her in the midst,
verse.note: In this Gospel nine cases have been selected to prove that the Lord Jesus is the life and the life supply to people. The first six cases, in [link]chs. 3-7[/link], form a group of signs signifying that, on the positive side, the Lord is the life and the life supply to us for regenerating, satisfying, healing, enlivening, feeding, and thirst quenching. The last three cases, in [link]chs. 8-11[/link], form a group of signs signifying that, on the negative side, the Lord is life to us to deliver us from the three main negative things: sin, blindness, and death.[br][br]The case in this chapter reveals all the matters related to the problem of sin: (1) the source of sin — the devil; (2) the three main items of sin — adultery and fornication, murder, and lies ([link]vv. 3[/link], [link]41[/link], [link]44[/link]); (3) the bondage, or slavery, of sin; (4) the issue, or result, of sin — death; (5) the One who is without sin — the Lord; (6) the One who is qualified to condemn sin — the Lord; (7) the One who is qualified to forgive sin — the Lord; (8) the One who is able to set people free from sin — the Lord. The Lord is the ever-existing God, the great I Am, who became the Son of Man and was lifted up on the cross to bear our sins; hence, He is qualified to forgive our sins. Furthermore, the Lord, being the eternal God, can come into us to be life and light to deliver us from the bondage and darkness of sin.[br][br]The case in this chapter shows also that the religion (represented by the temple — [link]vv. 2[/link], [link]20[/link]) of law ([link]vv. 5[/link], [link]17[/link]) cannot set people free from sin and death; but the Lord Jesus, the I Am, who became the Son of Man and was lifted up on the cross for the serpent-poisoned people, can do what religion and law cannot do. This chapter shows us that Christ, the great I Am, not only is versus sin and death but also is versus religion and law.

verse.text: They said to Him, Teacher, this woman has been caught committing adultery, in the very act.
Now [xref]a[/xref]in the law, Moses commanded us to stone such women. [note]1[/note]What then do You say?
verse.note: Their question here, like those in [link]4:20-25[/link] and [link]9:2-3[/link], was a matter of yes or no, which belongs to the tree of knowledge, the result of which is death ([link]Gen. 2:17[/link]). But the Lord's answer in [link]v. 7[/link] pointed them to Himself, the One who is the tree of life, which results in life ([link]Gen. 2:9[/link]).

verse.text: But they said this to [xref]a[/xref]tempt Him, so that they might have [i]reason[/i] to accuse Him. But Jesus [note]1[/note]stooped down and wrote with His finger on the ground.
verse.note: The Lord Jesus' stooping down was a sign done to humble and calm the proud and self-righteous scribes and Pharisees. It might be that He was writing, "Who among you is without sin?"

verse.text: But when they persisted in questioning Him, He stood up and said to them, He who is without sin among you, [xref]a[/xref]let him [i]be the[/i] first to throw a stone at her.
And again He stooped down and wrote on the ground.
And when they heard [i]that,[/i] they went out one by one, beginning with the older ones. And Jesus was left alone, and the woman [i]stood[/i] where she was, in the midst.
And Jesus stood up and said to her, Woman, where are they? Has no one condemned you?
And she said, No one, [note]1[/note]Lord. And Jesus said, [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Neither do I condemn you; go, and from now on [xref]b[/xref]sin no more.
verse.note: Or, Sir.
The scribes and Pharisees could not condemn the woman, because they were all sinful. Only the Lord Jesus was without sin, and only He was qualified to condemn the woman; but He would not.

verse.text: Again therefore Jesus spoke to them, saying, I am the [xref]a[/xref]light of the world; he who follows Me shall by no means walk in darkness, but shall have the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]light of life.
verse.note: The light of life ([link]1:4[/link]) shines within man by the inner sense of life to deliver man from sin.

verse.text: The Pharisees then said to Him, You are [xref]a[/xref]testifying concerning Yourself; Your testimony is not true.

Jesus answered and said to them, Even if I testify concerning Myself, My testimony is true, for I know [xref]a[/xref]where I came from and where I am going; but [xref]b[/xref]you do not know where I come from or where I am going.
[xref]a[/xref]You [note]1[/note]judge according to the flesh; I [note]1[/note]judge no one.
verse.note: Or, condemn.

verse.text: But even if I do [xref]a[/xref]judge, My judgment is true, for I am not alone, but [note]1[/note]I [xref]b[/xref]and the Father who sent Me.
verse.note: This proves that when the Son was on the earth, the Father was with Him on the earth. The Father can never be separated from the Son, and the Son can never be separated from the Father. When the Son was on the earth, He was still in heaven with the Father ([link]3:13[/link]). This proves that when God became flesh ([link]1:14[/link]), it was the Son with the Father, the Father with the Son, in the Spirit (that is, the entire God — the Father, the Son, and the Spirit) who became flesh ([link]1 Tim. 3:16[/link]). See also [link]v. 29[/link].

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]in your law also it has been written that the testimony of two men is true:
I am One who testifies concerning Myself, and the Father who sent Me testifies concerning Me.
They said then to Him, Where is Your Father? Jesus answered, You know neither Me nor My Father; [xref]a[/xref]if you knew Me, you would know My Father also.
These words He spoke in the treasury as He taught in the temple; and no one seized Him, because His [xref]a[/xref]hour had not yet come.
He said therefore again to them, I am going away, and [xref]a[/xref]you will seek Me and will [xref]b[/xref]die in your sin. Where I am going, you cannot come.
The Jews then said, He is not going to kill Himself, is He, for He says, Where I am going, you cannot come?

And He said to them, [xref]a[/xref]You are [note]1[/note]from below, I am [note]1[/note]from above; you are [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]of this world, [xref]c[/xref]I am not [note]1[/note]of this world.
verse.note: [i]From[/i] and [i]of[/i] are the same word in Greek.

verse.text: Therefore I said to you that you will [xref]a[/xref]die in your sins; for unless you believe that [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]I am, you will [xref]a[/xref]die in your sins.
verse.note: [i]I am[/i] ([link]vv. 28[/link], [link]58[/link]) is the meaning of the name Jehovah ([link]Exo. 3:14[/link]), and Jehovah is the name of God ([link]Gen. 2:7[/link]), the One who is and who was and who is coming, the self-existing and ever-existing One ([link]Rev. 1:4[/link]; [link]Exo. 3:14-15[/link]). This name is used in speaking of God in His relationship with man. Hence, it indicates that the Lord is the ever-existing God who has a relationship with man. Any man who does not believe that the Lord is this very God will die in his sins.

verse.text: They said then to Him, Who are You? Jesus said to them, Altogether that which I also [note]1[/note]tell you.
verse.note: The Lord's speaking reveals what He is, in particular His eternal divinity, as the I Am spoken of in the foregoing verse. This is the basic element revealed in the Lord's word.

verse.text: I have many things to say and to judge concerning you, but [xref]a[/xref]He who sent Me is true, and what I have heard from Him, these things I speak to the world.
They did not understand that He was speaking to them of the Father.

Jesus therefore said to them, When you [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]lift up the Son of Man, [xref]b[/xref]then you will know that [xref]c[/xref]I am, and [i]that[/i] [xref]d[/xref]I do nothing from Myself, but as My Father has taught Me, I speak these things.
verse.note: The phrase [i]lift[/i] (or [i]lifted[/i]) [i]up[/i] is used also in [link]3:14[/link] and [link]12:31-34[/link]. In [link]3:14[/link] the Lord as the Son of Man was to be lifted up in the form of the serpent to bear the judgment of God for the serpent-poisoned people. In [link]12:31-34[/link] the Lord as the Son of Man was to be lifted up for the casting out of the old serpent, Satan, the ruler of the world. Hence, in this chapter the Lord, as the Son of Man lifted up, can deliver the serpent-poisoned people from sin, the serpent's poison.

verse.text: And He who sent Me is [xref]a[/xref]with Me; He has not left Me alone, for I always do the things that are pleasing to Him.
As He spoke these things, many believed into Him.
Then Jesus said to those Jews who believed Him, If you [xref]a[/xref]abide in My word, you are truly My disciples;
And you shall know the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]truth, and the [note]1[/note]truth shall [xref]b[/xref]set you free.
verse.note: In Greek the same as [i]reality[/i] in [link]1:14[/link], [link]17[/link]. The truth is not the so-called truth of doctrine but the reality of the divine things, which is the Lord Himself (see note [link]6[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 14[/link]; [link]1:14[/link], [link]17[/link]). This verse says that "the truth shall set you free," whereas [link]v. 36[/link] says that "the Son sets you free." This proves that the Son, the Lord Himself, is the truth. Since the Lord is the embodiment of God ([link]Col. 2:9[/link]), He is the reality of what God is. Hence, reality is the very divine element of God realized by us. When the Lord as the great I Am comes into us as life, He shines within us as light, bringing the divine element as reality into us. This reality, which is the divine element imparted into us and realized by us, sets us free from the bondage of sin by the divine life as the light of man. When the Lord as the Word of God became flesh ([link]1:14[/link]), He brought God to us as this reality, that God might be the grace for our enjoyment ([link]1:17[/link]).

verse.text: They answered Him, We are [xref]a[/xref]Abraham's seed and have never yet been enslaved to anyone. How [i]is it that[/i] You say, You shall become free?
Jesus answered them, Truly, truly, I say to you, Everyone who commits sin is a [xref]a[/xref]slave of sin.
And the slave does not abide in the house forever; the son does abide forever.
If therefore the Son [xref]a[/xref]sets you free, you shall be free indeed.
I know that you are Abraham's seed; but you [xref]a[/xref]seek to kill Me because My word has no place in you.
[xref]a[/xref]I speak the things which I have seen with My Father; so then, you also do the things which you have heard from [xref]b[/xref]your father.
They answered and said to Him, Our father is Abraham. Jesus said to them, If you were [xref]a[/xref]Abraham's children, you would do the works of Abraham.
But now you are [xref]a[/xref]seeking to kill Me, a man who has told you the truth which I heard from God; Abraham did not do this.
You do the works of [xref]a[/xref]your father. They then said to Him, We were not born of fornication; we have [xref]b[/xref]one Father, God.

Jesus said to them, If God were your Father you would love Me; for [xref]a[/xref]I came forth out from God and have come [i]from Him;[/i] for [xref]b[/xref]I have not come of Myself, but He [note]1[/note]sent Me.
verse.note: See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: Why do you not understand My speaking? It is because you cannot hear My word.

[xref]a[/xref]You are of [i]your[/i] [note]1[/note]father the devil, and you want to do the desires of your father. He was a [xref]b[/xref]murderer from the beginning and does not stand in the truth, because there is no [xref]c[/xref]truth in him. When he speaks the lie, [xref]d[/xref]he speaks [i]it[/i] out of his own [note]2[/note][i]possessions;[/i] for he is a liar and the [note]3[/note]father of it.
verse.note: Because the devil is the father of sinners, sinners are the children of the devil ([link]1 John 3:10[/link]). The devil is the old serpent ([link]Rev. 12:9[/link]; [link]20:2[/link]), and sinners also are serpents, the generation of vipers ([link]Matt. 23:33[/link]; [link]3:7[/link]). Hence, they need the Lord in the form of the serpent to be lifted up for them on the cross ([link]3:14[/link]) to save them not only from sin but also from the source of sin, the devil ([link]Heb. 2:14[/link]).

The Lord's word here revealed that in the devil, the father of lies, there is a particular wicked thing that caused him to become the source of sin. This thing is something of his own, his private possession, and it is something that other creatures do not have.

Or, father of lies. Since the devil is the father of liars, he is the source of sin. The divine element of God, working as life and light within man, sets man free from the slavery of sin. But the evil element of the devil, working as sin through death and darkness within man, enslaves man to sin. The devil's nature is a lie and brings in death and darkness. With darkness is falsehood, the opposite of the truth.

verse.text: But because I speak the [xref]a[/xref]truth, you do not believe Me.
Which of you convicts Me of sin? Since I speak truth, why do you not believe Me?
He who is of God hears the [note]1[/note]words of God; for this [i]reason[/i] you do not hear [i]them,[/i] because you are not of God.
verse.note: See note [link]63[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 6[/link].

verse.text: The Jews answered and said to Him, Have we not spoken well [i]in saying[/i] that You are a [xref]a[/xref]Samaritan and [xref]b[/xref]have a demon?
Jesus answered, I do not have a demon, but I honor My Father, and you [xref]a[/xref]dishonor Me.
But [xref]a[/xref]I do not seek My glory; there is One who seeks [i]glory for Me[/i] and judges.
Truly, truly, I say to you, If anyone [xref]a[/xref]keeps My word, he shall by no means see [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]death forever.
verse.note: In the principle set forth in [link]ch. 2[/link], this also is the changing of death into life.

verse.text: The Jews therefore said to Him, Now we know that You [xref]a[/xref]have a demon. Abraham died, and the prophets [i]too;[/i] yet You say, If anyone keeps My word, he shall by no means [xref]b[/xref]taste death forever.
Are You greater than our father Abraham, who died? The prophets died too. Who are You making Yourself?
Jesus answered, [xref]a[/xref]If I glorify Myself, My glory is nothing; it is [xref]b[/xref]My Father who glorifies Me, of whom you say that He is your God.

Yet [xref]a[/xref]you have not [note]1[/note]known Him, but [xref]b[/xref]I [note]1[/note]know Him. And if I say that I do not know Him, I will be like you, [xref]c[/xref]a liar; but I do know Him and I keep His word.
verse.note: In this verse two Greek words are used for [i]know:[/i] the first denotes the outward, objective knowledge; the second refers to the inward, subjective consciousness. The Lord Jesus told the Pharisees that they had not known God the Father, even in the outward, objective knowledge, but that He knew the Father in the inward, subjective consciousness.

verse.text: Your father Abraham exulted that he would see My day, and he saw [i]it[/i] and rejoiced.
The Jews then said to Him, You are not yet fifty years old, and have You seen Abraham?
Jesus said to them, Truly, truly, I say to you, [xref]a[/xref]Before Abraham came into being, [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]I am.
verse.note: The Lord as the great I Am is the eternal, ever-existing God. Hence, He was before Abraham and is greater than Abraham ([link]v. 53[/link]).

verse.text: So they [xref]a[/xref]picked up stones to throw at Him, but Jesus was hidden and went out of the temple.
And as He passed by, He saw [note]1[/note]a man [note]2[/note]blind from birth.
verse.note: This case is further proof that the religion of law (see note [link]14[sup]1[/sup][/link]) could not in any way help a blind man. But the Lord Jesus, as the light of the world, imparted sight to him in the way of life ([link]10:10b[/link], [link]28[/link]).

Blindness, like sin in the previous chapter, is a matter of death. A dead person surely is blind. "The god of this age has blinded the thoughts of the unbelievers." Hence, they need "the illumination of the gospel of the glory of Christ" to shine on them ([link]2 Cor. 4:4[/link]) "to open their eyes, to turn them from darkness to light and from the authority of Satan to God" ([link]Acts 26:18[/link]). In the principle set forth in [link]ch. 2[/link], this also is the changing of death into life.

verse.text: And His disciples asked Him, saying, Rabbi, [note]1[/note]who sinned, this man or his parents, that he would be born blind?
verse.note: This question, like those in [link]4:20-25[/link] and [link]8:3-5[/link], was a matter of yes or no, which belongs to the tree of knowledge, the result of which is death ([link]Gen. 2:17[/link]). But the Lord's answer in [link]v. 3[/link] pointed them to Himself, the One who is the tree of life, which results in life ([link]Gen. 2:9[/link]).

verse.text: Jesus answered, Neither has this man sinned nor his parents, but [i]he was born so,[/i] that the works of God might be manifested in him.
We must work the works of Him who sent Me while it is [xref]a[/xref]day; night is coming when no one can work.
While I am in the world, I am the [xref]a[/xref]light of the world.
When He had said this, He [xref]a[/xref]spat on the ground and made clay of the [note]1[/note]spittle and anointed his eyes with the clay,
verse.note: Clay here, as in [link]Rom. 9:21[/link], signifies humanity. Spittle here, as something that proceeds out of the mouth of the Lord ([link]Matt. 4:4[/link]), signifies the Lord's words, which are Spirit and are life ([link]6:63[/link]). The Lord's making clay of the spittle signifies the mingling of humanity with the Lord's living word, which is the Spirit. The word [i]anointed[/i] proves this, because the Lord's Spirit is the anointing Spirit ([link]Luke 4:18[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 1:21-22[/link]; [link]1 John 2:27[/link]). Here the Lord anointed the blind eyes with the clay made of His spittle, that they might have sight. This signifies that by the anointing of the mingling of the Lord's word (which is His Spirit) with our humanity, our eyes, which were blinded by Satan, can have sight.

verse.text: And He said to him, Go, [note]1[/note]wash in the pool of [xref]a[/xref]Siloam (which is interpreted, [note]2[/note]Sent). [note]3[/note]He went therefore and washed and came [i]away[/i] seeing.
verse.note: Here to wash is to cleanse away the clay. This signifies the washing away of our old humanity, as experienced in baptism ([link]Rom. 6:3-4[/link], [link]6[/link]).
See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

His going and washing indicates that he obeyed the life-giving word of the Lord. So he received sight. If he had not gone to wash off the clay after having been anointed with it, the clay would have blinded him even more. Our obedience to the Lord's anointing cleanses us and brings us sight.

verse.text: The neighbors then and those who previously saw him as a beggar said, Is not this the one who used to sit and beg?
Some said, This is he. Others said, No, but he is like him. He said, I am [i]the one.[/i]
They said then to him, How then were your eyes opened?
He answered, The man called Jesus made clay and anointed my eyes, and said to me, Go to the [i]pool[/i] of Siloam and wash. I went therefore and washed, and I received my sight.
And they said to him, Where is He? He said, I do not know.
They brought him who was once blind to the Pharisees.
Now it was the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Sabbath, on which day Jesus made the clay and opened his eyes.
verse.note: It seems that the Lord again purposely did a sign on the Sabbath to expose the vanity of religious ritual. In any case, this strengthened religion's opposition, for He had already done a sign on the Sabbath ([link]5:10[/link], [link]16[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Again therefore the Pharisees also asked him how he received his sight. And he said to them, He put clay on my eyes, and I washed, and I see.

Then some of the Pharisees said, This man is not from God, because He does [xref]a[/xref]not keep the Sabbath. But others said, How can a man [i]who is[/i] a sinner do such [xref]b[/xref]signs? And there was [xref]c[/xref]a division among them.
Then they said to the blind man again, What do you say about Him, in that He opened your eyes? And he said, He is a prophet.
The Jews then did not believe concerning him that he had been blind and had received his sight, until they called the parents of him who had received his sight
And asked them, saying, Is this your son, of whom you say that he was born blind? How then does he now see?
Then his parents answered [i]them[/i] and said, We know that this is our son and that he was born blind.
But how he now sees, we do not know; or who opened his eyes, we do not know. Ask him; he is of age; he will speak for himself.

His parents said these things because they [xref]a[/xref]feared the Jews, for the Jews had already agreed that if anyone confessed Him [i]to be the[/i] Christ, he should be [xref]b[/xref]put out of the synagogue.
Because of this his parents said, He is of age; question him.
Therefore a second time they called the man who had been blind, and said to him, [xref]a[/xref]Give glory to God; we know that this man is a sinner.
Then he answered, Whether [i]or not[/i] He is a sinner, I do not know; one thing I do know, that though I was blind, now I see.
They said then to him, What did He do to you? How did He open your eyes?
He answered them, [xref]a[/xref]I told you already and you did not hear. Why do you want to hear [i]it[/i] again? Do you also want to become His disciples?
And they reviled him and said, You are His disciple; but [xref]a[/xref]we are disciples of Moses.
We know that God has spoken to Moses, but as for this man, [xref]a[/xref]we do not know where He is from.
The man answered and said to them, Why here is an amazing thing, that you do not know where He is from, and [i]yet[/i] He opened my eyes!
[xref]a[/xref]We know that God does not hear sinners, but if anyone is God-fearing and does His will, He hears him.
[note]1[/note]Since time began it has never been heard that anyone opened the eyes of one born blind.
verse.note: Lit., from the age; i.e., from eternity.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]If this man were not [note]1[/note]from God, He could do nothing.
verse.note: See note [link]14[sup]5[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: They answered and said to him, You were wholly born in [xref]a[/xref]sins, and you are teaching us? And they [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]cast him out.
verse.note: To cast him out was to excommunicate, to ostracize, him from the Jewish synagogue. This was to put him out of the sheepfold, as spoken by the Lord in [link]10:3-4[/link]. Religion's persecution of the Lord's called one did nothing but fulfill what the Lord intended for him.

verse.text: Jesus heard that they had [xref]a[/xref]cast him out, and He found him and said, Do you believe into the [note]1[/note]Son of God?
verse.note: Some ancient authorities read, Son of Man.

verse.text: He answered and said, And who is He, [xref]a[/xref]Lord, that I may believe into Him?
Jesus said to him, You have both seen Him, and [xref]a[/xref]He is the One speaking with you.
And he said, Lord, I believe; and he [xref]a[/xref]worshipped Him.
And Jesus said, For [xref]a[/xref]judgment I have come into this world, that [xref]b[/xref]those who do not see may see, and that [xref]c[/xref]those who see may become blind.
[i]Some[/i] of the Pharisees who were with Him heard these things and said to Him, We are not [xref]a[/xref]blind also, are we?
Jesus said to them, If you were blind, you would [xref]a[/xref]not have sin; but now [i]that[/i] you say, We see; your sin remains.

Truly, truly, I say to you, He who does not enter through the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]door into the [note]2[/note]sheepfold, but climbs up from somewhere else, he is a [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]thief and a robber;
verse.note: See note [link]9[sup]1[/sup][/link]; so in the succeeding verses.
The sheepfold signifies the law, or Judaism as the religion of the law, in which God's chosen people were kept and guarded in custody until Christ came.
Thieves and robbers ([link]v. 8[/link]) signify those who came into Judaism, but not through Christ.

verse.text: But he who enters through the [xref]a[/xref]door is the [xref]b[/xref]shepherd of the sheep.
To him the doorkeeper opens, and the [note]1[/note]sheep [xref]a[/xref]hear his voice; and he calls his own sheep by name and leads them [xref]b[/xref]out.
verse.note: The blind man who received sight in the previous chapter was such a sheep. He was led by the Lord out of the Judaism-fold. Hence, this chapter is a continuation of [link]ch. 9[/link].

verse.text: When he puts forth all his own, he goes before them, and the sheep [xref]a[/xref]follow him because they know his [xref]b[/xref]voice.
But they will by no means follow a stranger, but will flee from him, because they do not know the voice of strangers.
This [xref]a[/xref]parable Jesus spoke to them, but they did not know what those things meant that He spoke to them.
Jesus therefore said to them again, Truly, truly, I say to you that I am the [xref]a[/xref]door of the sheep.
All who came before Me are [xref]a[/xref]thieves and robbers, but the sheep did not hear them.
I am the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]door; if anyone enters through Me, he shall be saved and shall go in and go out and shall find [note]2[/note]pasture.
verse.note: Christ is the door not only for God's elect to enter into the custody of the law, as did Moses, David, Isaiah, and Jeremiah in the Old Testament time, before Christ came, but also for God's chosen people, such as Peter, John, James, and Paul, to come out of the fold of the law now that Christ has come. Thus, the Lord indicated here that He is the door not only through which God's elect may go in but also through which God's chosen people may go out.

The pasture here signifies Christ as the feeding place for the sheep. When the pasture is not available (e.g., in the wintertime or at night), the sheep must be kept in the fold. When the pasture is ready, there is no further need for the sheep to remain in the fold. To be kept in the fold is transitional and temporary. To be in the pasture enjoying its riches is final and permanent. Before Christ came, the law was a ward, and being under the law was transitional. Now that Christ has come, all God's chosen people must come out of the law and come into Him to enjoy Him as their pasture ([link]Gal. 3:23-25[/link]; [link]4:3-5[/link]). This should be final and permanent. Because they did not have such a revelation, the leaders in Judaism considered the law, on which Judaism was based, as permanent. As a result, they missed Christ and could not participate in Him as their pasture.

verse.text: The thief does not come except to steal and kill and destroy; I have come that they may [xref]a[/xref]have [note]1[/note]life and may have [i]it[/i] abundantly.
verse.note: Gk. [i]zoe.[/i] This word is used in the New Testament for the eternal, divine life.

verse.text: I am the good [xref]a[/xref]Shepherd; the good Shepherd [xref]b[/xref]lays down His [note]1[/note]life for the sheep.
verse.note: Gk. [i]psuche,[/i] soul; i.e., soul-life, and so in the succeeding verses. As a man, the Lord has the psuche life, the human life, and as God, He has the zoe life, the divine life. He laid down His soul, His psuche life, His human life, to accomplish redemption for His sheep ([link]vv. 15[/link], [link]17-18[/link]) that they may share His zoe life, His divine life ([link]v. 10b[/link]), the eternal life ([link]v. 28[/link]), by which they can be formed into one flock under Himself as the one Shepherd. As the good Shepherd, He feeds His sheep with the divine life in this way and for this purpose.

verse.text: He who is a hireling and not the shepherd, whose own the sheep are not, sees the wolf coming and leaves the sheep and flees; and the wolf snatches them and scatters [i]them.[/i]
[i]He flees[/i] because he is a hireling and it does not matter to him concerning the sheep.
I am the good [xref]a[/xref]Shepherd, and [xref]b[/xref]I know My own, and [xref]c[/xref]My own know Me,
Even as the [xref]a[/xref]Father knows Me and I know the Father; and I [xref]b[/xref]lay down My life for the sheep.

And I have [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]other sheep, which are not of this fold; I must lead them also, and they shall hear My voice, and there shall be [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]one flock, one [xref]c[/xref]Shepherd.
verse.note: The other sheep are the Gentile believers ([link]Acts 11:18[/link]).

The one flock signifies the one church, the one Body of Christ ([link]Eph. 2:14-16[/link]; [link]3:6[/link]), brought forth by the Lord's eternal, divine life, which He imparted into His members through His death ([link]vv. 10-18[/link]). The fold is Judaism, which is of letter and regulation, and the flock is the church, which is of life and spirit.

verse.text: For this [i]reason[/i] the [xref]a[/xref]Father loves Me, because [xref]b[/xref]I lay down My life that I may take it again.

No one takes it away from Me, but I [xref]a[/xref]lay it down of Myself. I have authority to lay it down, and I have authority to [xref]b[/xref]take it again. This commandment I received from My Father.
[xref]a[/xref]A division again took place among the Jews because of these words.
And many of them said, He [xref]a[/xref]has a demon and is [xref]b[/xref]insane. Why do you listen to Him?
Others said, These are not the words of one [i]who is[/i] demon-possessed. Can a demon [xref]a[/xref]open the eyes of the blind?
At that time the [note]1[/note]Feast of the Dedication occurred in Jerusalem, [i]and[/i] it was winter.
verse.note: From 170 B.C. to 168 B.C., Antiochus Epiphanes, king of Syria, invaded Jerusalem and looted the temple. Moreover, on December 25, 168 B.C., he sacrificed a sow on the altar and set up an image in the temple, thus defiling and damaging the temple. Three years later, in 165 B.C., Judas Maccabeus, a strong man of Judah, purified and restored the altar and the temple. He set December 25 — the day on which the altar and the temple had been defiled — as the beginning of a sacred feast that was to have eight consecutive days of rejoicing to celebrate the great achievement of the purification and restoration of the altar and the temple. This sacred feast is the Feast of the Dedication mentioned here.

verse.text: And Jesus was walking in the temple in the [xref]a[/xref]portico of Solomon.
The Jews therefore surrounded Him and said to Him, How long will You hold our soul in suspense? If You are the Christ, tell us [xref]a[/xref]plainly.
Jesus answered them, I told you, and you do not believe. The [xref]a[/xref]works which I do [note]1[/note]in My Father's name, these testify concerning Me;
verse.note: See note [link]43[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 5[/link].

verse.text: But you do not believe, because you are not of My sheep.
My sheep [xref]a[/xref]hear My voice, and [xref]b[/xref]I know them, and they [xref]c[/xref]follow Me;
And I give to them [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]eternal life, and they shall by no means perish forever, and [xref]b[/xref]no one shall [xref]c[/xref]snatch them out of [note]1[/note]My hand.
verse.note: Eternal life (see note [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link]) is for the believers' living. The Father's hand, by which He chooses in His love according to His purpose ([link]17:23[/link]; [link]6:38-39[/link]), and the Son's hand, by which He saves by His grace for the fulfillment of the Father's purpose ([link]1:14[/link]; [link]6:37[/link]), both of which have the keeping power, are for the believers' protection. Eternal life will never run out, and the hands of the Father and the Son will never fail. Hence, the believers are eternally secure and will never perish.

verse.text: My Father, who has given [i]them[/i] to Me, is greater than all, and no one can [xref]a[/xref]snatch [i]them[/i] out of My [note]1[/note]Father's hand.
verse.note: See note [link]28[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]I and the Father are [xref]a[/xref]one.
verse.note: Here the Lord asserted His deity, that is, that He is God ([link]v. 33[/link]; [link]5:18[/link]; [link]1:1[/link]; [link]20:28[/link]; [link]1 John 5:20[/link]; [link]Phil. 2:6[/link]).

verse.text: The Jews again [xref]a[/xref]took up stones that they might stone Him.
Jesus answered them, I have shown you many good works from the Father; for which of these works are you stoning Me?
The Jews answered Him, We are not stoning You for a good work, but for blasphemy, and because You, being a man, are making Yourself [xref]a[/xref]God.
Jesus answered them, Is it not written in your law, "I said, [xref]a[/xref]You are gods"?
If He said they [i]were[/i] gods, to whom the word of God came, and the Scripture cannot be broken,
Do you say of Him whom the Father [xref]a[/xref]has sanctified and [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]sent into the world, You are blaspheming, because I said, [xref]c[/xref]I am the Son of God?
verse.note: See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: If I do not do the [xref]a[/xref]works of My Father, do not believe Me;

But if I do [i]them,[/i] even if you do not believe Me, [xref]a[/xref]believe the works so that you may come to know and continue to know that the [xref]b[/xref]Father [i]is[/i] in Me and I [i]am[/i] in the Father.
Then they sought again to [xref]a[/xref]seize Him, yet He went forth out of their hand.
And [note]1[/note]He went away again [xref]a[/xref]across the Jordan, to the place where John was baptizing at first, and He remained there.
verse.note: At this point the Lord left the temple and went to the very place where John the Baptist had given the New Testament testimony concerning Him. This signifies that He abandoned Judaism and came to the new ground, where many believed into Him.

verse.text: And many came to Him and said, John did no sign, but [xref]a[/xref]all the things John said concerning this man were true.
And [xref]a[/xref]many believed into Him there.
Now there was a certain man who was sick, Lazarus from [note]1[/note]Bethany, of the village of Mary and her sister Martha.
verse.note: The Lord had left Judaism and had come to a place from which He could proceed to Bethany, which was an early miniature of the church.

verse.text: It was [i]that[/i] Mary who [xref]a[/xref]anointed the Lord with ointment and wiped His feet with her hair, whose brother Lazarus was sick.
The sisters therefore sent to Him saying, Lord, behold, [i]he[/i] whom You love is sick.
But when Jesus heard [i]it,[/i] He said, This sickness is not unto death, but for the [xref]a[/xref]glory of God, in order that the Son of God may be glorified through it.
Now Jesus loved Martha and her sister and Lazarus.
When therefore He heard that he was sick, He remained at that time in the place where He was for two days.
Then after this He said to the disciples, Let us go into Judea again.
The disciples [note]1[/note]said to Him, Rabbi, the Jews were just now seeking to [xref]a[/xref]stone You, and You are going there again?
verse.note: In the eight foregoing cases, in [link]chs. 3-10[/link], religion was the main frustration to and opponent of life. Here, outside religion and on the new ground, life was going to raise a dead person. Here life no longer faced religion with its rituals, but it was frustrated by many human opinions: the disciples' opinions ([link]vv. 8-16[/link]), Martha's opinion ([link]vv. 21-28[/link]), Mary's opinion ([link]vv. 32-33[/link]), the Jews' opinion ([link]vv. 36-38[/link]), and, again, Martha's opinion ([link]vv. 39-40[/link]). Opinions, which come from knowledge, belong to the tree of knowledge, but the Lord here was actually the tree of life for people to enjoy.

verse.text: Jesus answered, Are there not twelve hours in the day? If anyone walks in the [xref]a[/xref]day, he does not stumble, because he sees the [xref]b[/xref]light of this world.
But if anyone walks in the night, he stumbles, because the light is not in him.
He said these things, and after this He said to them, Our friend Lazarus has fallen [xref]a[/xref]asleep; but I am going that I may wake him out of sleep.
The disciples then said to Him, Lord, if he has fallen asleep, he will [note]1[/note]recover.
verse.note: Lit., be saved.

verse.text: But Jesus had spoken about his death, but they thought that He was speaking about taking rest in sleep.
So Jesus then told them plainly, Lazarus has [note]1[/note]died.
verse.note: In the Lord's salvation He does not merely heal the sick; He also gives life to the dead. Hence, He remained two days until the sick one had died ([link]v. 6[/link]). The Lord does not reform or regulate people — He regenerates people and raises them out of death. Hence, the first of the nine cases in [link]chs. 3-11[/link] was a case of regeneration, and the last was a case of resurrection, revealing that all the aspects of Christ as life to us, as unveiled in the other seven cases, are in the principle of regeneration and resurrection. This last case was the actual changing of death into life.

verse.text: And I rejoice for your sakes that I was not there, so that you may believe; but let us go to him.
Then Thomas, who is called [note]1[/note]Didymus, said to his fellow disciples, Let us also go, that we may die with Him.
verse.note: I.e., Twin.

verse.text: Then when Jesus came, He found that he had already been in the tomb [xref]a[/xref]four days.
Now Bethany was near Jerusalem, about [note]1[/note]fifteen stadia away.
verse.note: I.e., about two miles.

verse.text: And many of the Jews had come to Martha and Mary to console them concerning their brother.
Martha therefore, when she heard that Jesus was coming, went to meet Him; but Mary sat in the house.
Then Martha said to Jesus, Lord, [xref]a[/xref]if You had been here, my brother would not have died.
But even now I know that whatever You ask of God, God will give You.
Jesus said to her, Your brother will rise again.
Martha said to Him, I know that he will rise again in the [xref]a[/xref]resurrection [note]1[/note]in the last day.
verse.note: The Lord told Martha, "Your brother will rise again" ([link]v. 23[/link]). This meant that the Lord would raise him immediately; but Martha expounded the Lord's word so as to postpone the present resurrection to the last day. What an exposition of the divine word! Some of the knowledge of fundamental teaching is truly destructive and frustrates people from enjoying the Lord's present resurrection life.

verse.text: Jesus said to her, I am the resurrection and the [xref]a[/xref]life; he who believes into Me, even if he should die, shall [xref]b[/xref]live;
And everyone who lives and believes into Me shall by [xref]a[/xref]no means die forever. Do you believe this?
She said to Him, Yes, Lord; I have [note]1[/note]believed that [xref]a[/xref]You are the Christ, the Son of God, He who [xref]b[/xref]comes into the world.
verse.note: The Lord said to Martha, "I am the resurrection and the life," and asked her, "Do you believe this?" She answered, "Yes, Lord; I have believed that You are the Christ, the Son of God." Her reply did not answer the Lord's question. Her old, preoccupying knowledge covered her, preventing her from understanding the Lord's new word. Man's old knowledge and old opinions are coverings that keep him from knowing clearly the Lord's new revelation.

verse.text: And when she had said this, she went away and called Mary her sister secretly, saying, The Teacher is here and [note]1[/note]is calling you.
verse.note: This might have been Martha's opinion and not the Lord's command.

verse.text: And she, when she heard [i]this,[/i] rose quickly and came to Him.
Now Jesus had not yet come into the village, but was still in the place where Martha met Him.

The Jews then who were with her in the house and were consoling her, when they saw that Mary rose up quickly and went out, followed her, supposing that she was going to the tomb to [note]1[/note]weep there.
verse.note: Lit., wail.

verse.text: Then Mary, when she came to where Jesus was, saw Him and fell at His feet, saying to Him, Lord, [xref]a[/xref]if You had been here, my brother would not have died.

Then Jesus, when He saw her [note]1[/note]weeping and the [xref]a[/xref]Jews who came with her [note]1[/note]weeping, was [xref]b[/xref]moved with indignation in His spirit and was [xref]c[/xref]troubled,
verse.note: Lit., wailing.

verse.text: And He said, Where have you put him? They said to Him, Lord, come and see.
Jesus [note]1[/note]wept.
verse.note: This word differs from the word translated [i]weep[/i] and [i]weeping[/i] in [link]vv. 31[/link] and [link]33[/link]. Here it means [i]to shed tears, to weep silently.[/i] This is the only time the word is used in the New Testament.

verse.text: The Jews then said, Behold how He [xref]a[/xref]loved him!
But some of them said, Could not He who [xref]a[/xref]opened the eyes of the blind man also have caused that this man would not die?
Jesus therefore, moved with indignation again in Himself, came to the tomb. Now it was a cave, and a stone was lying against it.
Jesus said, Take away the stone. Martha, the sister of him who was deceased, said to Him, Lord, by now he smells, for [i]it is[/i] the [xref]a[/xref]fourth day [i]that[/i] he is [i]there.[/i]
Jesus said to her, Did I not tell you that if you believe you will see the [xref]a[/xref]glory of God?
Then they [note]1[/note]took the stone away. And Jesus [xref]a[/xref]lifted up His eyes and said, [xref]b[/xref]Father, I thank You that You have heard Me.
verse.note: Their taking the stone away and loosing Lazarus were their submitting to and cooperating with the resurrection life.

verse.text: And I knew that You always hear Me; but because of the crowd standing around, I said [i]it,[/i] that they may [xref]a[/xref]believe that You have [note]1[/note]sent Me.
verse.note: See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: And when He had said these things, He cried out with a loud voice, Lazarus, come out!
And he who had died came out, [xref]a[/xref]bound hand and foot with cloths, and [xref]b[/xref]his face was bound about with a handkerchief. Jesus said to them, Loose him and let him go.
Many of the [xref]a[/xref]Jews therefore who had come to Mary and beheld the things that He did believed into Him.
But some of them went away to the Pharisees and told them the things that Jesus did.
Then the chief priests and the Pharisees assembled a council and said, What do we do? For this man is doing many [xref]a[/xref]signs.
If we let Him do so, all will believe into Him, and the Romans will come and take away both our place and [i]our[/i] nation.
But a certain one of them, Caiaphas, who was [xref]a[/xref]high priest that year, said to them, You know nothing at all,
Nor do you take account [i]of the fact[/i] that [xref]a[/xref]it is expedient for you that one man die for the people and [i]that[/i] not the whole nation perish.
But this he did not say from himself, but being [xref]a[/xref]high priest that year, he prophesied that Jesus was to die for the nation,
And not for the nation only, but that He might also [note]1[/note]gather into [xref]a[/xref]one the children of God who are scattered abroad.
verse.note: The phrase [i]gather into one the children of God[/i] mentioned in this chapter implies that not only the Lord's death but also the Lord's resurrection life are for the building up of God's children. By His death the Lord released His life so that it could be imparted into those who believe into Him. This life is experienced by us in His resurrection. It is in the Lord's resurrection that we grow together into one by His life to become His Body.

verse.text: From that day therefore they [xref]a[/xref]took counsel to kill Him.
Jesus therefore no longer [xref]a[/xref]walked openly among the Jews, but went away from there to the region near the wilderness, into a city called Ephraim, and there He remained with the disciples.
Now the [xref]a[/xref]Passover of the Jews was near, and many went up to Jerusalem out of the country before the Passover in order to [xref]b[/xref]purify themselves.
They then sought Jesus, and said to one another as they stood in the temple, What do you think? That He will not, by any means, come to the feast?
Now the chief priests and the Pharisees had given orders that if anyone knew where He was, he should disclose it, so that they might arrest Him.
Then Jesus, six days before the [xref]a[/xref]Passover, came to [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Bethany, where Lazarus was, [xref]c[/xref]whom Jesus had raised from the dead.
verse.note: [i]Bethany[/i] means [i]house of affliction.[/i] At this point the Lord was outside Judaism. Through His resurrection life He had gained a house in Bethany where He could feast and have rest and satisfaction. This house of feasting was a miniature of the church life and depicted the situation of the church: (1) produced by the resurrection life — Lazarus ([link]11:43-44[/link]); (2) composed of cleansed sinners — Simon the leper ([link]Mark 14:3[/link]); (3) outwardly afflicted — Bethany; (4) inwardly feasting in and with the presence of the Lord ([link]v. 2[/link]); (5) having more sisters than brothers ([link]vv. 2-3[/link]); (6) having members with different functions: serving — Martha, testifying — Lazarus, and loving — Mary ([link]vv. 2-3[/link]); (7) spotted by the false one — Judas ([link]v. 4[/link]); (8) persecuted by religion ([link]v. 10[/link]); (9) being a test and exposing people ([link]vv. 6[/link], [link]10[/link]); and (10) bringing in many believers ([link]v. 11[/link]).

verse.text: Therefore they made Him a supper there; and [xref]a[/xref]Martha served, but Lazarus was one of the ones reclining [i]at table[/i] with Him.

Then [xref]a[/xref]Mary took a [note]1[/note]pound of ointment, of very valuable pure nard, and anointed the feet of Jesus, and wiped His feet with her hair; and the [note]2[/note]house was filled with the fragrance of the ointment.
verse.note: A unit of weight at that time, about twelve ounces.
This was the house of Simon the leper ([link]Mark 14:3[/link]).

verse.text: But [xref]a[/xref]Judas Iscariot, one of His disciples, who was about to betray Him, said,
Why was this ointment not sold for three hundred [note]1[/note]denarii and given to the poor?
verse.note: See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 6[/link].

verse.text: But he said this not because it mattered to him concerning the poor, but because he was a thief, and [xref]a[/xref]holding the purse, carried off what was put into [i]it.[/i]
Then [note]1[/note]Jesus said, Leave her alone; she has reserved it for the day of My burial.
verse.note: The Lord Jesus was a test to all those around Him. The chief priests and Pharisees conspired to kill Him ([link]11:47[/link], [link]53[/link], [link]57[/link]), Simon the leper prepared his house for Him ([link]Matt. 26:6[/link]), Martha served Him, Lazarus testified concerning Him, Mary loved Him ([link]vv. 2-3[/link]), Judas was about to betray Him ([link]v. 4[/link]), and many believed into Him ([link]v. 11[/link]). The Lord is the center of God's economy and is a sign set up by God ([link]Luke 2:34[/link]). Anyone who contacts Him will inevitably be tested and exposed.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]For the poor you always have with you, but you do not always have Me.
Then a great crowd of the Jews found out that He was there, and they came, not because of Jesus only, but that they might also see Lazarus, [xref]a[/xref]whom He had raised from the dead.
And the chief priests took counsel to kill Lazarus also,
Because on account of him [xref]a[/xref]many of the Jews went away and believed into Jesus.
On the next day, [xref]a[/xref]the great crowd who had come to the [xref]b[/xref]feast, when they heard that Jesus was coming into Jerusalem,

Took the branches of the palm trees and went out to meet Him, and cried out, [note]1[/note]Hosanna! [xref]a[/xref]Blessed is He who comes in the name of the Lord, even the [xref]b[/xref]King of Israel!
verse.note: A Hebrew expression meaning [i]do save, we pray[/i] ([link]Psa. 118:25[/link]).

verse.text: And Jesus, having found a young donkey, sat on it, as it is written,
[xref]a[/xref]"Fear not, daughter of Zion; behold, your King comes, sitting on a donkey's colt."

These things His disciples did not understand at first, but when Jesus was [xref]a[/xref]glorified, then they [xref]b[/xref]remembered that these things were written of Him and [i]that[/i] they had done these things to Him.
The crowd therefore that was with Him when He called Lazarus out of the tomb and raised him from the dead testified.
For this [i]reason[/i] the crowd also went and met Him, because they heard that He had done this sign.
The Pharisees then said to one another, You see that you are not doing anything worthwhile; behold, the world has gone after Him.
And there were some Greeks among those who went up to [xref]a[/xref]worship at the feast.
These then came to [xref]a[/xref]Philip, who was from Bethsaida of Galilee, and asked him, saying, Sir, we wish to see Jesus.
Philip came and told Andrew; Andrew came, and Philip [i]too,[/i] and they told Jesus.
And Jesus answered them, saying, The [xref]a[/xref]hour has come for the Son of Man to be [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]glorified.
verse.note: For Jesus as the Son of Man to be glorified was for Him to be resurrected, that is, to have His divine element, His divine life, released from within the shell of His humanity to produce many believers in resurrection ([link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link]), just as a grain of wheat ([link]v. 24[/link]) has its life element released when it falls into the ground and grows up out of the ground to bear much fruit, that is, to bring forth many grains. See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 17[/link].

verse.text: Truly, truly, I say to you, [xref]a[/xref]Unless the grain of wheat [note]1[/note]falls into the ground and dies, it abides alone; but if it dies, it bears [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]much fruit.
verse.note: At this point, according to the worldly view, Jesus was in His golden time. A great crowd of the Jews esteemed Him highly and welcomed Him warmly because of the resurrection of Lazarus ([link]vv. 12-19[/link]), and even the Greeks were seeking after Him ([link]vv. 20-22[/link]). But He preferred to fall as a grain of wheat into the ground and die that He might produce many grains for the church.

This "much fruit" became Christ's increase in resurrection. This increase is the glory into which Christ entered through His death and resurrection ([link]Luke 24:26[/link]). The portion from [link]v. 23[/link] of this chapter to the end of [link]ch. 17[/link] is a discourse on the mystery of this glory. Christ had the glory with God ([link]17:5[/link]). His incarnation caused His divine glory to be concealed in His flesh. Through His death and resurrection His glory was released, producing many grains, which become His increase as the expression of His glory. What was spoken in [link]vv. 23[/link], [link]28[/link]; [link]13:31-32[/link]; [link]14:13[/link]; [link]15:8[/link]; [link]16:14[/link]; and [link]17:1[/link], [link]4[/link], [link]5[/link], [link]10[/link], [link]22[/link], [link]24[/link] is related to this glory. In the Lord's last words to the believers in [link]chs. 14-16[/link], there are three concrete, corporate expressions of this glory: the Father's house (the church) in [link]14:2[/link], the branches of the vine (the constituents of the Body of Christ) in [link]15:1-5[/link], and a newborn corporate man (the new man) in [link]16:21[/link]. All three denote the church, showing that the church is the glorious increase produced by the glorious Christ through His death and resurrection. In this glorious increase, Christ, the Son of God, is glorified, causing God the Father also to be glorified in Christ's glorification, that is, to be fully expressed through the church ([link]Eph. 3:19-21[/link]). This expression needs to be maintained in the oneness of the Triune God. Therefore, the Lord prayed in particular for this matter in His concluding prayer in [link]ch. 17[/link] ([link]17:20-23[/link]). This glorious increase of Christ is the peak of the mystery revealed in the Gospel of John, and its ultimate consummation is the New Jerusalem in Revelation, also written by John. The new holy city will be the aggregate of Christ's increase throughout the generations, and in it Christ's divine glory will be expressed to the uttermost. In the glorifying of God the Son, God the Father also will obtain eternal, matchless glory, which will be His full expression in eternity. Thus His eternal economy will be fulfilled for eternity.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]He who loves his [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]soul-life loses it; and he who [xref]c[/xref]hates his [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]soul-life in this world shall keep it unto [note]2[/note]eternal life.
verse.note: The same Greek word as for [i]life[/i] in [link]10:11[/link], [link]15[/link], [link]17[/link]. The Lord, as a grain of wheat that fell into the ground, lost His soul-life through death that He might release His eternal life in resurrection to the many grains. As the many grains, we also must lose our soul-life through death that we may enjoy eternal life in resurrection. This is to follow Him that we may serve Him and walk with Him on this way, the way of losing our soul-life and living in His resurrection, as mentioned in [link]v. 26[/link].
See note [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].

verse.text: If anyone serves Me, let him follow Me; and where I am, there also My servant will be. If anyone serves Me, the Father will honor him.

Now is [xref]a[/xref]My [note]1[/note]soul troubled; and what shall I say? Father, [xref]b[/xref]save Me out of this [xref]c[/xref]hour. But for [note]2[/note]this [i]reason[/i] I have come to this hour.
verse.note: As a man, the Lord was troubled in His soul because of the death He was about to suffer. Hence, He prayed, "Father, save Me out of this hour." However, it must have been that in His spirit He realized that it was for the glorifying of the Father that He had come to that hour.
This refers to the glorifying of the Father's name in the next verse.

verse.text: Father, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]glorify Your name. Then a [xref]b[/xref]voice came out of heaven: I have both [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]glorified [i]it[/i] and will [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]glorify [i]it[/i] again.
verse.note: To glorify the name of the Father is to cause the Father's divine element to be expressed. The Father's divine element, which is the eternal life, was in the incarnated Son. The shell of the Son's incarnation had to be broken through death that the Father's divine element, the eternal life, might be released and expressed in resurrection, just as the life element of a grain of wheat is released by the breaking of its shell and is expressed by its blossom. This is the glorification of God the Father in the Son. See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 17[/link].

verse.text: The crowd therefore which stood by and heard [i]it[/i] said that there had been thunder; others said, [xref]a[/xref]An angel has spoken to Him.
Jesus answered and said, This voice has not [note]1[/note]come for My sake, but for your sake.
verse.note: Lit., happened.

verse.text: Now is the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]judgment of this [note]2[/note]world; now shall the [xref]b[/xref]ruler of this world be cast out.
verse.note: On the cross the Lord as the Son of Man ([link]v. 23[/link]) was lifted up in the form of the serpent ([link]3:14[/link]), that is, in the likeness of the flesh of sin ([link]Rom. 8:3[/link]). Satan as the old serpent ([link]Rev. 12:9[/link]; [link]20:2[/link]), the ruler of this world, had injected himself into man's flesh. Through His death on the cross in the likeness of the flesh of sin, the Lord destroyed Satan, who is in man's flesh ([link]Heb. 2:14[/link]). By judging Satan ([link]16:11[/link]) in this way, the Lord also judged the world, which is hanging on Satan. Hence, the Lord's being lifted up caused the world to be judged and its ruler, Satan, to be cast out.

The Greek word here means [i]arrangement[/i] (see note [link]15[sup]2[/sup] in 1 John 2[/link]). The world is an evil system arranged systematically by Satan. All the things on the earth, especially those related to mankind, and all the things in the air have been systematized by Satan into his kingdom of darkness to occupy people and frustrate them from accomplishing the purpose of God, and to distract them from the enjoyment of God. This evil system, the kingdom of darkness, was judged when its ruler, Satan, was cast out by the Lord's being crucified in the flesh. See note [link]31[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And I, if I be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]lifted up from the earth, will [xref]b[/xref]draw [xref]c[/xref]all men to Myself.
verse.note: In one aspect, the Lord's death was His falling into the ground, as revealed in [link]v. 24[/link]; in another aspect, it was His being lifted up on the tree ([link]1 Pet. 2:24[/link]). His falling into the ground was to produce the many grains; His being lifted up on the tree was to draw all men to Himself. The many grains produced by His falling into the ground are the "all men" drawn by His being lifted up on the tree.[br][br]In this chapter the Lord's death is revealed not as the redeeming death but as the producing, generating death. By this death His incarnation-shell of humanity was broken that He might accomplish His threefold purpose: (1) the producing of many grains, the drawing of all men to Himself ([link]vv. 24[/link], [link]32[/link]); (2) the releasing of the divine element, the eternal life ([link]vv. 23[/link], [link]28[/link]); and (3) the judging of the world and the casting out of its ruler, Satan ([link]v. 31[/link]). We must experience the Lord's death that we may participate in the threefold purpose that He accomplished.

verse.text: But He said this [xref]a[/xref]signifying by what kind of death He was about to die.

The crowd therefore answered Him, We have heard out of the law that the [xref]a[/xref]Christ abides forever; and how [i]is it that[/i] You say, The Son of Man must be lifted up? Who is this Son of Man?

Jesus then said to them, The light is [xref]a[/xref]still among you a little while. Walk while you have the light so that darkness may not [xref]b[/xref]overcome you; and he who [xref]c[/xref]walks in the darkness does not know where he is going.

While you have the [xref]a[/xref]light, believe into the light, so that you may become [xref]b[/xref]sons of light.[separator]Jesus said these things, and He went away and [xref]c[/xref]was hidden from them.
But though He had done so many signs before them, they did not believe into Him,
That the word of the prophet Isaiah which he said might be fulfilled, [xref]a[/xref]"Lord, who has believed our report? And to whom has the [note]1[/note]arm of the Lord been revealed?"
verse.note: The arm of the Lord is the Lord Jesus Himself.

verse.text: For this [i]reason[/i] they could not believe, because again Isaiah said,
[xref]a[/xref]"He has [note]1[/note]blinded their eyes and He hardened their heart, that they might not see with their eyes and understand with their heart and turn, and I will heal them."
verse.note: These two, blindness and the hardening of the heart, are related; they are a punishment to the unbelieving ones.

verse.text: These things said Isaiah because he [xref]a[/xref]saw [note]1[/note]His glory and spoke concerning Him.
