verse.note: [i]His glory[/i] here confirms that the Lord Jesus is the very God, Jehovah of hosts, whose glory Isaiah saw ([link]Isa. 6:1[/link], [link]3[/link]). This glory was seen and appreciated by Isaiah but was not loved by the Lord's weaker believers ([link]vv. 42-43[/link]).

verse.text: Nevertheless even many of the rulers believed into Him, but because of the Pharisees they did not confess [i]Him,[/i] [xref]a[/xref]so that they would not be [xref]b[/xref]put out of the synagogue;
For they loved the [xref]a[/xref]glory of men more than the [xref]a[/xref]glory of God.
But Jesus [note]1[/note]cried out and said, He who believes into Me does not believe into Me, but [xref]a[/xref]into Him who sent Me;
verse.note: This was the Lord's declaration to the unbelieving religionists. It implied that (1) He was God manifested to man ([link]vv. 44-45[/link]); (2) He came as a light into the world so that by believing into Him man would not remain in darkness ([link]vv. 46[/link], [link]36[/link]); and (3) He came to man with the living words; whoever receives His words has eternal life now and forever, and whoever rejects His words will be judged by His words in the last day ([link]vv. 47-50[/link]).

verse.text: And he who [xref]a[/xref]beholds Me beholds Him who sent Me.
I have come [i]as[/i] a [xref]a[/xref]light into the world, that everyone who believes into Me would not remain in darkness.
And if anyone hears My [note]1[/note]words and does not keep [i]them,[/i] I do not judge him; for I have not come to [xref]a[/xref]judge the world, but to save the world.
verse.note: See note [link]63[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 6[/link]; so in the next verse.

verse.text: He who rejects Me and does not receive My words has one who judges him; the [xref]a[/xref]word which I have spoken, that will judge him in the last day.
For I have not spoken from Myself; but the Father who sent Me, He Himself has [xref]a[/xref]given Me commandment, what to say and what to speak.
And I know that His commandment is [note]1[/note]eternal life. The things therefore that I speak, even [xref]a[/xref]as the Father has said to Me, so I speak.
verse.note: See note [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Now before the [xref]a[/xref]Feast of the Passover, Jesus knowing that His [xref]b[/xref]hour had come for Him to depart out of this world unto the [xref]c[/xref]Father, having loved His own who were in the world, He loved them to the uttermost.
verse.note: In this Gospel, the first section, [link]chs. 1-13[/link], describes how the Lord as God Himself, as the Son of God, came through His incarnation to bring God into man that He might be man's life for the producing of the church. The second section, [link]chs. 14-21[/link], describes how the Lord as the Son of Man went through His death and resurrection to bring man into God that man and God, God and man, might be built together as a mutual abode. This chapter, coming at the end of the first section, is a dividing line and a turning point.

verse.text: And while supper was taking place, the [xref]a[/xref]devil having already put into the heart of Judas Iscariot, [i]the son[/i] of Simon, that he should [xref]b[/xref]betray Him,
[i]Jesus,[/i] knowing that the Father had [xref]a[/xref]given all into His hands and that He had [xref]b[/xref]come forth from God and was going to God,
Rose from supper and [note]1[/note]laid aside His outer garments; and taking a [note]2[/note]towel, He [note]3[/note]girded Himself;
verse.note: The outer garments here signify the Lord's virtues and attributes in His expression. Hence, the laying aside of His outer garments signifies the putting off of what He is in His expression.
From a Latin word denoting a linen towel.
To gird oneself signifies to be bound and restricted with humility (cf. [link]1 Pet. 5:5[/link]).

verse.text: Then He poured [note]1[/note]water into the basin and began to [note]2[/note]wash the disciples' [note]3[/note]feet and to wipe [i]them[/i] with the towel with which He was girded.
verse.note: Water here signifies the Holy Spirit ([link]Titus 3:5[/link]), the word ([link]Eph. 5:26[/link]; [link]John 15:3[/link]), and life ([link]19:34[/link]).

In [link]chs. 1-12[/link] life came and brought forth the church, composed of the regenerated ones. In their spirit the regenerated ones are in God and in the heavenlies, but in their body they are still living in the flesh and walking on the earth. Through their contact with earthly things they often become dirty. This frustrates their fellowship with the Lord and with one another. Hence, there is the need for the washing with the Holy Spirit, the word, and life. This is the washing away of their dirtiness that their fellowship with the Lord and with one another may be maintained; it is not the washing away of their sins by the blood ([link]1 John 1:9[/link]). This is why, after [link]ch. 12[/link], there is a need for such a sign in this chapter. Since this Gospel is a book of signs, what is recorded in this chapter should be considered a sign, having spiritual significance. Foot-washing should not be taken merely in a physical sense, but rather in a spiritual sense.

In ancient times the Jews wore sandals, and since their roads were dusty, their feet easily became dirty. If, when they came to a feast, they sat at the table and stretched out their feet, the dirt and the smell would certainly frustrate the fellowship. Hence, for the feast to be pleasant they needed foot-washing. The Lord washed His disciples' feet to show them that He loved them to the uttermost ([link]v. 1[/link]), and He charged them to do the same to one another in love ([link]vv. 14[/link], [link]34[/link]). Today the world is dirty, and we, the saints, are easily contaminated. For us to maintain pleasant fellowship with the Lord and with one another, we need spiritual foot-washing — with the washing Holy Spirit, the washing word, and the washing life — carried out both by the Lord in His love and by one another in love. This is absolutely necessary in order for us to live in the fellowship of the divine life, which is revealed in John's first Epistle, a continuation of the Gospel of John.

verse.text: He came then to Simon Peter. [i]Peter[/i] said to Him, Lord, do You wash my feet?
Jesus answered and said to him, What I am doing you do not [note]1[/note]know now, but you will [note]1[/note]know after these things.
verse.note: In Greek, [i]know[/i] in the first instance denotes the inward, subjective consciousness; in the second it refers to the outward, objective knowledge. See note [link]55[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 8[/link].

verse.text: Peter said to Him, You shall by no means wash my feet forever. Jesus answered him, Unless I wash you, you have no part with Me.
Simon Peter said to Him, Lord, not my feet only, but also my hands and my head.
Jesus said to him, He who is [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]bathed has no need except to wash his feet, but is wholly [xref]b[/xref]clean; and you are clean, but not all [i]of you.[/i]
verse.note: Bathing here signifies the washing of regeneration ([link]Titus 3:5[/link]; [link]John 3:5[/link]).

verse.text: For He [xref]a[/xref]knew the one betraying Him; for this [i]reason[/i] He said, Not all of you are clean.
Then when He had washed their feet and taken His outer garments and reclined [i]at the table[/i] again, He said to them, Do you know what I have done to you?
You call Me the Teacher and the Lord, and you say rightly, for I am.
If I then, the Lord and the Teacher, have washed your feet, you also ought to wash one another's feet.
For I have given you an [xref]a[/xref]example so that you also may do even as I have done to you.
Truly, truly, I say to you, A [xref]a[/xref]slave is not greater than his master, nor [note]1[/note]one who is sent greater than the one who sends him.
verse.note: [i]One who is sent[/i] is, literally, [i]an apostle.[/i]

verse.text: If you know these things, [xref]a[/xref]blessed are you if you do them.

I do not speak concerning [xref]a[/xref]all of you. I know whom I have [xref]b[/xref]chosen, but that the [xref]c[/xref]Scripture may be fulfilled, [xref]d[/xref]"He who [note]1[/note]eats bread with Me has lifted up his heel against Me."
verse.note: Lit., masticates.

verse.text: From now on I am [xref]a[/xref]telling you before it happens, so that when it happens, you may believe that [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]I am.
verse.note: See note [link]24[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 8[/link].

verse.text: Truly, truly, I say to you, [xref]a[/xref]He who receives whomever I shall send receives Me, and he who receives Me receives Him who sent Me.
When Jesus had said these things, He became troubled in His [xref]a[/xref]spirit, and He testified and said, Truly, truly, I say to you that [xref]b[/xref]one of you will betray Me.
The disciples looked at one another, perplexed over whom He was speaking about.
One of His disciples, [xref]a[/xref]whom Jesus loved, was reclining on Jesus' bosom.
Simon Peter therefore nodded to him to inquire who it might be about whom He was speaking.
Then he, while reclining thus on Jesus' breast, said to Him, Lord, who is it?
Jesus answered, It is he for whom I will dip the morsel and to whom I will give [i]it.[/i] And dipping the morsel, He gave [i]it[/i] to Judas Iscariot, [i]the son[/i] of Simon.
And at that moment, after the morsel, [xref]a[/xref]Satan entered into him. Jesus therefore said to him, What you do, do quickly.
But none of those reclining [i]at table[/i] knew why He said this to him.
For some supposed, since Judas held the purse, that Jesus was saying to him, Buy the things that we have need of for the feast, or that he should give something to the poor.
Therefore having taken the morsel, he went out immediately; and it was night.
Then when he went out, Jesus said, Now has the Son of Man been [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]glorified, and God has been [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]glorified in Him.
verse.note: See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 12[/link].
See note [link]28[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 12[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]If God has been [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]glorified in Him, God will also [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]glorify Him in Himself, and He will [note]3[/note]glorify Him immediately.
verse.note: Some ancient MSS omit the clause, If God has been glorified in Him.
See note [link]28[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 12[/link].
See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 12[/link].

verse.text: Little children, [xref]a[/xref]I am still with you a little while; [xref]b[/xref]you will seek Me, and even as I said to the Jews, [xref]c[/xref]Where I am going, you cannot come, now I say to you also.
A new [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]commandment I give to you, that you [xref]b[/xref]love one another, even as I have loved you, that you also love one another.
verse.note: The Greek word for [i]commandment[/i] here is the same word as in [link]Matt. 5:19[/link] and [link]Rom. 7:8[/link], [link]9[/link], [link]10[/link], [link]11[/link], [link]12[/link], [link]13[/link]. However, in [link]Matt. 5[/link] and [link]Rom. 7[/link] it refers to the old commandments of the law in the Old Testament; here it refers to the new commandment given to us by the Lord in the New Testament. Also in [link]14:15[/link], [link]21[/link]; [link]15:10[/link], [link]12[/link]; [link]1 John 2:3[/link], [link]4[/link], [link]7[/link], [link]8[/link]; [link]3:22[/link], [link]23[/link], [link]24[/link]; [link]4:21[/link]; [link]5:2[/link], [link]3[/link]; [link]2 John 4[/link], [link]5[/link], [link]6[/link], it refers to the new commandment given to us in the New Testament, either by the Lord Jesus or by God. This new commandment is different from the old commandments in the Old Testament.

verse.text: By this shall all men know that you are My disciples, if you have love for one another.
[xref]a[/xref]Simon Peter said to Him, Lord, where are You going? Jesus answered him, [xref]b[/xref]Where I go you cannot follow Me now, but you will [xref]c[/xref]follow later.
Peter said to Him, Lord, why can't I follow You now? I will lay down my [note]1[/note]life for You.
verse.note: Lit., soul, soul-life; so in the next verse.

verse.text: Jesus answered, Will you lay down your life for Me? Truly, truly, I say to you, A [xref]a[/xref]rooster shall by no means crow until you deny Me three times.
[xref]a[/xref]Do not let your heart be troubled; believe into [note]1[/note]God, believe also into [note]1[/note]Me.
verse.note: Here the Lord showed His disciples that He is the same as God. The disciples were troubled upon hearing of His leaving. By this word He made them realize that as God He is omnipresent and is not limited by time and space.

verse.text: In [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]My Father's house are [note]2[/note]many [xref]b[/xref]abodes; if [i]it were[/i] not [i]so,[/i] I would have told you; for I [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]go to prepare a place for you.
verse.note: According to the interpretation in [link]2:16[/link], [link]21[/link], [i]My Father's house[/i] refers to the temple, the body of Christ, as God's dwelling place. At first the body of Christ was only His individual body. But through Christ's death and resurrection, the body of Christ has increased to be His corporate Body, which is the church, including all His believers, who have been regenerated through His resurrection ([link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link]). In Christ's resurrection the church is the Body of Christ, which is the house of God ([link]1 Tim. 3:15[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:5[/link]; [link]Heb. 3:6[/link]), God's habitation ([link]Eph. 2:21-22[/link]), God's temple ([link]1 Cor. 3:16-17[/link]).

The many abodes are the many members of the Body of Christ ([link]Rom. 12:5[/link]), which is God's temple ([link]1 Cor. 3:16-17[/link]). This is adequately proven by [link]v. 23[/link], which says that the Lord and the Father will make an abode with the one who loves Him.

This book has two main sections. The first section, [link]chs. 1-13[/link], points out how Christ, as the eternal Word, came through incarnation to bring God into man that He might be the life and life supply to man. The second section, [link]chs. 14-21[/link], unveils how Christ, as the man Jesus, went through death and resurrection to bring man into God for the building of God's habitation, which is the building of the church ([link]Matt. 16:18[/link]) and which is related to the building of the New Jerusalem ([link]Heb. 11:10[/link]; [link]Rev. 21:2[/link]). In the entire universe God has only one building, that is, the building of His living habitation with His redeemed people.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]if I go and [note]2[/note]prepare a place for you, I [xref]a[/xref]am coming again and will [note]3[/note]receive you to Myself, so that [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]where I am you also may be.
verse.note: [i]If I go[/i]...I am coming proves that the Lord's going (through His death and resurrection) was His coming (to His disciples — [link]vv. 18[/link], [link]28[/link]). He came in the flesh ([link]1:14[/link]) and was among His disciples, but He could not enter into them while He was in the flesh. He had to take the further step of passing through death and resurrection in order to be transfigured from the flesh into the Spirit that He might come into the disciples and dwell in them, as revealed in [link]vv. 17-20[/link]. After His resurrection He did come to breathe Himself as the Holy Spirit into the disciples ([link]20:19-22[/link]).

The Lord's intention in this chapter was to bring man into God for the building of His dwelling place. But between man and God there were many obstacles, such as sin, sins, death, the world, the flesh, the self, the old man, and Satan. For the Lord to bring man into God, He had to solve all these problems. Therefore, He had to go to the cross to accomplish redemption that He might open the way and make a standing for man, that man might enter into God. This standing in God, being enlarged, becomes the standing in the Body of Christ. Anyone who does not have a standing, a place, in God does not have a place in the Body of Christ, which is God's dwelling place. Hence, the Lord's going in order to accomplish redemption was to prepare a place in His Body for the disciples.
In receiving the disciples to Himself, the Lord put them into Himself, as indicated in [link]v. 20[/link] by the words [i]you in Me.[/i]

The Lord is in the Father ([link]vv. 10-11[/link]). He wanted His disciples also to be in the Father, as revealed in [link]17:21[/link]. Through His death and resurrection He brought His disciples into Himself. Since He is in the Father, they are in the Father by being in Him. Hence, where He is, the disciples are also.

verse.text: And where I am going you know the way.
Thomas said to Him, Lord, we do not know where You are going; how can we know the way?
Jesus said to him, I am the [note]1[/note]way and the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]reality and the [xref]b[/xref]life; no one comes to the Father except through Me.
verse.note: The way for man to enter into God is the Lord Himself. Since the way is a living person, the place to which the Lord brings man must also be a person, God the Father Himself. The Lord Himself is the living way by which man is brought into God the Father, the living place. The way needs the reality, and the reality needs the life. The Lord Himself is the life to us. This life brings us the reality, and the reality becomes the way by which we enter into the enjoyment of God the Father.

Christ is the reality of the divine things. This reality came through Him and becomes the realization of God to us. See note [link]14[sup]6[/sup] in ch. 1[/link] and note [link]6[sup]6[/sup] in 1 John 1[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]If you had [xref]a[/xref]known Me, you would have known My Father also; and henceforth you [xref]b[/xref]know Him and have seen Him.
verse.note: This chapter unveils the way God dispenses Himself into man. In the dispensing of Himself into us, God is triune. He is one, yet He is three — the Father, the Son, and the Spirit. The Son is the embodiment and expression of the Father ([link]vv. 7-11[/link]), and the Spirit is the reality and realization of the Son ([link]vv. 17-20[/link]). In the Son (the Son is even called the Father — [link]Isa. 9:6[/link]) the Father is expressed and seen, and as the Spirit ([link]2 Cor. 3:17[/link]) the Son is revealed and realized. The Father in the Son is expressed among the believers, and the Son as the Spirit is realized in the believers. God the Father is hidden, God the Son is manifested among men, and God the Spirit enters into man to be his life, his life supply, and his everything. Hence, this Triune God — the Father in the Son and the Son as the Spirit — dispenses Himself into us to be our portion that we may enjoy Him as our everything in His divine trinity.

verse.text: Philip said to Him, Lord, show us the Father and it is sufficient for us.
Jesus said to him, Have I been so long a time with you, and you have not known Me, Philip? He who has [xref]a[/xref]seen Me has seen the Father; how [i]is it that[/i] you say, Show us the Father?

Do you not believe that I am [xref]a[/xref]in the Father and the [xref]b[/xref]Father is in Me? The [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]words that I say to you I do not speak [xref]d[/xref]from Myself, but the Father who abides in Me does His works.
verse.note: See note [link]63[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 6[/link].

verse.text: Believe Me that I am [xref]a[/xref]in the Father and the Father is in Me; but if not, believe because of the [xref]b[/xref]works themselves.

Truly, truly, I say to you, He who believes into Me, the works which I do he shall do also; and [xref]a[/xref]greater than these he shall do because I am [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]going to the Father.
verse.note: The Lord came from the Father to bring God into man through His incarnation. Here, He is going to the Father to bring man into God through His death and resurrection.

verse.text: And whatever you [xref]a[/xref]ask [note]1[/note]in My name, that I will do, that the [note]2[/note]Father may be [xref]b[/xref]glorified in the Son.
verse.note: To be in the Lord's name, here and in [link]v. 14[/link], means to be one with the Lord, to live by the Lord, and to let the Lord live in us. The Lord came and did things in the Father's name ([link]5:43[/link]; [link]10:25[/link]), meaning that He was one with the Father ([link]10:30[/link]), that He lived because of the Father ([link]6:57[/link]), and that the Father worked in Him ([link]v. 10[/link]). In the Gospels the Lord as the expression of the Father did things in the Father's name. In the Acts the disciples as the expression of the Lord did even greater things ([link]v. 12[/link]) in the Lord's name.

For the Father to be glorified in the Son means that His divine element is expressed from within the Son. Whatever the Son does expresses the Father's divine element. This is the glorifying of the Father in the Son.

verse.text: If you [xref]a[/xref]ask Me anything in My name, I will do [i]it.[/i]
If you [xref]a[/xref]love Me, you will keep My [xref]b[/xref]commandments.
And I will ask the Father, and He will give you another [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Comforter, that He may be with you forever,
verse.note: The Greek word here means [i]advocate, one alongside who takes care of our cause, our affairs.[/i] The Greek word for [i]Comforter[/i] is the same as that for [i]Advocate[/i] in [link]1 John 2:1[/link]. Today we have both the Lord Jesus in the heavens and the Spirit (the Comforter) within us as our Advocate, who takes care of our case.

verse.text: [i]Even[/i] the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Spirit of reality, whom the world cannot receive, because it does not behold Him or know [i]Him; but[/i] you know Him, because [note]2[/note]He abides with you and shall be [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]in you.
verse.note: The Spirit promised here was referred to in [link]7:39[/link]. This Spirit is the Spirit of life ([link]Rom. 8:2[/link]), and this promise of the Lord's was fulfilled on the day of the Lord's resurrection, when the Spirit as the breath of life was breathed into the disciples ([link]20:22[/link]). The Lord's promise here is different from the promise of the Father concerning the Spirit of power in [link]Luke 24:49[/link]. That promise was fulfilled fifty days after the Lord's resurrection, on the day of Pentecost, when the Spirit as the mighty wind blew upon the disciples ([link]Acts 2:1-4[/link]). In this verse the Spirit of life is called "the Spirit of reality." This Spirit of reality is Christ ([link]v. 6[/link]); hence, the Spirit of reality is the Spirit of Christ ([link]Rom. 8:9[/link]). This Spirit is also the reality of Christ ([link]1 John 5:6[/link], [link]20[/link]) that Christ may be realized in those who believe into Him, as their life and life supply.

The very "He" who is the Spirit of reality in this verse becomes the very "I" who is the Lord Himself in [link]v. 18[/link]. This means that the Christ who was in the flesh went through death and resurrection to become the life-giving Spirit, the pneumatic Christ. [link]First Corinthians 15:45[/link] confirms this. In dealing with the matter of resurrection, that verse says, "The last Adam [Christ in the flesh] became a life-giving Spirit."

This is the first time that the promise of the Spirit's indwelling is revealed. It is fulfilled and fully developed in the Epistles. See [link]1 Cor. 6:19[/link] and [link]Rom. 8:9[/link], [link]11[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]I will not leave you [i]as[/i] orphans; I am [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]coming to you.
verse.note: See note [link]17[sup]2[/sup][/link].
This coming was fulfilled on the day of His resurrection ([link]20:19-22[/link]). After His resurrection the Lord came back to His disciples to be with them forever, thus not leaving them as orphans.

verse.text: Yet [xref]a[/xref]a little while and the world beholds Me no longer, but you behold Me; because I [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]live, you also shall [xref]c[/xref]live.
verse.note: It should be after His resurrection that the Lord lives in His disciples and that they live by Him, as mentioned in [link]Gal. 2:20[/link].

verse.text: In that [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]day you will know that I am [xref]b[/xref]in My Father, and you [xref]c[/xref]in Me, and I [xref]d[/xref]in you.
verse.note: This should refer to the day of the Lord's resurrection ([link]20:19[/link]).

verse.text: He who has My commandments and keeps them, he is the one who [xref]a[/xref]loves Me; and he who loves Me will be loved by My Father, and I will love him and will [xref]b[/xref]manifest Myself to him.
Judas, not Iscariot, said to Him, Lord, and what has happened that You are to manifest Yourself to us and not to the world?

Jesus answered and said to him, If anyone [xref]a[/xref]loves Me, he will [xref]b[/xref]keep My word, and My Father will love him, and We will come to him and make an [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]abode with him.
verse.note: This is one of the many abodes mentioned in [link]v. 2[/link]. It will be a mutual abode, in which the Triune God abides in the believers and the believers abide in Him.

verse.text: He who does not love Me does not keep My words; and the [xref]a[/xref]word which you hear is not Mine, but the Father's who sent Me.
These things I have spoken to you [i]while[/i] abiding with you;

But the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Comforter, the Holy Spirit, whom the [note]2[/note]Father will send in [note]3[/note]My name, He will [xref]b[/xref]teach you [xref]c[/xref]all things and remind you of all the things which I have said to you.
verse.note: The Comforter, the Holy Spirit, was to be sent by the Father in the Son's name. Therefore, the Holy Spirit was sent by the Father and also by the Son. Thus, the Holy Spirit comes not only from the Father but also from the Son, and He is the reality not only of the Father but also of the Son. Hence, when we call on the name of the Son, we get the Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 12:3[/link]).

The Father being in the Son's name is equivalent to the Father being the Son (see note [link]43[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 5[/link]). Therefore, the Father's sending of the Holy Spirit in the Son's name is the Son's sending of the Holy Spirit from the Father ([link]15:26[/link]). The Son and the Father are one ([link]10:30[/link]). Hence, the Spirit who is sent comes not only out of the Father ([link]15:26[/link]) but also out of the Son. Moreover, when the Spirit comes, He comes with the Father and the Son (see note [link]26[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 15[/link]). This proves that the Father, the Son, and the Spirit are one God, the Triune God, who reaches us and is working, that is, dispensing, Himself into us in His divine trinity to be our life and everything.

In [link]5:43[/link] we are told that the Son came in the Father's name, and here that the Father sent the Holy Spirit in the Son's name. This proves not only that the Son and the Father are one ([link]10:30[/link]) but also that the Holy Spirit is one with the Father and the Son. The Holy Spirit, who is sent by the Father in the Son's name, is not only the reality that comes from the Father but also the reality that comes from the Son. This is the Triune God — the Father, the Son, and the Spirit — who reaches man eventually as the Spirit.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Peace I leave with you; My peace I give to you; not as the world gives do I give to you. Do not let your heart be [xref]b[/xref]troubled, neither let it be afraid.

You have heard that I said to you, I am [xref]a[/xref]going away and I am [note]1[/note]coming to you. If you loved Me, you would rejoice because [xref]b[/xref]I am [note]2[/note]going to the Father, for the Father is [xref]c[/xref]greater than I.
verse.note: See note [link]18[sup]2[/sup][/link].
See note [link]12[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And now I have told you [xref]a[/xref]before it happens, so that when it happens you may believe.
I will no longer speak much with you, for the [xref]a[/xref]ruler of the world is coming, and in Me he has nothing;
But [i]this is so[/i] that the world may know that I love the Father, and as the Father [xref]a[/xref]commanded Me, so I do. Rise, let us go from here.
I am the [note]1[/note]true [xref]a[/xref]vine, and My Father is the [note]2[/note]husbandman.
verse.note: This true vine (the Son) with its branches (the believers in the Son) is the organism of the Triune God in God's economy. This organism grows with His riches and expresses His divine life.

The Greek word means [i]cultivator of the soil, land-worker, farmer[/i] ([link]2 Tim. 2:6[/link]; [link]James 5:7[/link]; [link]Matt. 21:33[/link]). The Father as the husbandman is the source, the author, the planner, the planter, the life, the substance, the soil, the water, the air, the sunshine, and everything to the vine. The Son as the vine is the center of God's economy and the embodiment of all the riches of the Father. The Father, by cultivating the Son, works Himself with all His riches into the vine, and eventually the vine expresses the Father in a corporate way through its branches. This is the Father's economy in the universe.

verse.text: Every branch in Me that does not bear fruit, He takes it away; and every [i]branch[/i] that bears fruit, He [note]1[/note]prunes it that it may bear more fruit.
verse.note: Lit., cleanses.

verse.text: You are already [xref]a[/xref]clean because of the word which I have spoken to you.
[xref]a[/xref]Abide in Me and I [xref]b[/xref]in you. As the branch cannot bear fruit [note]1[/note]of itself unless it abides in the vine, so neither [i]can[/i] you unless you abide in Me.
verse.note: Lit., from.

verse.text: I am the vine; you are the branches. He who abides in Me and I in him, he bears [xref]a[/xref]much fruit; for apart from Me you can do [xref]b[/xref]nothing.

If one does not abide in Me, he is [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]cast out as a branch and is dried up; and they gather them and cast [i]them[/i] into the [xref]b[/xref]fire, and they are [xref]c[/xref]burned.
verse.note: For a branch to be cast out means that it is cut off from participation in the riches of the life of the vine.

verse.text: If you abide in Me and My [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]words abide in you, [note]2[/note]ask whatever you will, and it shall be done for you.
verse.note: See note [link]63[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 6[/link].

When we abide in the Lord and let His words abide in us, we actually are one with Him, and He works within us. Then, when we ask in prayer for whatever we will, it is not only we who are praying; He too is praying, in our praying. This kind of prayer is related to fruit-bearing ([link]v. 8[/link]) and will surely be answered. See note [link]16[sup]2[/sup][/link].

verse.text: In this is My Father [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]glorified, that you bear much fruit and [i]so[/i] you will become My [xref]b[/xref]disciples.
verse.note: In fruit-bearing the Father's divine life is expressed; hence, He is glorified.

verse.text: As the Father has [xref]a[/xref]loved Me, I also have loved you; abide in My love.
If you [note]1[/note]keep My [xref]a[/xref]commandments, you will abide in My love; even as I have kept My Father's commandments and abide in His love.
verse.note: When we abide in the Lord, He speaks His instant words within us. These words are His commandments to us. If we keep those commandments, it shows that we love Him; it is thus that we will abide in His love.

verse.text: These things I have spoken to you that My [note]1[/note]joy may be in you and [i]that[/i] your [xref]a[/xref]joy may be made full.
verse.note: Being branches of the divine vine and bearing fruit to express the divine life are matters of joy, and they also issue in a joyful life.

verse.text: This is My [xref]a[/xref]commandment, that you [xref]b[/xref]love one another even as I have loved you.
No one has greater love than this, that one [xref]a[/xref]lay down his [note]1[/note]life for his friends.
verse.note: The Greek word here means [i]soul, soul-life.[/i]

verse.text: You are My [xref]a[/xref]friends if you do what I command you.
No longer do I call you slaves, for the slave does not know what his master is doing; but I have called you friends, for all the things which I have heard from My Father I have made known to you.

You did not choose Me, but I [xref]a[/xref]chose you, and I [note]1[/note]set you that you should [note]2[/note]go forth and [xref]b[/xref]bear fruit and [note]3[/note][i]that[/i] your fruit should [note]4[/note]remain, that whatever you [note]5[/note][xref]c[/xref]ask the Father in My name, He may give you.
verse.note: We were wild branches, and through faith we have been grafted into Christ. Here the Lord said that He [i]set[/i] us. This fits the thought of grafting.

The Greek word for [i]go forth[/i] means [i]to depart,[/i] implying to leave for another place; hence, it is rendered [i]go forth.[/i] It is the same Greek word as that for [i]go[/i] in [link]14:4[/link] and [link]16:5[/link]. The fruit borne by going forth in this way does not denote the virtues of the fruit-bearer's character, such as the fruit of the Holy Spirit in the believer's living, mentioned in [link]Gal. 5:22-23[/link], but it denotes the believers produced by the fruit-bearer. This corresponds with the subject of this section, [link book="John"]12:20-17:26[/link], which is Christ's multiplication. The virtues we possess through our abiding in the Lord cannot be counted as Christ's multiplication. Only the believers that we produce in the Lord are the tangible multiplication of Christ. The Father's house in [link]ch. 14[/link], the true vine in this chapter, and the man-child in [link]ch. 16[/link] are all related to the multiplication of Christ.

After we go forth to produce believers in the Lord, we need to care for them. The best way is to set up meetings in their homes to cover and protect them that they may be cared for by being nourished and taught, and may become the remaining fruit, living in the branches of the true vine, that is, in the Body of Christ, to be Christ's increase.
The same Greek word used for [i]abide[/i] in this chapter.

To ask in the Lord's name requires us to abide in the Lord and allow Him and His words to abide in us that we may actually be one with Him. Then when we ask, He asks in our asking. This kind of asking is related to fruit-bearing and will surely be answered by the Father. See note [link]7[sup]2[/sup][/link].

verse.text: These things I command you that you may [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]love one another.
verse.note: This is to love one another in the Lord's life, the divine life, in the Lord's love, and in His commission of fruit-bearing. Life is the source, love is the condition, and fruit-bearing is the goal. If we all live by the Lord's life as the source, in the Lord's love as the condition, and for fruit-bearing as the goal, we surely will love one another. Having different sources of life, different conditions, or different goals will separate us and prevent us from loving one another.

verse.text: If the world [xref]a[/xref]hates you, know that it has [xref]b[/xref]hated Me before you.

If you were [note]1[/note]of the world, the world would love its own; but because you are [xref]a[/xref]not [note]1[/note]of the world, but I chose you out of the world, therefore the world hates you.
verse.note: Lit., out of.

verse.text: Remember the word which I said to you, A slave is not [xref]a[/xref]greater than his master. If they have [xref]b[/xref]persecuted Me, they will [xref]c[/xref]persecute you also; if they have kept My word, they will keep yours also.
But all these things they will do to you because of My [xref]a[/xref]name, because they do [xref]b[/xref]not know Him who sent Me.
If I had not come and spoken to them, they would not have [xref]a[/xref]sin; but now they have no excuse for their sin.
He who [xref]a[/xref]hates Me hates My Father also.
If I did not do among them the [xref]a[/xref]works which no one else has done, they would not have [xref]b[/xref]sin; but now they have both seen and hated both Me and My Father.
But [i]it is so[/i] that the word written in their law may be fulfilled, [xref]a[/xref]"They hated Me without cause."

But when the [xref]a[/xref]Comforter comes, whom I will [xref]b[/xref]send to you [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]from the Father, the [xref]d[/xref]Spirit of reality, who proceeds [note]1[/note]from the Father, He will [xref]e[/xref]testify concerning Me;
verse.note: The sense in Greek is [i]from with[/i] (see note [link]14[sup]5[/sup] in ch. 1[/link]). The Spirit of reality, who is sent by the Son from the Father, comes not only from the Father but also with the Father. The Father is the source. When this Spirit comes from the source, He does not leave the source but comes with the source. This Spirit, sent by the Son and coming with the Father, testifies concerning the Son. Therefore, His testimony concerning the Son is a matter of the Triune God.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]you testify also, because from the beginning you have been with Me.
These things I have spoken to you so that you would not be [xref]a[/xref]stumbled.
They will [xref]a[/xref]put you out of the synagogues; but an hour is coming for everyone who [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]kills you to think that he is offering service to God.
verse.note: In this Gospel religion is revealed as the enemy of life. In the Gospels, Judaism opposed and persecuted the Lord Jesus. In the Acts it continued by opposing and persecuting the apostles and the disciples ([link]Acts 4:1-3[/link]; [link]5:17-18[/link], [link]40[/link]; [link]6:11-14[/link]; [link]7:57-59[/link]; [link]26:9-12[/link]). In subsequent history the Catholic Church persecuted the Lord's followers. All organized religions, of whatever kind, persecute those who seek the Lord in life. All these religions consider their persecuting of the Lord's seekers a service offered to God.

verse.text: And these things they will do [xref]a[/xref]because they have not known the Father nor Me.

But these things I have spoken to you that [xref]a[/xref]when their hour comes you may remember them, that I told you [i]of them.[/i] Now these things I have not said to you from the beginning, because I was with you.
But now I am [xref]a[/xref]going to Him who sent Me; and none of you asks Me, [xref]b[/xref]Where are You going?
But because I have spoken these things to you, [xref]a[/xref]sorrow has filled your [xref]b[/xref]heart.

But I tell you the truth, It is expedient for you that I go away; for if I do not go away, the Comforter will [xref]a[/xref]not come to you; but if I [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]go, I will [xref]c[/xref]send Him to you.
verse.note: This "going" was ultimately fulfilled by His ascension in [link]20:17[/link].

verse.text: And when He comes, He will [note]1[/note]convict the world concerning [note]2[/note]sin and concerning [note]2[/note]righteousness and concerning [note]2[/note]judgment:
verse.note: To convict means to convince, to condemn, to cause people to rebuke themselves.

Sin entered through Adam ([link]Rom. 5:12[/link]), righteousness is the resurrected Christ ([link]v. 10[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]), and judgment is for Satan ([link]v. 11[/link]), who is the author and source of sin ([link]8:44[/link]). In Adam we were born of sin. The only way to be freed from sin is to believe into Christ, the Son of God ([link]v. 9[/link]). If we believe into Him, He is righteousness to us, and we are justified in Him ([link]Rom. 3:24[/link]; [link]4:25[/link]). If we do not repent of the sin that is in Adam and believe into Christ, the Son of God, we will remain in sin and share the judgment of Satan for eternity ([link]Matt. 25:41[/link]). These are the main points of the gospel. The Spirit uses these points to convict the world.

verse.text: Concerning [xref]a[/xref]sin, because they do not [xref]b[/xref]believe into Me;
And concerning [xref]a[/xref]righteousness, because [xref]b[/xref]I am going to the Father and you no longer behold Me;
And concerning judgment, because the ruler of this world has been [xref]a[/xref]judged.
I have yet many things to say to you, but you cannot bear [i]them[/i] now.

But when He, the [xref]a[/xref]Spirit of reality, comes, He will [note]1[/note]guide you into all the [xref]b[/xref]reality; for He will not speak [xref]c[/xref]from Himself, but what He hears He will speak; and He will [note]1[/note]declare to you [xref]d[/xref]the things that are coming.
verse.note: The work of the Spirit is, first, to convict the world. Second, as the Spirit of reality He guides the believers into all the reality; that is, He makes all that the Son is and has real to the believers. All that the Father is and has is embodied in the Son ([link]Col. 2:9[/link]), and all that the Son is and has is declared as reality to the believers through the Spirit ([link]vv. 14-15[/link]). This declaring is the glorifying of the Son with the Father. Hence, it is a matter of the Triune God being wrought into and mingled with the believers. Third, the Spirit declares the things that are to come, which are revealed mainly in Revelation ([link]Rev. 1:1[/link], [link]19[/link]). The three aspects of the Spirit's work correspond with the three sections of John's writings: his Gospel, his Epistles, and his Revelation.

verse.text: He will [xref]a[/xref]glorify Me, for He will receive of Mine and will declare [i]it[/i] to you.
[xref]a[/xref]All that the Father has is Mine; for this [i]reason[/i] I have said that He receives of Mine and will declare [i]it[/i] to you.
[xref]a[/xref]A little while and you no longer behold Me, and again a little while and you will [xref]b[/xref]see Me.

[i]Some[/i] of His disciples then said to one another, What is this that He says to us, A little while and you do not behold Me, and again a little while and you will see Me; and, Because I am going to the Father?
Therefore they said, What is this that He says, A little while? We do not know what He is talking about.

Jesus knew that they wanted to ask Him and He said to them, Are you inquiring among yourselves concerning this, that I said, A little while and you do not behold Me, and again a little while and you will see Me?
Truly, truly, I say to you that you will [xref]a[/xref]weep and lament, but the world will rejoice; you will be sorrowful, but your sorrow will be turned into [xref]b[/xref]joy.

A woman, when she gives birth, has sorrow because her hour has come; but when she [note]1[/note]brings forth the [note]2[/note]little [xref]a[/xref]child, she no longer remembers the affliction because of the joy that a man has been born into the world.
verse.note: The bringing forth here is the begetting in [link]Acts 13:33[/link]. The incarnated Christ, including all His believers, was begotten in His resurrection to be the Son of God ([link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link]). Thus, He has become the firstborn Son of God, and all His believers have become God's many sons as His brothers to constitute His church ([link]Rom. 8:29[/link]; [link]John 20:17[/link] and note 2; [link]Heb. 2:10-12[/link]) as His multiplication ([link]12:24[/link]), His increase ([link]3:29-30[/link]), and His Body, which is His fullness, His expression ([link]Eph. 1:23[/link]).

In this parable the Lord indicated that the disciples were then like a woman travailing in birth, and that He was the little child to be brought forth in His resurrection ([link]Acts 13:33[/link]; [link]Heb. 1:5[/link]; [link]Rom. 1:4[/link]).

verse.text: Therefore you also now have sorrow; but I will [note]1[/note]see you [xref]a[/xref]again and your heart will [xref]b[/xref]rejoice, and no one takes your joy away from you.
verse.note: After being born in resurrection, the Lord came to see the disciples in the evening of the day of His resurrection, and the disciples rejoiced at His presence ([link]20:20[/link]).

verse.text: And in that [xref]a[/xref]day you will ask Me nothing. Truly, truly, I say to you, [note]1[/note]Whatever you ask the Father in My name, He will give to you.
verse.note: Or, Whatever you ask the Father, He will give to you in My name.

verse.text: Until now you have [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]asked for nothing in My name; ask and you shall receive, that your [xref]b[/xref]joy may be made full.
verse.note: See note [link]16[sup]5[/sup] in ch. 15[/link]; so in [link]v. 26[/link].

verse.text: These things I have spoken to you in parables; an hour is coming when I will no longer speak to you in parables, but I will report to you plainly concerning the Father.
In that [xref]a[/xref]day you will [xref]b[/xref]ask in My name, and I do not say to you that I will ask the Father concerning you,
For the Father Himself loves you, because you have loved Me and have believed that I [xref]a[/xref]came forth [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]from God.
verse.note: See note [link]14[sup]5[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: I [note]1[/note]came forth [xref]a[/xref]out from the Father and have come into the world; again, I am leaving the world and am [xref]b[/xref]going to the Father.
verse.note: Some MSS read, came forth from the Father. The word [i]from[/i] in these MSS is the same as that in [link]v. 27[/link].

verse.text: His disciples said, Behold, now You are speaking plainly and not saying any parable.
Now we know that You know all things and have no need that anyone ask You; by this we believe that You [xref]a[/xref]came forth [note]1[/note]from God.
verse.note: The word [i]from[/i] used by the disciples here does not have the sense of [i]from with.[/i] It is different from the word used by the Lord in [link]v. 27[/link].

verse.text: Jesus answered them, Do you now believe?

Behold, an hour is coming, and has come, that you will be [xref]a[/xref]scattered each to his own place and will leave Me alone; yet I am not [xref]b[/xref]alone, because the Father is [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]with Me.
verse.note: See note [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 8[/link].

verse.text: These things I have spoken to you that in Me you may have [xref]a[/xref]peace. In the world you have [xref]b[/xref]affliction, but take courage; I have [xref]c[/xref]overcome the world.

These things Jesus spoke, and [xref]a[/xref]lifting up His eyes to heaven, He said, [xref]b[/xref]Father, the hour has come; [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]glorify Your Son that the Son may [xref]d[/xref]glorify You;
verse.note: This is the subject of the Lord's prayer in this chapter. He was God incarnated in the flesh, and His flesh was a tabernacle in which God could dwell on earth ([link]1:14[/link]). His divine element was confined in His humanity, just as God's shekinah glory had been concealed within the tabernacle. Once, on the mountain of transfiguration, His divine element was released from within His flesh and expressed in glory, being seen by the three disciples ([link]Matt. 17:1-4[/link]; [link]John 1:14[/link]). But then it was concealed again in His flesh. Before this prayer He predicted that He would be glorified and that the Father would be glorified in Him ([link]12:23[/link]; [link]13:31-32[/link]). Now He was about to pass through death so that the concealing shell of His humanity might be broken and His divine element, His divine life, might be released. Also, He would resurrect that He might uplift His humanity into the divine element and that His divine element might be expressed, with the result that His entire being, His divinity and His humanity, would be glorified (see note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 12[/link]). The Father would thus be glorified in Him (see note [link]28[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 12[/link]). Hence, He prayed for this.[br][br]The Lord's prayer here concerning the divine mystery is fulfilled in three stages. First, it was fulfilled in His resurrection, in that His divine element, His divine life, was released from within His humanity into His many believers ([link]12:23-24[/link]), and His whole being, including His humanity, was brought into glory ([link]Luke 24:26[/link]), and in that the Father's divine element was expressed in His resurrection and glorification. In His resurrection God answered and fulfilled His prayer ([link]Acts 3:13-15[/link]). Second, it has been fulfilled in the church, in that as His resurrection life has been expressed through His many members, He has been glorified in them, and the Father has been glorified in Him through the church ([link]Eph. 3:21[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 3:15-16[/link]). Third, it will ultimately be fulfilled in the New Jerusalem, in that He will be fully expressed in glory, and God will be glorified in Him through the holy city for eternity ([link]Rev. 21:11[/link], [link]23-24[/link]).[br][br]In praying in this way, the Lord unveiled His person, His deity; He is the same as the Father in the divine glory.

verse.text: Even as [note]1[/note]You have given Him [xref]a[/xref]authority over all flesh to give [note]2[/note]eternal [xref]b[/xref]life to all whom You have [xref]c[/xref]given Him.
verse.note: This indicates the Lord's work. The Lord has the Father's authority over all mankind that He may give eternal life, not to all mankind but only to those whom the Father has given Him — the Father's chosen ones.
See note [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].

verse.text: And this is [note]1[/note]eternal life, that they may [xref]a[/xref]know You, the only [xref]b[/xref]true God, and Him whom You have [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]sent, Jesus [xref]d[/xref]Christ.
verse.note: Eternal life is the divine life with a special function, that is, to know God and Christ (cf. [link]Matt. 11:27[/link]). God and Christ are divine. To know the divine person, we need the divine life. Since the believers are born of the divine life, they know God and Christ ([link]Heb. 8:11[/link]; [link]Phil. 3:10[/link]).
See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link]; so in [link]vv. 8[/link], [link]18[/link], [link]21[/link], [link]23[/link], [link]25[/link].

verse.text: I have [note]1[/note]glorified You on earth, finishing the [xref]a[/xref]work which You have given Me to do.
verse.note: This means that while He was living on earth, the Lord manifested and expressed the Father.

verse.text: And now, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]glorify Me along with Yourself, Father, with the [xref]b[/xref]glory which I had [xref]c[/xref]with You [xref]d[/xref]before the world was.
verse.note: This word strengthens the indication in [link]v. 1[/link], concerning the deity of the Lord's person. He had the divine glory along with the Father before the world was, in eternity past; hence, He should be glorified now with that glory along with the Father. The Lord participates in the divine glory not by Himself but along with the Father, for He and the Father are one ([link]10:30[/link]).

verse.text: I have manifested [note]1[/note]Your [xref]a[/xref]name to the men whom You [xref]b[/xref]gave Me out of the world. They were [xref]c[/xref]Yours, and You gave them to Me, and they have kept Your [note]2[/note]word.
verse.note: [i]Your name,[/i] here and in [link]v. 26[/link], means the very name [i]Father.[/i] The name [i]God[/i] and the name [i]Jehovah[/i] were adequately revealed to man in the Old Testament, but the name [i]Father[/i] was not, though it was mentioned briefly in [link]Isa. 9:6[/link]; [link]63:16[/link]; [link]64:8[/link]. The Son came and worked in the Father's name ([link]5:43[/link]; [link]10:25[/link]) to manifest the Father to the men whom the Father gave Him and to make the Father's name known to them ([link]v. 26[/link]). That name reveals the Father as the source of life ([link]5:26[/link]) for the propagation and multiplication of life. Many sons would be born of the Father ([link]1:12-13[/link]) to express the Father. Hence, the Father's name is very much related to the divine life.

The Father's words are of two kinds: the constant word ([link]v. 6[/link]) and the instant words ([link]v. 8[/link]). Both are used by the Lord to impart eternal life to the believers who receive both kinds of words.

verse.text: Now they have come to know that all that You have given Me is from You,

For the [xref]a[/xref]words which You gave Me I have [xref]b[/xref]given to them, and they received [i]them[/i] and knew truly that I [xref]c[/xref]came forth [note]1[/note]from You, and they have believed that You [xref]d[/xref]sent Me.
verse.note: See note [link]14[sup]5[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: I [xref]a[/xref]ask concerning them; I do not ask concerning the world, but concerning [i]those[/i] whom You have [xref]b[/xref]given Me, for they are [xref]c[/xref]Yours;
And all that is Mine is Yours, and [xref]a[/xref]Yours Mine; and I have been [note]1[/note]glorified [note]2[/note]in them.
verse.note: Since the disciples expressed the Lord, He was glorified in them.
I.e., because of them.

verse.text: And I am no longer in the world; yet they are [xref]a[/xref]in the world, and I am [xref]b[/xref]coming to You. [note]1[/note]Holy Father, [xref]c[/xref]keep them [note]2[/note]in Your [xref]d[/xref]name, which You have given to Me, that they may be [xref]e[/xref]one even as We are.
verse.note: The Son's believers are still in the world. They need to be kept that they may be one even as the Divine Trinity is one, that is, that they may be one in the Divine Trinity. The Son prayed that the holy Father would so keep them.

To be kept in the Father's name is to be kept by His life, because only those who are born of the Father and have the Father's life can participate in the Father's name. The Son has given the Father's life to those whom the Father has given Him ([link]v. 2[/link]); hence, they share the Father's name by being kept in it, and they are one in it. The first aspect of this oneness, that is, the first aspect of the building up of the believers, is the oneness in the Father's name and by His divine life. In this aspect of oneness the believers, born of the Father's life, enjoy the Father's name, that is, the Father Himself, as the factor of their oneness.

verse.text: When I was with them, I [xref]a[/xref]kept them in Your [xref]b[/xref]name, which You have given to Me, and I guarded [i]them;[/i] and [xref]c[/xref]not one of them [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]perished, except the [xref]e[/xref]son of [note]1[/note]perdition, that the [xref]f[/xref]Scripture might be fulfilled.
verse.note: [i]Perished[/i] (a verb) and [i]perdition[/i] (a noun) are from the same Greek root.

verse.text: But now I am [xref]a[/xref]coming to You, and these things I speak in the world that they may have My [xref]b[/xref]joy made full in themselves.

I have [xref]a[/xref]given them Your [note]1[/note]word, and the [note]2[/note]world has [xref]b[/xref]hated them, because they are [xref]c[/xref]not [note]3[/note]of the [note]2[/note]world even as [xref]d[/xref]I am not [note]3[/note]of the [note]2[/note]world.
verse.note: The Lord has given the believers two kinds of words: the constant word ([link]vv. 14[/link], [link]17[/link]) and the instant words ([link]v. 8[/link]).

The world is the system of Satan ([link]12:31[/link]). The believers are not of the world ([link]vv. 14[/link], [link]16[/link]) but are separated from the world ([link]v. 19[/link]), and are not taken out of the world ([link]v. 15[/link]) but are sent into the world ([link]v. 18[/link]) for the Lord's commission. (So in [link]vv. 15[/link], [link]16[/link].)
Lit., out of; so in [link]v. 16[/link].

verse.text: I do not ask that You would take them out of the world, but that You would [xref]a[/xref]keep them [note]1[/note]out of [i]the hands of[/i] the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]evil [i]one.[/i]
verse.note: Or, out of the evil.

The whole world lies in the evil one ([link]1 John 5:19[/link]). Hence, the believers need to be kept out of the hands of the evil one, and they need always to be watchful in prayer that they may be delivered from the evil one ([link]Matt. 6:13[/link]).

verse.text: They are [xref]a[/xref]not of the world, even as I am not of the world.
[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Sanctify them [note]2[/note]in the truth; Your [note]3[/note]word is truth.
verse.note: To be sanctified ([link]Eph. 5:26[/link]; [link]1 Thes. 5:23[/link]) is to be separated from the world and its usurpation unto God and His purpose, not only positionally ([link]Matt. 23:17[/link], [link]19[/link]) but also dispositionally ([link]Rom. 6:19[/link], [link]22[/link]). God's living word works in the believers to separate them from anything worldly. This is to be sanctified in God's word, which is the truth, the reality.

Or, in the reality. Reality is the Triune God ([link]1:14[/link], [link]17[/link]; [link]14:6[/link]; [link]1 John 5:6[/link]). Since the Triune God is contained and concealed in His word, His word is reality (see notes [link]14[sup]6[/sup] in ch. 1[/link] and [link]6[sup]6[/sup] in 1 John 1[/link]). We are sanctified in the reality of this word.

The Father's word carries the reality of the Father with it. When God's word says, "God is light," it carries God as light in it. Hence, God's word is reality, the truth, unlike Satan's word, which is vanity, a lie ([link]8:44[/link]).

verse.text: As You have [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sent Me into the world, I also have [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]sent them into the world.
verse.note: The Father sent the Son into the world with Himself as life and everything to the Son. In the same way, the Son sends His believers into the world with Himself as life and everything to the believers. See note [link]21[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 20[/link].

verse.text: And for their sake I [note]1[/note]sanctify Myself, that they themselves also may be [xref]a[/xref]sanctified in truth.
verse.note: The Son is absolutely holy in Himself. Yet, to set an example of sanctification for His disciples, He still sanctified Himself in His way of living while He was on earth.

verse.text: And I do not [xref]a[/xref]ask concerning these only, but concerning those also who believe into Me through their word,

That they all may be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]one; even as You, Father, are [xref]b[/xref]in Me and I [xref]c[/xref]in You, that they also may be [xref]d[/xref]in Us; that the [xref]e[/xref]world may believe that You have [xref]f[/xref]sent Me.
verse.note: This is the second aspect of the believers' oneness, the oneness in the Triune God through sanctification, separation from the world by the word of God. In this aspect of oneness the believers, separated from the world unto God, enjoy the Triune God as the factor of their oneness.

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]glory which You have given Me I have given to them, that they may be [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]one, even as We are [xref]c[/xref]one;
verse.note: The glory that the Father gave to the Son is the sonship with the Father's life and divine nature ([link]5:26[/link]). The sonship was given so that the Son could express the Father in His fullness ([link]1:18[/link]; [link]14:9[/link]; [link]Col. 2:9[/link]; [link]Heb. 1:3[/link]). The Son has given this glory to His believers that they too may have the sonship with the Father's life and divine nature ([link]v. 2[/link]; [link]2 Pet. 1:4[/link]) to express the Father in the Son in the Son's fullness ([link]1:16[/link]).

This is the third aspect of the believers' oneness, the oneness in the divine glory for the corporate expression of God. In this aspect of oneness the believers, their self having been fully denied, enjoy the glory of the Father as the factor of their perfected oneness and thus express God in a corporate, built-up way. This is the oneness of the divine commission; it fulfills the Son's prayer that He be fully expressed, that is, glorified, in the building up of the believers, and that the Father be fully expressed, glorified, in the Son's glorification. Hence, the ultimate oneness of the believers is (1) in the eternal life of God (in the Father's name), (2) by the holy word of God, and (3) in the divine glory to express the Triune God for eternity. That the Son might accomplish this oneness, the Father gave Him six things: the authority ([link]v. 2[/link]), the believers ([link]vv. 2[/link], [link]6[/link], [link]9[/link], [link]24[/link]), the work ([link]v. 4[/link]), the words ([link]v. 8[/link]), the Father's name ([link]vv. 11-12[/link]), and the Father's glory ([link]v. 24[/link]). That the believers may participate in this oneness, the Son gave them three things: the eternal life ([link]v. 2[/link]), the holy word of God ([link]vv. 8[/link], [link]14[/link]), and the divine glory ([link]v. 22[/link]). (So also for [i]one[/i] in [link]v. 23[/link].)

verse.text: I [xref]a[/xref]in them, and You [xref]b[/xref]in Me, that they may be perfected into [xref]c[/xref]one, that the world may know that You have [xref]d[/xref]sent Me and have [note]1[/note]loved them even as You have [xref]e[/xref]loved Me.
verse.note: The Father loved the Son by giving the Son His life, His nature, His fullness, and His glory that the Son might express Him. In the same way, the Father loved the Son's believers by giving them His life, His nature, His fullness, and His glory that they might express Him in the Son. This is a story of love as well as glory.

verse.text: Father, [i]concerning[/i] that which You have [xref]a[/xref]given Me, I desire that they also may [note]1[/note]be with Me [xref]b[/xref]where I am, that they may behold My [xref]c[/xref]glory, which You have given Me, for You [xref]d[/xref]loved Me [xref]e[/xref]before the foundation of the world.
verse.note: The Son is in the divine glory of the Father's expression. Therefore, for the Son's believers to be with Him where He is means that they are with Him in the divine glory to express the Father. The fulfillment of this matter began with the Son's resurrection, when He brought His believers into participation in His resurrection life, and will consummate in the New Jerusalem, when His believers will be brought fully into the divine glory for the ultimate corporate expression of the Triune God in eternity.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Righteous Father, though the world has not known You, yet I have [xref]a[/xref]known You, and these have known that You have [xref]b[/xref]sent Me.
verse.note: The world neither knows nor wants the Father, but the Son and the Son's believers do. Hence, the Father loves the Son and His believers so that He gives His glory to both the Son and His believers. In this matter He is righteous and just. In sanctifying the Son's believers, the Father is holy ([link]v. 11[/link]). In loving the Son and His believers so that He gives the Son and the believers His glory, the Father is righteous.

verse.text: And I have made Your [xref]a[/xref]name known to them and will [i]yet[/i] make [i]it[/i] known, that the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]love with which You have [xref]b[/xref]loved Me may be in them, and I [xref]c[/xref]in them.
verse.note: The love here is the love of the Father. In this love the Father gave His life and glory to the Son and His believers so that the Son and His believers can express Him. The Son prayed that this love would be in His believers and that they would always have the sense of this love.

verse.text: When Jesus had said these things, [xref]a[/xref]He [note]1[/note]went forth with His disciples across the brook [xref]b[/xref]Kedron, where there was a garden, into which He entered as well as His disciples.
verse.note: The Lord delivered Himself of His own accord to the process of death, as He had indicated in [link]10:17-18[/link]. He did it voluntarily and boldly.

verse.text: And Judas also, who was [xref]a[/xref]betraying Him, knew the place, for Jesus often gathered there with His disciples.
Then Judas, having gotten the cohort and some attendants from the chief priests and Pharisees, came there with torches and lamps and weapons.
Jesus therefore, [xref]a[/xref]knowing all the things that were coming upon Him, [note]1[/note]went forth and said to them, Whom do you seek?
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: They answered Him, Jesus the [xref]a[/xref]Nazarene. He said to them, [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]I am. And Judas also, who was betraying Him, was standing with them.
verse.note: I Am is the name of Jehovah (so in [link]vv. 6[/link], [link]8[/link]). See note [link]24[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 8[/link]. When the soldiers heard this name, they drew back and fell to the ground.

verse.text: When therefore He said to them, I am, they drew back and fell to the ground.
Then again He asked them, Whom do you seek? And they said, Jesus the Nazarene.
Jesus answered, I told you that [xref]a[/xref]I am; if therefore you seek Me, let [note]1[/note]these go away,
verse.note: While suffering betrayal at the hands of His false disciple and arrest by the soldiers, the Lord still took good care of His disciples. This reveals that He was at ease in passing through the process of death.

verse.text: That the word might be fulfilled which He spoke, [xref]a[/xref]Of those whom You have given Me, I have not lost one.
Then Simon Peter, having a [xref]a[/xref]sword, drew it and struck the slave of the high priest and [xref]b[/xref]cut off his right ear; and the slave's name was Malchus.
Jesus therefore said to Peter, Put the sword into its sheath. The [note]1[/note]cup which the Father has given Me, shall I not drink it?
verse.note: This word, too, shows that the Lord was willing to pass through the process of death.

verse.text: Then the cohort and the commander and the attendants of the Jews [xref]a[/xref]seized Jesus and bound Him
And [note]1[/note]led [i]Him[/i] away to Annas first; for he was the father-in-law of Caiaphas, who was high priest that year.
verse.note: The Lord was the Lamb of God ([link]1:29[/link]), and He was killed on the day of the Passover ([link]v. 28[/link]). As the passover lamb was examined before it was killed ([link]Exo. 12:3-6[/link]), so He was examined by the whole of mankind, represented by the high priest of the Jews and the governor of the Romans, and proved to be without blemish ([link]v. 38b[/link]; [link]19:4[/link], [link]6[/link]). See note [link]37[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 12[/link].

verse.text: Now it was [xref]a[/xref]Caiaphas who had advised the Jews that it was expedient for one man to die for the people.
And Simon Peter followed Jesus, as well as another disciple. And that disciple was known to the high priest, and he entered with Jesus into the court of the high priest;
But Peter stood at the door outside. Then the other disciple, the one known to the high priest, went out and spoke to [i]the maid[/i] who kept the door and brought Peter in.
Then the maid who kept the door said to Peter, Are you not also [i]one[/i] of this man's disciples? He said, [xref]a[/xref]I am not.

Now the slaves and the attendants were standing [i]there,[/i] having made a fire of coals, for it was cold, and they were warming themselves; and Peter also was with them, standing and warming himself.
The high priest then questioned Jesus concerning His disciples and concerning His teaching.
Jesus answered him, I have spoken openly to the world; I always taught in the synagogue and in the temple, where all the Jews come together, and I spoke nothing in secret.
[note]1[/note]Why do you question Me? Question those who have heard [i]Me, concerning[/i] what I spoke to them; behold, these know what I said.
verse.note: While judging the Lord, both the high priest of the Jewish religion and the governor of the Roman Empire were judged by Him in His dignity.

verse.text: And when He said these things, one of the attendants standing by [xref]a[/xref]slapped Jesus, saying, Is that how You answer the high priest?
Jesus answered him, If I have spoken wrongly, testify concerning the wrong; but if rightly, why do you strike Me?
Annas then sent Him bound to Caiaphas the high priest.
Now Simon Peter was standing and warming himself. Then they said to him, Are you not also [i]one[/i] of His disciples? He denied and said, I am not.
One of the slaves of the high priest, who was a relative of him whose ear Peter had cut off, said, Did I not see you in the garden with Him?
Then Peter denied again, and immediately a rooster crowed.

[xref]a[/xref]Then they led Jesus from Caiaphas into the [note]1[/note]praetorium, and it was [note]2[/note]early morning. And they themselves did not enter into the praetorium, so that they would not be defiled, but might eat the passover.
verse.note: The governor's official residence.
A reference to the fourth watch, 3:00 a.m. to 6:00 a.m.

verse.text: Pilate therefore went outside to them and said, What accusation do you bring against this man?
They answered and said to him, If this man were not doing evil, we would not have delivered Him to you.
Pilate said then to them, You take Him and judge Him according to your [xref]a[/xref]law. The Jews said to him, It is not lawful for us to kill anyone,
That the [xref]a[/xref]word of Jesus might be fulfilled which He spoke, signifying by what [note]1[/note]kind of death He was to die.
verse.note: The Jews' way to put criminals to death was to stone them ([link]Lev. 24:16[/link]). But the Lord Jesus predicted, according to the type in the Old Testament ([link]Num. 21:8-9[/link]), that He would be lifted up ([link]3:14[/link]; [link]8:28[/link]; [link]12:32[/link]). It was of God's sovereignty that not long before that time the Roman Empire had made it a law that criminals sentenced to death should be crucified. It was in this way that the Lord was executed. This proves that the Lord's death was not accidental but was predetermined by God ([link]Acts 2:23[/link]).

verse.text: Pilate therefore entered again into the praetorium and called for Jesus. And he said to Him, You are the [xref]a[/xref]King of the Jews?
Jesus answered, [note]1[/note]Are you saying this of yourself, or did others tell you about Me?
verse.note: See note [link]21[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: Pilate answered, Am I a Jew? Your nation and its chief priests have delivered You to me. What have You done?

Jesus answered, My [xref]a[/xref]kingdom is not [note]1[/note]of this world. If My kingdom were [note]1[/note]of this world, My attendants would be struggling so that I would not be delivered to the Jews; but as it is, My kingdom is not from [note]2[/note]here.
verse.note: Lit., out of; so in [link]v. 37[/link].
The world.

verse.text: Pilate said therefore to Him, So then You are a king? Jesus answered, You say that I am a king. For this I have been [xref]a[/xref]born, and for this I have come into the world, that I would testify to the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]truth. Everyone who is of the [note]1[/note]truth hears My voice.
verse.note: In view of the entire revelation of this book, [i]truth[/i] here denotes the divine reality embodied, revealed, and expressed in Christ as the Son of God. See notes [link]14[sup]6[/sup] in ch. 1[/link] and [link]6[sup]6[/sup] in 1 John 1[/link].

verse.text: Pilate said to Him, What is truth?[separator]And having said this, he again went out to the Jews and said to them, I find [xref]a[/xref]no fault in Him.
But you have a custom that I release one man to you at the Passover. Is it your will therefore that I release to you the King of the Jews?
Then they cried out again, saying, Not this man, but Barabbas. Now Barabbas was a robber.
[xref]a[/xref]Therefore at that time Pilate took Jesus and scourged [i]Him.[/i]
And the soldiers wove a crown of thorns and put it on His head, and they threw a purple garment around Him.
And they came to Him and said, [note]1[/note]Rejoice, King of the Jews! and [xref]a[/xref]slapped Him.
verse.note: See note [link]29[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 27[/link].

verse.text: And Pilate went outside again and said to them, Behold, I am bringing Him out to you that you may know that I find [xref]a[/xref]no fault in Him.
Then Jesus came out, wearing the thorny crown and the purple garment. And he said to them, Behold, the man!

When therefore the chief priests and the attendants saw Him, they cried out, saying, Crucify! Crucify! Pilate said to them, You take Him and crucify [i]Him,[/i] for I do [xref]a[/xref]not find fault in Him.
The Jews answered him, We have a [xref]a[/xref]law, and according to that law He ought to die because He [xref]b[/xref]made Himself the Son of God.
When Pilate therefore heard this word, he became frightened the more,
And he entered into the [note]1[/note]praetorium again and said to Jesus, Where are You from? But Jesus gave him no answer.
verse.note: The governor's official residence.

verse.text: Therefore Pilate said to Him, You do not speak to me? Do You not know that I have authority to release You and I have authority to crucify You?
Jesus answered him, You would have no authority against Me if it were not [xref]a[/xref]given to you from above; for this [i]reason,[/i] he who has delivered Me to you has the greater sin.
From then on, Pilate sought to release Him, but the Jews cried out, saying, If you release this man, you are not a friend of Caesar; everyone who makes himself a king opposes Caesar.
Pilate therefore, when he heard these words, brought Jesus outside and sat down on the judgment seat in a place called the Pavement, but in Hebrew, [note]1[/note]Gabbatha.
verse.note: An Aramaic term from Hebrew, meaning [i]a raised place.[/i] This must have been an elevated place, like a raised platform, paved with beautiful stones, as indicated by the Greek word for [i]Pavement,[/i] mentioned earlier in the verse.

verse.text: Now it was the [i]day of[/i] [note]1[/note]preparation for the Passover; it was about the [note]2[/note]sixth hour. And he said to the Jews, Behold, your King!
verse.note: See note [link]62[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 27[/link].

verse.text: They cried out then, Take [i]Him[/i] away! Take [i]Him[/i] away! Crucify Him! Pilate said to them, Shall I crucify your King? The chief priests answered, We have no king except Caesar.
Therefore at that time he delivered Him to them that [note]1[/note]He might be crucified. Therefore they [xref]a[/xref]took Jesus.
verse.note: This unjust, joint sentence exposed the blindness of religion and the darkness of politics.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]bearing the cross for Himself, He went out to the [i]place[/i] called the Place of a Skull, which is called in Hebrew, Golgotha,
Where they crucified Him, and with Him [xref]a[/xref]two others, on this side and that, and Jesus in the middle.
And Pilate wrote a notice also and put [i]it[/i] on the cross; and it was written, JESUS THE [xref]a[/xref]NAZARENE, THE [xref]b[/xref]KING OF THE JEWS.

This notice therefore many of the Jews read, for the place where Jesus was crucified was near the city, and it was written in [note]1[/note]Hebrew, in [note]1[/note]Latin, [i]and[/i] in [note]1[/note]Greek.
verse.note: Hebrew here represents the Hebrew religion, Latin represents Roman politics, and Greek represents Greek culture. These three together represent the entire world, all of mankind. This signifies that the Lord Jesus as the Lamb of God was killed by and for all mankind.

verse.text: The chief priests of the Jews therefore said to Pilate, Do not write, The King of the Jews, but that He said, I am the King of the Jews.
Pilate answered, [note]1[/note]What I have written, I have written.
verse.note: What Pilate wrote was not of himself but of God's sovereignty.

verse.text: The soldiers then, when they had crucified Jesus, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]took His garments and made four parts, a part for each soldier, [i]and they took[/i] the [note]2[/note]tunic as well. But the [note]2[/note]tunic was seamless, woven from the top throughout.
verse.note: In His crucifixion, the Lord's right to be clothed ([link]vv. 23-24[/link]) and to drink ([link]vv. 28-30[/link]) was stripped from Him, along with His life.
A shirt-like undergarment.

verse.text: They said therefore to one another, Let us not tear it, but let us cast lots for it [i]to see[/i] whose it shall be, that the Scripture might be fulfilled which says, [xref]a[/xref]"They divided My garments among themselves, and for My clothing they cast lots." So then the soldiers [note]1[/note]did these things.
verse.note: This was not of the soldiers but of God's sovereignty.

verse.text: And there were standing by the cross of Jesus His mother and His mother's [note]1[/note]sister [i]and[/i] Mary the [i]wife[/i] of Clopas and [xref]a[/xref]Mary the Magdalene.
verse.note: Salome ([link]Mark 15:40[/link]), the wife of Zebedee and the mother of James and John ([link]Matt. 27:56[/link]).

verse.text: Then Jesus, seeing His mother and the disciple whom He loved standing by, said to His mother, [xref]a[/xref]Woman, [note]1[/note]behold, your son.
verse.note: In [link]Luke 23:43[/link] the Lord said to one of the two thieves crucified with Him, "Today you shall be with Me in Paradise." That word was in regard to salvation, since Luke's Gospel proves that the Lord is the sinner's Savior. Here, in [link]vv. 26-27[/link], the Lord said to His mother, "Behold, your son," and to the disciple whom He loved, "Behold, your mother." These words indicate a life-union, since this Gospel testifies that the Lord is life imparted into His believers. It is by this life that His beloved disciple could be one with Him and become the son of His mother, and that she could become the mother of His beloved disciple.

verse.text: Then He said to the disciple, [note]1[/note]Behold, your mother. And from that hour the disciple took her into his own [i]home.[/i]
verse.note: See note [link]26[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: After this, Jesus, knowing that all things had now been finished [i]and[/i] so that the Scripture might be fulfilled, said, [xref]a[/xref]I [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]thirst.
verse.note: Thirst is a taste of death ([link]Luke 16:24[/link]; [link]Rev. 21:8[/link]). The Lord Jesus suffered this for us on the cross ([link]Heb. 2:9[/link]).

verse.text: There was lying [i]there[/i] a vessel full of vinegar; therefore, they put a sponge full of vinegar on hyssop and brought it to His mouth.
Then when Jesus had taken the [note]1[/note]vinegar, He said, It is [note]2[/note]finished! And He bowed His head and delivered up His spirit.
verse.note: In [link]Matt. 27:34[/link] and [link]Mark 15:23[/link], wine mingled with gall and myrrh was offered to the Lord as a stupefying drink before His crucifixion, but He would not drink it. In this verse vinegar was offered to Him in a mocking way at the end of His crucifixion ([link]Luke 23:36[/link]).

In His crucifixion the Lord was still working, and through His crucifixion He finished the work of His all-inclusive death, by which He accomplished redemption, terminated the old creation, and released His resurrection life to bring forth the new creation to fulfill God's purpose. In the process of death He proved to His opposers and His believers, by the way He behaved, that He was life. The dreadful environment of death did not frighten Him in the least; rather, it provided a contrast that proved strongly that He, as life, was versus death and could not be affected by death in any way. Therefore, the work that the Lord finished here included the accomplishing of redemption, the termination of the old creation, the release of His resurrection life, and the displaying of Himself as the life that cannot be affected by death.

verse.text: Then the Jews, since it was the [i]day of[/i] preparation [i]and[/i] so that the bodies might not [xref]a[/xref]remain on the cross on the Sabbath (for that Sabbath day was a great [i]Sabbath[/i]), requested of Pilate that their legs might be broken and that they might be taken away.
